explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Post-stroke neuropsychiatric syndromes reflect disruption of cortical–subcortical circuits. Mania arises when lesions interrupt inhibitory fronto-striatal-limbic pathways.
• The caudate nucleus is a key node in the associative and limbic basal ganglia loops, modulating mood and executive drive.
• Lesions here disinhibit the thalamus and frontal cortex, producing hyperactivity, pressured speech, and flight of ideas.
• Other basal ganglia structures (e.g., putamen) and right-sided frontal lesions can cause disinhibition, but classic manic syndromes localize to caudate involvement. (125 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Lesions of the caudate nucleus disrupt the ventral striatum’s regulatory control over limbic outputs, leading to mania. Starkstein and Robinson (1988) first described post-stroke mania localized to the anterior caudate on CT/MRI. Subsequent series (Shiroma et al., 2014) confirmed that right caudate infarcts carry a 4-fold increased risk of manic presentations versus other basal ganglia infarcts. Current AHA/ASA 2021 guidelines on post-stroke neurobehavioral care recommend careful monitoring for mania in patients with basal ganglia lesions (Class IIa, Level B). Functional imaging shows caudate lesions produce hypermetabolism in the orbitofrontal cortex and anterior cingulate, correlating with flight of ideas and psychomotor agitation. Thus, the caudate is the anatomically and pathophysiologically sound answer.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Thalamus
• Thalamic infarcts classically produce pure sensory or motor deficits (e.g., Dejerine–Roussy syndrome), not primary mania.
• Misconception: “Any deep structure lesion causes mood changes.” Thalamic strokes more often yield cognitive slowing and dysarthria, not flight of ideas.

C. Frontal lobe
• Frontal infarcts can cause disinhibition or apathy, but true manic syndromes (pressured speech, euphoria) require basal ganglia–limbic loop disruption.
• Differentiation: Frontal lesions yield dysexecutive syndrome, abulia, or impulsivity without classic manic phenomenology.

D. Temporal lobe
• Temporal lobe damage impairs memory, language (dominant side), or causes visual/auditory hallucinations in epilepsy, not stereotyped mania.
• Common error: equating limbic structure damage with mania; mesial temporal lesions more often cause affective flattening or seizures, not mania.

Comparison Table

FeatureCaudate (Correct)ThalamusFrontal LobeTemporal Lobe
CircuitBasal ganglia-limbic loopThalamo-cortical relayPrefrontal networksLimbic memory networks
Typical DeficitMania (flight of ideas)Sensory/motor syndromesDysexecutive, apathy, disinhibitionMemory impairment, seizures
Imaging FindingHead of caudate infarctVentral posterolateral/midline lesionsFrontal cortical infarctMedial/lateral temporal lesion
Behavioral OutcomePressured speech, euphoriaCognitive slowing, painImpulsivity without maniaSeizure focus, memory loss

Clinical Pearls

- Post-stroke mania is most often seen with right-sided basal ganglia (caudate) lesions disrupting orbitofrontal loops.
• Differentiate mania from impulsive disinhibition: true mania includes elated mood and goal-directed overactivity.
• Early recognition guides management: mood stabilizers (valproate, lithium) are effective but require caution in renal/hepatic impairment.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking orbitofrontal disinhibition from frontal lobe damage for manic syndrome.
• Assuming any subcortical stroke spares mood—neglecting basal ganglia’s role in affect regulation.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA “Guidelines for the Prevention of Stroke in Patients With Stroke and Transient Ischemic Attack” (2021): Recommends routine screening for post-stroke mood disorders in basal ganglia infarcts (Class IIa, Level B).
• NICE “Bipolar Disorder: Assessment and Management” (2018): Endorses valproate or lithium for manic episodes, with adjustments in elderly and post-stroke patients (Evidence Level 1A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The ventral (limbic) striatum—chiefly head of the caudate—integrates cortical inputs from the orbitofrontal cortex and anterior cingulate, relaying through the mediodorsal thalamus. Lesions here release subcortical disinhibition, manifesting as mania.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Infarction of the caudate head abolishes GABAergic inhibition of the globus pallidus interna, leading to thalamocortical overactivity. The resultant hyperexcitability of orbitofrontal circuits produces elevated mood and psychomotor agitation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Post-stroke new behavioral change →
2. Neuropsychiatric assessment (mood rating scales) →
3. MRI to localize lesion (focus on basal ganglia) →
4. Exclude delirium, metabolic causes →
5. Initiate mood treatment if criteria for mania met.

Neuroimaging Pearls

DWI/FLAIR MRI sequences will show hyperintense signal in the anterior caudate head. Volumetric studies correlate lesion size with mania severity.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: Valproic acid (loading dose 15–20 mg/kg) with monitoring of liver function.
• Lithium is effective but requires strict renal dosing and serum monitoring to avoid toxicity in the elderly.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. On board exams, expect post-stroke neurobehavioral vignettes testing lesion localization within fronto-striatal circuits, often contrasting basal ganglia versus cortical lesions.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Ocular bobbing consists of a rapid downward saccade followed by a slow, passive upward drift. It is classically seen in comatose patients with ventral pontine lesions. Key neuroanatomical concepts:
• Vertical saccade burst neurons reside in the pontine paramedian reticular formation (PPRF) for downward movements and in the rostral interstitial nucleus of the MLF (riMLF) for upward movements.
• Disruption of pontine burst neurons abolishes the active phase of the upward saccade, yielding only a passive drift, while corrective downward saccades remain intact.
• Recognizing specific eye‐movement patterns (e.g., ocular bobbing vs. nystagmus) enables precise brainstem localization at the bedside.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Ocular bobbing is pathognomonic for pontine involvement. Ropper & Samuels (2021) describe how lesions in the ventral pons interrupt burst neuron firing in the PPRF, abolishing active upward saccades and leaving only a passive drift. In a prospective cohort (Johnson et al., Neurology 2018;90:957–964), 92% of comatose patients with ocular bobbing had diffusion‐confirmed pontine infarcts. AHA/ASA 2019 stroke guidelines emphasize that recognition of brainstem ocular signs, including bobbing, mandates urgent MRI/MRA to identify posterior circulation infarction and consider reperfusion therapy (Level A evidence). The fast downward phase is mediated by intact oculomotor corrective pathways, while the slow upward drift reflects loss of burst activity.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Medulla
• Medullary lesions more often produce ocular lateropulsion, skew deviation or upbeat/downbeat nystagmus due to vestibular nucleus involvement.
• Misconception: any brainstem lesion alters vertical eye movements; in reality, the medulla lacks burst neuron groups for saccades.
• Differentiator: medullary strokes present with Wallenberg signs and no characteristic fast‐slow bobbing.

C. Midbrain
• Midbrain pathology (e.g., Parinaud’s) causes vertical gaze palsy, convergence‐retraction nystagmus and lid retraction, not ocular bobbing.
• Misconception: rostral interstitial dysfunction produces bobbing; actually riMLF lesions block both up and down saccades symmetrically.
• Differentiator: midbrain lesions yield limited upward gaze rather than a fast‐down/slow‐up pattern.

D. Cerebellum
• Cerebellar damage results in gaze‐evoked nystagmus, saccadic dysmetria or opsoclonus, not ocular bobbing.
• Misconception: cerebellar vermis involvement alters vertical control like brainstem; but cerebellar pathology affects calibration, not burst generation.
• Differentiator: cerebellar nystagmus is rhythmic and direction‐fixed, lacking the biphasic velocity profile of bobbing.

Comparison Table

FeaturePons Lesion (Ocular Bobbing)Medulla LesionMidbrain LesionCerebellar Lesion
Eye‐movement patternFast downward saccade, slow upward driftOcular lateropulsion, skew deviationUpward gaze palsy, convergence‐retractionGaze‐evoked nystagmus, dysmetria
Burst neuron involvementPPRF vertical burst neuronsAbsent for vertical saccadesriMLF for vertical saccadesNone (calibration center)
Associated clinical signsPinpoint pupils, coma, quadriparesisIpsilateral facial loss, ataxiaLight‐near dissociation, lid retractionLimb/truncal ataxia
Imaging findingsDWI MRI: pontine infarctDWI MRI: lateral medullary infarctMRI: dorsal midbrain lesionMRI: cerebellar infarct/degeneration

Clinical Pearls

- Ocular bobbing in coma localizes almost exclusively to ventral pontine lesions.
• It carries a guarded prognosis: often seen in large pontine infarcts or hemorrhages.
• Differentiate from ocular flutter (horizontal back‐to‐back saccades) by its vertical direction and fast-slow phase.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misreading ocular bobbing as nystagmus: nystagmus has a slow‐fast pattern and rhythmic oscillations, while bobbing is fast‐slow and monophasic each cycle.
2. Attributing any vertical gaze abnormality to the midbrain: midbrain lesions cause paralysis rather than a biphasic drift‐correct pattern.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Powers WJ et al. “2019 AHA/ASA Guideline for the Early Management of Patients with Acute Ischemic Stroke.” Recommendation: In posterior circulation stroke with brainstem ocular signs (e.g., ocular bobbing), obtain emergent MRI/MRA and assess for reperfusion (Class I; Level A).
2. Markus HS et al. “ESO Guidelines on Posterior Circulation Stroke” (2021). Recommendation: Identification of ocular bobbing warrants urgent vascular imaging for basilar artery evaluation (Class IIa; Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The PPRF in the ventral pons contains burst neurons initiating vertical saccades. Lesions disrupt excitatory burst inputs to the oculomotor nuclei, abolishing active upward gaze. Downward corrective saccades remain intact via preserved inhibitory burst neurons, producing the characteristic downward “snap” and slow drift.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Pontine lesion → loss of burst neuron firing for upward saccades → passive tonic vestibular/position‐holding forces drive slow upward drift → intact oculomotor corrective circuits trigger fast downward reset.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Observe eye movement in comatose or encephalopathic patient.
2. Differentiate bobbing (fast‐down/slow‐up) from nystagmus (slow‐fast).
3. Assess for additional pontine signs (pinpoint pupils, quadriparesis).
4. Order urgent brain MRI with DWI and MRA.
5. Initiate stroke protocol if pontine infarct/hemorrhage confirmed.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Small pontine infarcts may be occult on CT; MRI DWI is highly sensitive.
• FLAIR hyperintensity in ventral pons correlates with ocular bobbing.
• MRA can identify basilar perforator occlusions causing pontine strokes.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. On boards, ocular bobbing is a high‐yield sign for pontine lesions, often tested in the context of coma localization or brainstem stroke. Clinicians are expected to distinguish it from other vertical eye‐movement disorders.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Horizontal conjugate gaze begins with the frontal eye field (FEF) in the cortex, which sends signals to the contralateral paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF). The PPRF activates the abducens nucleus to abduct the ipsilateral eye and, via the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), coordinates adduction of the contralateral eye through the oculomotor nucleus. A lesion of the MLF produces internuclear ophthalmoplegia—failure of adduction on one side with abducting nystagmus of the opposite eye. One-and-a-half syndrome combines an ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy (due to PPRF or abducens nucleus involvement) with internuclear ophthalmoplegia (MLF lesion). Clinically, patients cannot look toward the side of the lesion with either eye (“one”), and when looking away, the ipsilateral eye cannot adduct (“half”).

Evidence-Based Analysis

One-and-a-half syndrome localizes to the ipsilateral pontine tegmentum where the PPRF/abducens nucleus and MLF lie in close proximity. Lesions here abolish ipsilateral gaze in both eyes (PPRF/VI nucleus involvement) and interrupt internuclear fibers (MLF), preventing adduction of the ipsilateral eye on contralateral gaze. Landmark series (Fisher, 1967; Manni & Bastianelli, 1993) and recent diffusion tensor imaging studies (Chen et al., Neurology 2023) consistently demonstrate infarcts or demyelinating plaques in this region in patients with one-and-a-half syndrome. Etiologies include pontine infarction—where AHA/ASA 2018 guidelines recommend IV alteplase within 4.5 hours for eligible brainstem strokes (Class I, Level A)—and demyelination, which often responds to high-dose IV methylprednisolone per AAN 2018 practice parameters (Level B). Thus, the convergence of clinical exam, neuroanatomy, and imaging confirms localization to the ipsilateral PPRF plus MLF.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Ipsilateral frontal eye field
• Lesion here causes a contralateral horizontal gaze palsy, not an ipsilateral one-and-a-half syndrome.
• Misconception: supranuclear vs nuclear/tract localization differences.

C. Contralateral superior colliculus
• Superior colliculus lesions produce saccadic initiation deficits but spare conjugate gaze pathways and the MLF.
• Key difference: collicular lesions affect voluntary saccades, not coordinated abduction/adduction pattern.

D. Ipsilateral oculomotor nucleus
• Oculomotor nucleus lesions cause ptosis, pupillary involvement, and medial rectus weakness, but do not impair ipsilateral abduction or produce a bilateral gaze palsy.
• Confuses nuclear oculomotor vs internuclear/pontine lesions.

Comparison Table

OptionLesion SiteHorizontal Gaze FindingAdduction Finding
B (✓)Ipsilateral PPRF + MLFAbolition of gaze toward lesionIpsilateral adduction failure
AIpsilateral FEFContralateral gaze palsyNormal adduction
CContralateral superior colliculusSaccadic initiation deficitsNormal adduction
DIpsilateral oculomotor nucleusNormal abductionIpsilateral adduction weakness + ptosis

Clinical Pearls

- Variants: “eight-and-a-half syndrome” adds facial nerve (VII) involvement to one-and-a-half syndrome.
• Distinguish PPRF (ipsilateral gaze palsy) from FEF (contralateral gaze palsy) by side of conjugate gaze deficit.
• Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (MLF lesion) often shows abducting nystagmus in the non-adducting eye.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing one-and-a-half syndrome with isolated internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO)—the former includes a complete ipsilateral gaze palsy plus INO.
• Mislocalizing to the oculomotor nerve when both eyes cannot look toward one side; oculomotor nucleus lesions spare abduction.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guideline 2018 (Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke): recommends IV alteplase within 4.5 hours for eligible patients with suspected pontine strokes presenting with gaze palsies (Class I, Level A).
2. AAN Practice Parameter 2018 (Management of Acute Relapse in Multiple Sclerosis): advises high-dose IV methylprednisolone (500–1000 mg/day for 3–5 days) for symptomatic demyelinating events including internuclear ophthalmoplegia (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- PPRF: horizontal gaze center in the dorsal pons; projects to abducens nucleus.
• Abducens nucleus: innervates ipsilateral lateral rectus; MLF fibers cross midline to contralateral oculomotor nucleus.
• MLF: interconnects VI nucleus with III nucleus; lesion yields internuclear ophthalmoplegia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Lesion in the pontine tegmentum disrupts:
1. The PPRF/abducens complex → loss of ipsilateral horizontal gaze (both eyes).
2. The ipsilateral MLF → failure of adduction in the ipsilateral eye on contralateral gaze.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed ocular motility exam: assess conjugate gaze and adduction.
2. Differentiate internuclear (MLF) vs nuclear vs supranuclear causes by testing saccades and vestibulo-ocular reflex.
3. Brain MRI with DWI/FLAIR to identify pontine infarct or demyelinating plaque.
4. Etiology-directed therapy (thrombolysis vs steroids).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Pontine infarcts appear hyperintense on DWI within hours; FLAIR shows demyelinating plaques in MS.
• High-resolution tractography (DTI) can delineate focal MLF disruption in research settings.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam.
One-and-a-half syndrome is frequently tested in neuroanatomy/localization questions, often as a variant (e.g., eight-and-a-half syndrome) to assess mastery of brainstem gaze pathways.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Peduncular hallucinosis is characterized by vivid, formed visual hallucinations in clear sensorium, typically arising after lesions in the dorsal midbrain or adjacent thalamus.
• The midbrain houses the superior colliculus and periaqueductal gray, integral to visual processing and modulation.
• The paramedian thalamic nuclei relay visual and cortical feedback loops; disruption leads to “release” phenomena.
• Classic cases follow vascular insults (e.g., midbrain infarct) or demyelination affecting these structures, distinguishing them from cortical or limbic causes of hallucinations.

(Word count: 92)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Peduncular hallucinosis results from focal lesions in the midbrain and thalamus that disrupt normal inhibition of visual association areas. Carota et al. (2000, Brain) reviewed 26 patients with lesions at the level of the rostral midbrain or paramedian thalami, all of whom experienced vivid, formed hallucinations of people or animals. Lesion mapping studies using diffusion‐weighted MRI (Bogousslavsky et al., 1989) localize these phenomena to the superior cerebellar peduncle decussation and nearby paramedian thalamic nuclei. The pathophysiological mechanism is thought to be deafferentation of the visual cortex (a release phenomenon) combined with abnormal cholinergic–serotonergic neurotransmission in the midbrain–thalamic reticular formation. No major clinical practice guidelines specifically address peduncular hallucinosis; management is extrapolated from treatment of Charles Bonnet syndrome and visual hallucinations in Parkinson’s disease (NICE 2018 recommends low-dose atypical antipsychotics when distressing).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Cerebellum and pons
• Incorrect because lesions here produce vestibulocerebellar syndromes (ataxia, nystagmus), not formed visual hallucinations.
• Misconception: All brainstem lesions cause visual release phenomena.
• Key feature: Cerebellar/pons pathology yields motor and ocular movement disturbances, not vivid visions.

C. Cortex and basal ganglia
• Incorrect; cortical lesions (e.g., occipital lobe) cause simple visual phenomena (phosphenes), not complex formed images. Basal ganglia lesions manifest with movement disorders, not hallucinations.
• Misconception: Basal ganglia dysfunction always leads to psychiatric symptoms.
• Key feature: Complex hallucinations require subcortical release from midbrain–thalamic gating, not striatal circuitry.

D. Hippocampus and amygdala
• Incorrect; limbic structures mediate memory and emotion. Lesions here produce memory deficits or emotional disturbances, not primary visual hallucinations.
• Misconception: All hallucinations stem from limbic overactivity.
• Key feature: Visual hallucinations in clear consciousness implicate visual relay pathways, not hippocampal–amygdalar circuits.

Comparison Table

FeatureMidbrain & ThalamusCerebellum & PonsCortex & Basal GangliaHippocampus & Amygdala
Lesion LocationRostral midbrain, paramedian thalamusCerebellar hemispheres, ponsCortical grey matter, striatumMedial temporal lobe
Hallucination TypeVivid, formed figures/animalsNone (ataxia, tremor)Simple visual phenomena or motorMemory flashbacks, emotional
Consciousness & InsightPreservedIntactPreservedMay have emotional lability
PathophysiologyRelease of visual cortex, deafferentationMotor pathway disruptionLocal cortical hyperexcitabilityLimbic dysfunction

Clinical Pearls

- Peduncular hallucinosis classically involves well-formed people or animals, preserved insight, and occurs in clear consciousness.
• MRI with diffusion‐weighted sequences is optimal to identify small midbrain or thalamic infarcts.
• Atypical antipsychotics (e.g., quetiapine at 12.5–50 mg nightly) can alleviate distressing hallucinations when they persist.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Attributing formed visual hallucinations to occipital cortex lesions—these typically produce simple phosphenes, not complex scenes.
2. Assuming limbic or basal ganglia lesions cause visual hallucinations—these regions yield memory/emotional or movement disorders, not vivid visual release phenomena.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Peduncular hallucinosis is a high‐yield topic linking neuroanatomical lesion localization with phenomenology; often tested as a vignettes where patients describe formed visual hallucinations post‐brainstem stroke.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

[Optional Latest Guidelines and Trials]

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] The cerebellar vermis, especially its anterior (rostral) portion, functions as the spinocerebellum to integrate proprioceptive input from the trunk and proximal limbs and modulate axial muscle tone via the fastigial nucleus. Lesions here disrupt vestibulospinal and reticulospinal pathways, leading to truncal instability. Clinically, rostral vermis damage manifests as a broad-based, unsteady gait (truncal ataxia). By contrast, cerebellar hemisphere lesions produce appendicular ataxia (e.g., intention tremor), and flocculonodular lobe pathology leads to vestibulo-ocular signs (e.g., nystagmus).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Rostral vermis lesions impair coordination of trunk and proximal lower-limb muscles. Schmahmann and Sherman (1998) characterized this as “midline cerebellar syndrome,” dominated by gait and truncal ataxia. Green et al. (2019, Neurology) correlated MRI‐quantified anterior vermis volume loss with gait velocity and balance metrics (r=0.72, p<0.001). Vestibulospinal tract disruption explains the broad-based stance: patients widen their base to lower their center of gravity and compensate for instability. The American Academy of Neurology (AAN) practice guideline (2020) on ataxia evaluation emphasizes clinical differentiation: wide-based gait is a level-B recommendation signifying midline cerebellar involvement. In contrast, intention tremor (hemispheric/dentate nucleus), dysarthria (posterior vermis or hemispheric connections), and nystagmus (flocculonodular lobe) are less specific to rostral vermis defects.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Intention tremor
• Why incorrect: Reflects appendicular ataxia due to cerebellar hemisphere/dentate nucleus lesions.
• Misconception: Ataxia = tremor; students often overlook truncal vs limb ataxia.
• Differentiator: Intention tremor worsens on goal-directed movement, not stance.

C. Dysarthria
• Why incorrect: Scanning speech arises with midline (whole vermis) or hemispheric involvement, not isolated rostral vermis.
• Misconception: All cerebellar lesions cause dysarthria; actually posterior vermis and hemispheric circuits mediate speech coordination.
• Differentiator: Speech impairment vs gait instability.

D. Nystagmus
• Why incorrect: Characteristic of flocculonodular lobe (vestibulocerebellum) disruption.
• Misconception: Any cerebellar lesion causes ocular signs; localization matters.
• Differentiator: Gaze-evoked/positional nystagmus vs broad-based gait.

Comparison Table

OptionClinical FeatureCerebellar RegionKey Distinction
AWide-based gaitRostral vermis (spinocerebellum)Truncal ataxia; stance instability
BIntention tremorCerebellar hemisphere (dentate nucleus)Limb ataxia; action tremor
CDysarthriaPosterior vermis/hemispheric pathwaysScanning speech; coordination of articulation
DNystagmusFlocculonodular lobe (vestibulocerebellum)Ocular motor dysfunction; gaze-evoked

Clinical Pearls

• Distinguish truncal vs appendicular ataxia by observing stance and gait (wide base) vs limb movement.
• Rostral vermis pathology spares fine limb coordination but severely impairs balance.
• Vestibulocerebellar (flocculonodular) lesions frequently present with head bobbing, nystagmus, and vertigo—features absent in pure vermis defects.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating “ataxia” solely with intention tremor rather than recognizing gait impairment.
2. Assuming dysarthria is universal in all cerebellar lesions without appreciating regional specificity.
3. Overlooking flocculonodular vs vermal signs when localizing cerebellar pathology.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Practice Guideline on Ataxia Evaluation, 2020: Recommends use of clinical exam to localize cerebellar lesions; wide-based gait indicates midline vermis involvement (Level B).
• European Academy of Neurology (EAN) Guideline on Degenerative Cerebellar Ataxias, 2021: Advises targeted MRI of the cerebellar vermis in suspected spinocerebellar syndromes; anterior vermis hypoplasia correlates with gait ataxia severity (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The rostral vermis receives afferents from spinal and vestibular nuclei via the inferior cerebellar peduncle, processes axial proprioceptive signals, and projects through the fastigial nucleus to vestibulospinal and reticulospinal tracts, crucial for postural adjustments.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Loss of anterior vermis integrity disrupts integration of trunk and lower-limb proprioception with descending motor commands, abolishing predictive postural control. The result is increased sway and a compensatory widened stance to maintain equilibrium.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2023 exam. Cerebellar localization—differentiating vermal vs hemispheric vs flocculonodular syndromes—is a frequently tested topic on neurology specialty and internal medicine board exams, often presented as clinical vignettes emphasizing gait, limb, and ocular findings.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Horizontal conjugate gaze requires coordination between the abducens nucleus (lateral rectus) and the contralateral oculomotor nucleus (medial rectus) via the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). A focal lesion in the MLF disrupts ipsilateral medial rectus activation, producing adduction failure, while the contralateral abducens nucleus continues to fire, causing abducting nystagmus. This internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) pattern is most often demyelinating in younger patients (e.g., multiple sclerosis) and ischemic in older adults. Recognizing the specific eye‐movement pattern localizes the lesion to the MLF in the dorsal pontine tegmentum.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) results from interruption of the MLF, a heavily myelinated dorsal brainstem tract conveying excitatory fibers from the abducens internuclear neurons to the contralateral oculomotor nucleus. In a right INO, attempted leftward gaze fails to activate the right medial rectus—hence impaired adduction—while the left abducens nucleus overfires, producing left‐beat nystagmus. UpToDate (2024) highlights that unilateral INO in older adults is usually ischemic (AHA/ASA 2019) and demyelinating in younger patients (AAN 2023). Richter et al. (Neurology 2022) demonstrated that high‐resolution MRI (7 T) detects MLF lesions with >90% sensitivity, guiding targeted evaluation. Occipital and frontal lobe lesions produce visual field deficits or conjugate gaze palsies without this characteristic adduction‐nystagmus dissociation.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Left MLF
A left MLF lesion causes impaired adduction of the left eye and right‐beat nystagmus on rightward gaze—the mirror image of the presentation. Confusing laterality of the MLF often leads to mislocalization; correct diagnosis hinges on matching the side of adduction failure to the lesion side.

C. Right occipital lobe
Occipital lesions produce contralateral homonymous hemianopia and may cause eyes to deviate toward the lesion in acute stroke but do not disrupt brainstem internuclear pathways. They never generate an INO pattern of adduction failure plus contralateral abducting nystagmus.

D. Left frontal lobe
Lesions of the frontal eye fields (e.g., left frontal lobe) result in an ipsiversive conjugate gaze palsy (inability to look right voluntarily) without internuclear adduction deficits or contralateral abducting nystagmus. They impair saccade initiation, not inter‐nuclear coordination.

Comparison Table

Lesion LocalizationIpsilateral Adduction DeficitContralateral Abducting NystagmusGaze Affected
Right MLF (INO)Yes (right eye on left gaze)Yes (left-beat)Leftward gaze
Left MLFYes (left eye on right gaze)Yes (right-beat)Rightward gaze
Right Occipital LobeNoNoHomonymous field cut
Left Frontal LobeNoNoVolitional right gaze

Clinical Pearls

- Convergence is spared in INO because the medial rectus subnucleus and its convergence interneurons bypass the MLF.
• Bilateral INO in a young adult strongly suggests multiple sclerosis; unilateral INO in an older patient often reflects pontine ischemia.
• INO may precede other brainstem signs; subtle ocular motility testing can unmask early MLF lesions.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking a PPRF lesion (conjugate gaze palsy) for INO—PPRF damage abolishes both eyes’ movement, whereas INO only impairs adduction.
• Reversing the side of nystagmus versus the adduction deficit; nystagmus always beats in the abducting (intact) eye.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA), 2019, Guidelines for Early Management of Patients with Acute Ischemic Stroke: Class I, Level A evidence for obtaining emergent MRI with DWI and T2/FLAIR to identify brainstem infarctions including MLF involvement.
• American Academy of Neurology (AAN), 2023, Multiple Sclerosis Practice Guideline: Recommendation 1.3 (Level B) endorses high-dose IV methylprednisolone (1 g daily for 3–5 days) for acute demyelinating INO to accelerate neurological recovery.
• Richter W, Smith J, et al. Neurology, 2022: A prospective cohort (n = 50) demonstrated 7 T MRI detected MLF lesions in 95% of clinically confirmed INO versus 80% with 3 T imaging.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The MLF runs in the dorsal pontine tegmentum, adjacent to the floor of the fourth ventricle. It links abducens internuclear neurons in the pons to the contralateral oculomotor nucleus in the midbrain. Disruption here specifically impairs adduction of the eye ipsilateral to the lesion and spares convergence pathways.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

A focal MLF lesion severs excitatory internuclear fibers from the abducens nucleus that would normally trigger the contralateral medial rectus. On attempted lateral gaze, the abducens‐driven lateral rectus functions, but medial rectus activation fails, causing an adduction deficit. Concurrently, the intact abducens nucleus overfires, producing nystagmus in the abducting eye.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Perform bedside ocular motility testing—assess adduction and abduction in lateral gazes.
2. Differentiate INO from conjugate gaze palsy (test convergence; preserved in INO).
3. Obtain brain MRI with DWI and T2/FLAIR to localize the MLF lesion.
4. Evaluate etiology: MS workup (CSF oligoclonal bands, evoked potentials) versus vascular risk assessment.

Neuroimaging Pearls

T2/FLAIR MRI reveals a hyperintense focus in the dorsal pontine tegmentum at the MLF. DWI sequences detect acute infarction. Ultra-high-field 7 T MRI further enhances detection of small demyelinating or ischemic foci.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Acute demyelinating INO: IV methylprednisolone 1 g daily for 3–5 days (AAN Level B).
• Acute ischemic INO: manage per AHA/ASA stroke guidelines—antiplatelet therapy, risk factor control; no MLF‐specific drug.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia and MLF localization are frequently tested as classic brainstem syndromes on neurology and neuroanatomy examinations, often presented as eye‐movement vignettes requiring precise lateralization.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] - Visual hallucinations are perceptions without external stimuli, categorized as simple (lights, shapes) or complex (formed people, animals).
• Peduncular (Lhermitte’s) hallucinosis: vivid, formed visual scenes, often colorful and moving, with preserved insight; classically due to lesions in the midbrain–thalamic region.
• Differentiate from Charles Bonnet syndrome (occipital deafferentation) and temporal lobe visual phenomena (epileptic auras with altered consciousness).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Peduncular hallucinosis results from lesions affecting the superior cerebellar peduncle, periaqueductal gray, or paramedian thalamic region, causing disinhibition of visual association areas (Lhermitte, 1920). ffytche et al. (Brain, 1998) reported midbrain infarcts in 82% of cases, confirming the brainstem origin. Boisseau et al. (Neurology, 2018) systematically reviewed 50 patients, highlighting that interruption of cholinergic and serotonergic projections from the midbrain–thalamic complex underlies these formed hallucinations. No occipital, temporal, or parietal lesions reliably produce the pattern of peduncular hallucinosis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Occipital lobe lesion: Produces Charles Bonnet syndrome—visual deafferentation causes simple or static complex images in visually impaired patients; lacks the vivid, dynamic scenes of peduncular origin.
C. Temporal lobe lesion: Yields visual auras and illusions in epilepsy, often with olfactory/gustatory components and impaired consciousness; mechanism is cortical hyperexcitability, not subcortical disinhibition.
D. Parietal lobe lesion: Leads to visual neglect, optic ataxia, or agnosia via dorsal stream disruption; these manifest as perceptual deficits rather than vivid formed hallucinations.

Comparison Table

Lesion LocationHallucination TypeMechanism
MidbrainPeduncular hallucinosisBrainstem disinhibition of cortex
Occipital lobeCharles Bonnet syndromeCortical deafferentation
Temporal lobeEpileptic visual aurasCortical hyperexcitability
Parietal lobeVisual neglect/agnosiaDorsal stream dysfunction

Clinical Pearls

- Peduncular hallucinosis often occurs at dusk or early night; patients describe movement and soundless dialogue with retained insight.
• Always obtain MRI with DWI/FLAIR of brainstem and thalamus when faced with new-onset complex visual hallucinations.
• Look for accompanying brainstem signs (e.g., vertical gaze palsy, pupillary abnormalities) to localize the lesion.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mislabeling Charles Bonnet syndrome as peduncular hallucinosis—check visual acuity and ophthalmologic assessment.
• Assuming all complex visual hallucinations localize to cortex; midbrain lesions can elicit vivid images via release phenomena.
• Overlooking thalamic strokes; peduncular hallucinosis may arise from paramedian thalamic infarcts.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ffytche EP et al., Brain (1998): MRI case series of 28 patients demonstrating midbrain–thalamic infarcts in 82% with peduncular hallucinosis, supporting the disinhibition hypothesis.
• Boisseau E et al., Neurology (2018): Systematic review of 50 patients highlighting midbrain and thalamic involvement; recommended targeted neuroimaging protocols (Level IV evidence).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Peduncular hallucinosis is a high-yield board topic under visual neuroanatomy and brainstem lesion localization, often tested in multiple-choice format.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Hallucinations are perceptions in the absence of external stimuli and can affect any sensory modality. Localization relies on identifying which sensory pathways and association cortices are involved:
• Primary sensory cortices (e.g., occipital for vision, Heschl’s gyrus in temporal lobe for audition) generate elementary phenomena when stimulated.
• Higher-order association cortices (particularly in the temporal lobe) produce complex, formed hallucinations by integrating memory, emotion, and sensory input.
• Mesial temporal structures (uncus, hippocampus) are prone to epileptogenic discharges causing olfactory, auditory or visual hallucinations.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Temporal lobe lesions—whether due to neoplasm, mesial temporal sclerosis or focal seizures—are classically associated with complex auditory, olfactory and formed visual hallucinations. Penfield’s cortical stimulation studies (Penfield & Perot, 1963) demonstrated that electrical activation of the superior temporal gyrus evokes elementary sounds, while stimulation of the parahippocampal gyrus produces complex, often autobiographical imagery. Functional MRI of schizophrenia patients during auditory hallucinations shows hyperactivation of the superior temporal cortex and Wernicke’s area (Shergill et al., 2000, American Journal of Psychiatry). The International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) 2017 classification of focal epilepsies recognizes “sensory auras” (including auditory, visual and olfactory hallucinations) as originating in temporal or temporo‐occipital regions (ILAE Commission, 2017).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Midbrain
• Peduncular hallucinosis arises from lesions in the midbrain tegmentum but is rare. These hallucinations are vivid, formed visual phenomena accompanied by oculomotor signs and sleep–wake disturbances, distinguishing them from the more common temporal‐lobe hallucinations.
B. Occipital lobe
• Lesions here cause elementary visual hallucinations (flashes, shapes, colors) without complex formed images, and do not produce auditory or olfactory phenomena.
C. Frontal lobe
• Frontal lesions produce disinhibition, confabulation or mood/personality changes but seldom primary sensory hallucinations; frontal involvement may modulate prefrontal executive control over sensory cortices rather than generate hallucinations directly.

Comparison Table

RegionPrimary ModalityHallucination TypeKey Features
Temporal lobeAuditory, Olfactory, Complex VisualFormed (voices, smells, scenes)Memory‐linked, emotional content; epileptic auras
Occipital lobeVisualElementary (flashes, shapes)Simple geometrical patterns; lacks narrative
MidbrainVisual (rare)Vivid formed imagesAssociated ocular motor signs, REM–wake confusional states
Frontal lobeNoneBehavioral disinhibitionExecutive dysfunction, confabulation, no true sensory hallucinations

Clinical Pearls

- Differentiate elementary versus formed hallucinations to guide localization: elementary = primary cortex; formed = association cortex.
• Olfactory auras (“smell of burning rubber”) localize to the uncus/mesial temporal structures—uncinate fits often precede temporal lobe seizures.
• Peduncular hallucinosis should be suspected when vivid visual hallucinations coexist with midbrain oculomotor signs and normal primary visual fields.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all visual hallucinations with occipital lesions—fails to recognize complex, formed images originate in temporal association cortex.
2. Ignoring multimodal auras in temporal lobe epilepsy—students may overlook that olfactory and gustatory hallucinations also localize to the temporal lobe.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) Commission Report, 2017
• Recommendation: Classify focal seizures with sensory hallucinations (auras) according to cortical region (Level IV evidence).
2. NICE Clinical Guideline CG178 (2014) on Psychosis and Schizophrenia in Adults
• Recommendation: Obtain brain MRI in first-episode psychosis to exclude an organic lesion, as temporal lobe masses can present with hallucinations (Level II evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Superior temporal gyrus (Heschl’s area): primary auditory cortex—auditory hallucinations.
• Parahippocampal gyrus and uncus: olfactory cortex—uncinate seizures with olfactory hallucinations.
• Inferior temporal gyrus and fusiform regions: complex visual imagery via ventral stream integration.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Aberrant synchronous neuronal discharges in temporal association cortices lead to false perceptual experiences. In epilepsy, loss of GABAergic inhibition in mesial temporal structures allows recurrent excitatory activity manifesting as sensory hallucinations.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm true hallucination (vs illusion or pseudohallucination).
2. Characterize modality, complexity (elementary vs formed), duration, triggers.
3. Review medications, toxins, metabolic workup.
4. EEG with focus on temporal lobe discharges.
5. MRI brain with epilepsy protocol to identify mesial temporal sclerosis or mass lesion.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- High-resolution MRI with thin coronal slices through temporal lobes reveals hippocampal sclerosis (T2/FLAIR hyperintensity, volume loss).
• Lesions in midbrain tegmentum on T2-weighted imaging suggest peduncular hallucinosis.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Temporal lobe localization for hallucinations is a high‐yield concept tested frequently in the context of focal epilepsy and neuroanatomy questions.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] - Splenium of the corpus callosum: the posterior commissural bundle connecting bilateral occipital lobes; essential for transfer of visual information from right hemisphere to the language-dominant left hemisphere.
• Visual Word Form Area (VWFA): located in the left fusiform gyrus; decodes written symbols into language. Integrity of left angular gyrus ensures preserved writing and spelling.
• Disconnection syndromes: interruption of callosal fibers produces “pure” deficits—here, pure alexia (alexia without agraphia), characterized by inability to read despite intact writing and language comprehension.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Alexia without agraphia (“pure alexia”) was first characterized by Dejerine in 1892, tracing the lesion to the splenium of the corpus callosum and adjacent left occipital cortex. Modern diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) studies (e.g., Tournier et al., 2012; Bartolomeo et al., 2013) confirm that splenial infarcts disrupt interhemispheric visual transfer to the left VWFA, producing letter‐by‐letter reading with preserved writing. The 2021 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke recommend emergent MRI with diffusion‐weighted imaging (Class I, Level A) to detect posterior circulation infarcts—including splenial lesions—enabling accurate diagnosis of disconnection syndromes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Agraphia without alexia
• Lesion in the dominant angular gyrus yields impaired writing (agraphia) but preserved reading; spares interhemispheric visual transfer.
• Misconception: confusing cortical writing center damage with callosal disconnection.

C. Alexia with agraphia
• Requires a perisylvian language‐area or left occipital/angular lesion affecting both reading and writing; not isolated to splenium.
• Differentiator: writing is also impaired.

D. Pure word deafness
• Results from bilateral superior temporal gyrus or subcortical auditory radiation lesions; speech is heard but not comprehended.
• Distinguished by preserved reading and writing of written language.

Comparison Table

SyndromeLesion LocationReadingWriting
Alexia without AgraphiaSplenium of corpus callosumImpairedIntact
Agraphia without AlexiaDominant angular gyrusNormalImpaired
Alexia with AgraphiaLeft occipital–angular region (perisylvian)ImpairedImpaired
Pure Word DeafnessBilateral superior temporal gyri/auditory radiationsNormal (visual)Intact

Clinical Pearls

- Pure alexia patients often compensate by letter‐by‐letter reading; recognition improves with scanning strategies.
• Writing-to-dictation and naming tasks remain normal; contrast with alexia with agraphia.
• DTI can quantify fractional anisotropy loss in the splenium, correlating with reading speed (Tournier et al., 2012).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Attributing pure alexia to cortical angular gyrus lesions rather than callosal disconnection.
• Failing to test writing in a patient with reading difficulty, thereby missing preserved agraphia.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2021 Guidelines: recommend emergent MRI with diffusion‐weighted imaging for suspected posterior circulation strokes to detect splenial infarcts (Class I, Level A).
2. European Stroke Organisation (ESO) Guidelines 2021: endorse MRI‐based penumbral imaging in posterior cerebral artery strokes, improving identification of callosal infarctions (Grade A, Level 1).
3. Demeyere et al., Journal of Neurology 2023: validated the Oxford Cognitive Screen reading subtest for pure alexia screening in acute stroke (sensitivity 93%).
4. Marangolo et al., Brain Stimulation 2022: randomized trial showing that repetitive TMS over the left angular gyrus improved reading speed in pure alexia patients by 23% (Level of Evidence II).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesion of the splenium severs transcallosal fibers linking right occipital visual cortex (processing intact visual input) to left VWFA in the fusiform gyrus; language production and writing centers in the angular and supramarginal gyri remain connected to dominant perisylvian networks.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Splenial infarction produces a disconnection syndrome: visual information from the intact right visual cortex cannot reach the language‐dominant left hemisphere, resulting in letter‐by‐letter reading (“pure alexia”) while motor engrams for writing, housed in left parietal areas, remain intact.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: reading aloud, writing-to-dictation, confrontation naming.
2. Neuropsychological testing: Boston Diagnostic Aphasia Examination, Oxford Cognitive Screen.
3. Neuroimaging: MRI with DWI to identify splenial lesion.
4. DTI tractography: quantify callosal fiber disruption.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Noncontrast head CT often misses small splenial infarcts.
• MRI DWI: hyperintense signal in splenium within hours of symptom onset.
• DTI: reduced fractional anisotropy in posterior callosal fibers correlates with reading impairment.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2023 exam. Disconnection syndromes—especially pure alexia from splenial lesions—are high‐yield and frequently tested as clinical vignettes requiring localization to commissural pathways.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] Nystagmus consists of a slow drift phase and a corrective fast phase; the fast phase defines its direction. Central vestibular lesions—particularly of the cerebellum—produce nystagmus present in primary gaze that is not suppressed by visual fixation. The cerebellar hemisphere (especially the flocculus and dorsal paraflocculus) houses components of the neural integrator that maintain eccentric gaze. Lesions here lead to gaze-evoked nystagmus (GEN) with a beating direction determined by imbalance in oculomotor control. Recognizing central versus peripheral nystagmus is fundamental in acute vestibular syndrome. (Word count: 103)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Cerebellar hemispheric lesions disrupt the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) adaptive gain and the gaze-holding neural integrator located in the flocculus/dorsal paraflocculus. This produces a gaze-evoked jerk nystagmus present in primary position that cannot be suppressed by fixation (Shaikh et al., Brain 2013; Leigh & Zee, The Neurology of Eye Movements, 6th ed., 2015). The fast phase toward the right indicates reduced inhibitory output from the right floccular Purkinje cells, causing an ipsiversive drift-corrective beat. AHA/ASA 2022 acute vestibular syndrome guidelines (Class I, Level B) recommend early neuroimaging when central signs like fixed direction-changing nystagmus are observed.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Tectal midbrain – Involvement here causes vertical gaze palsies (Parinaud’s) and skew deviation rather than horizontal jerk nystagmus; fast phase direction is not purely horizontal. Misconception: confusing vertical gaze centers with horizontal nystagmus generators.
C. Pontocerebellar angle – Lesions (e.g., vestibular schwannoma) cause peripheral vestibular nystagmus that typically suppresses with fixation and has a fast phase away from lesion; rarely produces primary-gaze, non-suppressed GEN. Key differentiation: fixation suppression and head-impulse test abnormality.
D. Medulla – Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) lesions can yield ocular lateropulsion or downbeat/upbeat nystagmus, not an isolated horizontal GEN at primary gaze. Common error: attributing any central vestibular sign to brainstem rather than cerebellum.

Comparison Table

Lesion SiteNystagmus TypeFast Phase DirectionFixation SuppressionGaze Dependence
Cerebellar hemisphereGaze-evoked jerk nystagmusIpsiversive (toward lesion)AbsentPresent (even primary)
Tectal midbrainVertical gaze palsy, skew deviationN/AN/AVertical dysfunction
Pontocerebellar anglePeripheral horizontal nystagmusAway from lesionPresentAbsent
Medulla (lateral)Downbeat/upbeat nystagmusVerticalVariableNot primary horizontal

Clinical Pearls

1. Gaze-evoked nystagmus in primary position that persists with fixation is almost pathognomonic of cerebellar pathology.
2. Lesions of the flocculus specifically impair the neural integrator, leading to “leaky” gaze-holding and corrective fast phases.
3. In acute vestibular syndrome, the HINTS exam (Head-Impulse, Nystagmus, Test-of-Skew) outperforms early MRI for central versus peripheral differentiation.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Interpreting the direction of the slow phase rather than the fast phase can lead to mislocalization.
2. Assuming any non-rotatory nystagmus is peripheral; central lesions often produce purely horizontal nystagmus.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2022 Guidelines on Acute Vestibular Syndrome: Recommends urgent neuroimaging for patients with gaze-evoked nystagmus or other central signs (Class I, Level B).
• EFNS/EAN 2017 Guideline on Cerebellar Ataxias: Endorses 4-aminopyridine for symptomatic treatment of cerebellar gaze-evoked and downbeat nystagmus (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The cerebellar flocculus and dorsal paraflocculus receive vestibular input and project to vestibular nuclei; Purkinje cell loss here disrupts the velocity-to-position neural integrator, causing gaze-holding failure.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Loss of inhibitory Purkinje cell output → unchecked vestibular nucleus activity → drift of eye position (slow phase) → corrective saccade (fast phase) toward side of decreased inhibition.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Perform fixation test: central nystagmus persists.
2. Conduct HINTS: normal head-impulse, direction-changing nystagmus, skew deviation → central lesion.
3. Obtain MRI with DWI to confirm cerebellar infarct or lesion.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Small cerebellar infarcts may be missed on CT; MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging and high-resolution FLAIR is preferred.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

4-Aminopyridine (5–10 mg TID) improves cerebellar gaze-holding deficits; gabapentin and memantine can also reduce amplitude of central nystagmus.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2019 exam.
Cerebellar versus peripheral nystagmus localization is a frequently tested concept, often presented as gaze-evoked or direction-changing nystagmus in primary gaze.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Acute myelopathies can be vascular, inflammatory, compressive or degenerative. The anterior spinal artery (ASA) supplies the anterior two-thirds of the cord including:
• Corticospinal tracts (motor control)
• Spinothalamic tracts (pain & temperature)
The dorsal columns (vibration & proprioception) are spared, as they are supplied by the posterior spinal arteries.
In ASA syndrome (spinal cord infarction), patients present with sudden flaccid paralysis below the lesion, loss of pain/temperature, but preserved vibration/proprioception. Differentiation from multiple sclerosis, peripheral neuropathy or anterior horn cell disease relies on time course (hyperacute vs subacute/chronic), sensory dissociation, reflex changes and imaging findings.
(This section: 102 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Spinal cord infarction due to ASA occlusion classically causes a flaccid-then-spastic paraparesis with dissociated sensory loss. MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) demonstrates hyperintensity in the anterior cord (“owl’s eyes” on axial T2) within hours.
• AHA/ASA Scientific Statement (Rabinstein et al., Stroke 2019) recommends emergent MRI with DWI for suspected spinal cord stroke (Level C-LD).
• In a multicenter series (Masson et al., Neurology 2017), 85% of ASA infarcts showed anterior horn hyperintensity and spared dorsal columns on T2.
Prompt recognition guides supportive management—maintain mean arterial pressure to optimize cord perfusion—and avoids unnecessary immunotherapies used in inflammatory myelopathies.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Multiple sclerosis
• MS lesions evolve subacutely over days to weeks, often with remissions.
• Demyelinating plaques frequently involve dorsal columns, causing proprioceptive deficits.
• Oligoclonal bands, MRI shows multifocal lesions in brain/cord, not isolated ASA territory.

C. Peripheral neuropathy
• Presents with distal, symmetric “stocking-glove” sensory loss including vibration sense.
• Motor weakness is mild, predominantly involves distal muscles rather than a spinal level.
• No clear acute spinal level or sensory level.

D. Anterior horn cell disease
• Pure motor neuron involvement (e.g., ALS, poliomyelitis) causes LMN signs without sensory loss.
• Pain and temperature pathways remain intact.
• Onset may be subacute to chronic; fasciculations and muscle atrophy are prominent.

Comparison Table

FeatureSpinal Cord Infarction (ASA)Multiple SclerosisPeripheral NeuropathyAnterior Horn Cell Disease
OnsetHyperacute (minutes–hours)Subacute (days–weeks)Insidious (months–years)Subacute–chronic
Motor deficitsFlaccid → spastic paraparesisVariable weaknessMild distal weaknessLMN weakness
Pain & temperature sensationLost below lesionOften preserved earlyLost in distal distributionPreserved
Vibration/proprioceptionPreservedOften impairedImpairedPreserved
ReflexesAreflexia acutely, later hyperreflexiaMixedHyporeflexiaHyporeflexia
MRI findingsAnterior cord hyperintensityMultifocal demyelinating plaquesNormal cord imagingNormal cord imaging

Clinical Pearls

- Acute dissociated sensory loss (pain/temperature ↓, vibration ↑) localizes to ASA territory.
• “Owl’s eyes” sign on axial T2 MRI is highly specific for ASA infarction.
• Maintain mean arterial pressure ≥85 mm Hg acutely to improve spinal perfusion.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing ASA syndrome with central cord syndrome: central cord involves upper extremities > lower and spares most trunk sensation.
2. Assuming any acute paraplegia is inflammatory myelitis and administering high-dose steroids without imaging.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Rabinstein AA et al. “Spinal Cord Infarction: A Scientific Statement from the American Heart Association.” Stroke. 2019;50(1):e23–e41.
• Recommendation: Emergent spinal MRI with DWI in suspected spinal cord stroke (Class I; Level C-LD).
2. Flanagan EP et al. “Practice Advisory: Diagnostic Approach to Acute Myelopathies.” Neurology. 2021;97(7):347–358.
• Suggestion: Distinguish vascular from inflammatory myelopathy by onset <12 h, pain, MRI pattern (anterolateral lesions for infarction) (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Anterior spinal artery arises from vertebral arteries, runs along ventral surface, supplying anterior two-thirds of cord.
• Spinothalamic fibers cross near entry level and ascend anterolaterally; corticospinal tracts descend in anterolateral columns.
• Dorsal columns (fasciculus gracilis/cuneatus) lie posteriorly, supplied by paired posterior spinal arteries.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Occlusion or hypoperfusion of the ASA—due to aortic surgery, dissection, hypotension or embolism—leads to ischemic necrosis of anterior horn cells, lateral corticospinal tracts and spinothalamic pathways. Secondary injury cascades involve excitotoxicity and inflammation, but dorsal columns remain intact.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical: Acute (<12 h) paraplegia + dissociated sensory loss.
2. Urgent MRI spine with T2 and DWI sequences.
3. Exclude compressive etiologies (epidural hematoma, abscess).
4. Vascular imaging (MR angiography) if dissection suspected.
5. Supportive care: hemodynamic optimization, early rehabilitation.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- T2-weighted “owl’s eyes” hyperintensity in anterior horns.
• DWI: restricted diffusion within anterior cord within 3 h of onset.
• Absence of contrast enhancement differentiates from inflammatory lesions.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- No specific neuroprotective agents proven.
• Antiplatelet therapy (aspirin 81–325 mg daily) recommended to reduce recurrent vascular events (Level C-EO).
• Hemodynamic support: maintain systolic BP 140–160 mm Hg in acute phase.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Acute myelopathies, especially anterior spinal artery syndrome, are tested via sensory dissociation patterns and imaging correlates.
Frequency: Annual Part 1 exams include 1–2 vascular myelopathy questions, often in single-best-answer format.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] • The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) supplies the lateral medulla, inferior cerebellar peduncle, vestibular nuclei, nucleus ambiguus (IX, X), and spinal trigeminal nucleus.
• Infarction in this territory produces Wallenberg (lateral medullary) syndrome: ipsilateral facial pain/temp loss, contralateral body pain/temp loss, ipsilateral ataxia, nucleus ambiguus signs (dysphagia, hoarseness, uvula deviation away from lesion).
• Uvula deviation occurs because lesion of nucleus ambiguus impairs ipsilateral palatal elevation (via vagus), so intact contralateral side pulls uvula away from lesion.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Left uvula deviation is characteristic of a right lateral medullary (PICA) infarct due to nucleus ambiguus involvement. The nucleus ambiguus gives motor fibers to the ipsilateral palate via the vagus nerve; when lesioned on the right, the left palate elevates unopposed, deviating the uvula to the left. AHA/ASA 2019 stroke guidelines emphasize bedside cranial nerve examination to localize posterior circulation strokes (Class I, Level B–NR). Neuroimaging corroborates vascular territory: CT/MRI angiography will show PICA infarction. Studies of brainstem stroke localization (Kim JS, Brain 2003) confirm that contralateral uvular deviation has >90% specificity for nucleus ambiguus lesions in lateral medullary syndrome.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Left side ptosis
– PICA infarct can cause ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (miosis, mild ptosis) on the right, not contralateral; left ptosis would indicate a left-sided sympathetic lesion.
– Misconception: equating ptosis with PICA always but ignoring side.
C. Right body decreased sensation
– Spinothalamic fibers in lateral medulla carry contralateral pain/temp: a right-sided lesion causes left body loss. Right body involvement suggests a left-sided lesion or spinal cord lesion.
– Common error: confusing ipsilateral facial vs body sensory loss.
D. Left limb ataxia
– Cerebellar peduncle involvement causes ipsilateral ataxia: right-sided lesion gives right limb ataxia. Left limb ataxia would reflect a left cerebellar or left spinocerebellar issue.
– Pitfall: reversing ipsi- versus contralateral signs.

Comparison Table

FeatureLeft Uvula Deviation (Correct)Left Side PtosisRight Body Decreased SensationLeft Limb Ataxia
Affected StructureNucleus ambiguus (CN IX,X)Sympathetic chainAnterolateral (spinothalamic) tractInferior cerebellar peduncle
Side Relative to Right LesionContralateral (uvula deviates away from right lesion)Contralateral (should be ipsilateral if present)Ipsilateral (wrong for spinothalamic)Contralateral (wrong for cerebellar signs)
Typical in PICA InfarctionYesNoNoNo

Clinical Pearls

• In Wallenberg syndrome, nucleus ambiguus signs (dysphagia, hoarseness, contralateral uvula deviation) distinguish PICA from lateral pontine infarcts (AICA).
• Ipsilateral facial analgesia with contralateral body analgesia is pathognomonic for lateral medullary involvement.
• Always test palate elevation and uvula position in suspected brainstem strokes; mislocalization leads to delayed diagnosis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming uvula deviates toward the lesion rather than away (students often invert).
2. Confusing PICA vs AICA: only PICA lesions involve nucleus ambiguus, AICA lesions involve facial nucleus (facial paralysis).
3. Mixing up ipsilateral vs contralateral cerebellar signs in brainstem strokes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke, 2019
– Recommendation: Use noncontrast CT ± CT angiography/MRI to identify posterior circulation infarcts and guide reperfusion strategies. (Class I, Level B–NR)
2. AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Prevention of Stroke in Patients With Stroke and Transient Ischemic Attack, 2014
– Recommendation: In minor noncardioembolic stroke (NIHSS ≤3), dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin plus clopidogrel for 21 days reduces recurrence. (Class I, Level A)

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The PICA arises from the vertebral artery and supplies lateral medulla structures: nucleus ambiguus (CN IX, X), spinal trigeminal nucleus, vestibular nuclei, inferior cerebellar peduncle, and spinothalamic tract. Lesion of nucleus ambiguus spares accessory nucleus (CN XI) but impairs vagal fibers to palate.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemia of the vertebral artery/PICA leads to infarction of the dorsolateral medulla. Loss of nucleus ambiguus output causes palatal droop on lesion side; intact contralateral palatal fibers pull uvula toward healthy side.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Posterior circulation stroke localization—especially differentiating PICA vs AICA syndromes—is frequently tested as multiple-choice items focusing on ipsilateral nucleus ambiguus signs and ipsilateral vs contralateral sensory/ataxic deficits.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] - Intracerebral hemorrhages (ICH) on noncontrast CT typically appear as homogeneous hyperdensities; a “fluid‐fluid level” (hematocrit effect) arises when red blood cells layer under plasma due to impaired clotting.
• Anticoagulation (warfarin or DOACs) predisposes to coagulopathy‐mediated bleeds that fail to clot effectively, producing this layering sign.
• In contrast, hypertensive ICHs (deep nuclei), cerebral amyloid angiopathy (lobar, microbleeds on GRE), and CVT (hemorrhagic infarcts with edema and venous patterns) lack a true fluid level.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The fluid‐fluid level sign—seen as a horizontal interface between hyperdense cellular elements and hypodense serum on CT—has been shown to have 90–95% specificity for coagulopathy‐related ICH (Kumazawa et al., AJNR 1996). The 2022 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Spontaneous ICH (Hemphill et al., Stroke 2022) recommend immediate assessment of anticoagulant status and reversal if present (Class I, Level A). In anticoagulated patients, deficient thrombin generation prevents stable clot formation, allowing erythrocytes to settle out of plasma. This pathophysiology underlies the distinctive layering on imaging and distinguishes it from other causes of ICH.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Amyloid
• Incorrect because cerebral amyloid angiopathy causes lobar, cortical hemorrhages with ovoid margins and multiple microbleeds on GRE/SWI, not a fluid level.
• Misconception: assuming any lobar hemorrhage in elderly is amyloid—fails to account for coagulopathy signs.

B. Cerebral Venous Thrombosis (CVT)
• CVT may produce hemorrhagic infarcts, usually with irregular margins, surrounding edema, and venous sinus occlusion on MRV, not an acute intraparenchymal fluid‐fluid level.
• Students may confuse venous infarct hemorrhage for simple ICH.

D. Hypertensive intracerebral hemorrhage
• Deep basal ganglia or pontine bleeds from hypertension appear as dense, homogeneous masses without layering.
• Misconception: equating any spontaneous ICH in elderly to hypertension, neglecting imaging nuances.

Comparison Table

FeatureAnticoagulation‐related ICHHypertensive ICHAmyloid Angiopathy ICHCVT Hemorrhagic Infarct
LocationAny parenchyma, often lobarBasal ganglia, thalamusLobar cortexVariable, venous territory
CT AppearanceFluid–fluid (hematocrit) levelHomogeneous hyperdensityHomogeneous hyperdensityHeterogeneous, infarct + bleed
MRI GRE/SWINo specific microbleedsPossible microbleedsMultiple cortical microbleedsVenous thrombosis signs
Clotting profileElevated INR or DOAC levelsNormal coagulationNormal coagulationPossible D‐dimer elevation

Clinical Pearls

- A fluid‐fluid level on CT (“hematocrit effect”) in ICH: think coagulopathy first.
• Always obtain coagulation studies (INR, anti‐Xa levels) immediately when ICH shows layering.
• Early reversal of anticoagulation (e.g., PCC for warfarin, idarucizumab for dabigatran) reduces hematoma expansion and improves outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overlooking fluid levels in mixed‐density bleeds, attributing to hemorrhage age rather than coagulopathy.
2. Mislabeling any lobar hemorrhage in the elderly as amyloid without MRI GRE correlation.
3. Assuming hemorrhagic infarcts from CVT present identically to primary ICH on CT without MRV.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- 2022 AHA/ASA Guideline for the Management of Spontaneous Intracerebral Hemorrhage (Hemphill et al., Stroke 2022): Reversal of warfarin anticoagulation with prothrombin complex concentrate is Class I, Level A.
• INTERACT2 Trial (2013, Lancet): Intensive blood pressure lowering (target SBP <140 mm Hg) in acute ICH is safe and may improve functional outcomes; relevant when managing bleed expansion in anticoagulated patients.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Anticoagulant drugs inhibit vitamin K–dependent factors (warfarin) or direct thrombin/Factor Xa (DOACs), impairing fibrin clot formation.
• Unstable clots allow erythrocytes to settle under plasma, creating a fluid‐fluid level visible on CT.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Emergent noncontrast head CT → identify ICH and layering.
2. Obtain coagulation profile (PT/INR, aPTT, anti‐Xa).
3. If coagulopathy: reverse anticoagulation per guidelines.
4. Monitor for hematoma expansion with repeat imaging.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Hematocrit effect appears within hours of bleed in coagulopathy; on supine CT, look for flat horizontal interface.
• Differentiate from sedimentation in subdural hygromas by location (intraparenchymal vs subdural) and density.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Imaging signs such as the fluid–fluid level are high‐yield for distinguishing coagulopathy‐related hemorrhages on board examinations.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] • Transient ischemic attack (TIA) represents a brief episode of neurological dysfunction without infarction; amaurosis fugax indicates retinal ischemia via the ipsilateral ophthalmic artery branch of the internal carotid.
• Dysarthria suggests involvement of cortical or subcortical motor pathways in the carotid distribution.
• The primary goal in TIA is rapid identification of large‐vessel stenosis: carotid duplex ultrasound noninvasively quantifies plaque burden and flow velocity, guiding urgent interventions (e.g., endarterectomy).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Carotid duplex ultrasound is the recommended first test in symptomatic TIA with anterior circulation features. The 2018 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention guidelines advise vascular imaging (duplex, CTA, or MRA) within 24 hours of presentation to detect ≥50 % internal carotid stenosis (Class I, Level of Evidence A). The NASCET trial demonstrated that patients with 70–99 % symptomatic stenosis reduce stroke risk by >50 % with endarterectomy. Duplex has high sensitivity (88–94 %) and specificity (85–90 %) for moderate‐to‐severe stenosis. Brain MRI and echocardiography are important but follow vascular imaging. Routine anticoagulation without a cardioembolic source is not indicated and increases hemorrhagic risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Brain MRI
• While diffusion‐weighted MRI identifies acute infarction, it does not assess extracranial carotid stenosis.
• Misconception: imaging for infarction must precede vascular imaging; in fact, urgent vessel assessment guides revascularization.

C. Echocardiography
• Used to detect cardiac embolic sources (e.g., PFO, left atrial appendage thrombus) after excluding large‐vessel disease.
• Does not address the high‐risk carotid plaque causing amaurosis fugax.

D. Initiate anticoagulation therapy
• Full anticoagulation is reserved for confirmed cardioembolic or dissection etiologies.
• In noncardioembolic TIA, dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) is indicated short term; anticoagulation may increase bleeding without benefit.

Comparison Table

FeatureCarotid DuplexBrain MRIEchocardiographyAnticoagulation
Primary PurposeQuantify carotid stenosisDetect acute cerebral infarctionIdentify cardiac embolic sourcePrevent cardioembolic events
Timing PriorityWithin 24 h of TIAWithin 24–48 hAfter vascular imagingAfter embolic source identified
Diagnostic YieldHigh for ≥50 % stenosis (88–94 %)High for infarction but no vesselModerate for intracardiac thrombiNot diagnostic
Impact on Immediate ManagementGuides carotid revascularizationGuides secondary preventionGuides anticoagulation decisionsTherapeutic, not diagnostic

Clinical Pearls

• Amaurosis fugax (“curtain coming down”) is a retinal TIA indicating ipsilateral carotid artery disease.
• Vascular imaging within 24 hours reduces early recurrent stroke risk by enabling timely endarterectomy.
• Symptomatic 70–99 % carotid stenosis benefits most from surgical intervention; <50 % stenosis is managed medically.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prioritizing MRI over carotid imaging leads to delayed revascularization in high‐risk patients.
2. Automatically starting anticoagulation for all TIAs ignores etiology, risking hemorrhage without reducing stroke recurrence.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• 2018 AHA/ASA TIA/Stroke Guideline: “Perform cervical vascular imaging within 24 hours of TIA” (Class I, Level A).
• 2021 ESO Guidelines: “First‐line evaluation of symptomatic carotid disease with duplex ultrasound, CTA, or MRA” (Level A).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Carotid duplex evaluation in amaurosis fugax and TIA scenarios is frequently tested on neurology boards, often emphasizing timing and indications for endarterectomy.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Spinal cord infarction arises when arterial supply—most often the anterior spinal artery (ASA)—is compromised, producing acute myelopathic deficits. Early imaging is essential to distinguish ischemia from compressive, inflammatory, or infectious myelopathies.
Core concepts:
• Vascular anatomy: ASA supplies anterior two-thirds of cord; occlusion yields bilateral motor and pain/temperature loss below lesion.
• Diagnostic urgency: Timely MRI detects ischemic changes before irreversible injury develops.
• Imaging modalities: MRI (T2‐weighted, diffusion‐weighted imaging) outperforms CT in soft-tissue contrast and sensitivity for acute infarction.

Evidence-Based Analysis

MRI is the gold standard for suspected spinal cord infarction. T2‐weighted sequences detect cord edema within hours; diffusion‐weighted imaging (DWI) demonstrates restricted diffusion in acute ischemia. The American College of Radiology Appropriateness Criteria (2019) rates emergent spine MRI “usually appropriate” (rating 8/9) for suspected cord ischemia. AHA/ASA 2018 scientific statement (Class I; Level B) recommends MRI with DWI to confirm diagnosis and rule out mimic conditions. Early MRI guides prognosis and management—identifying lesion level, excluding compressive etiologies, and informing potential interventions (e.g., blood pressure augmentation).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRV (to rule out CVT)
• Targets cerebral venous sinuses, not spinal vasculature.
• Spinal cord venous thrombosis is exceedingly rare; venous imaging yields no data on arterial infarction.
Common misconception: conflating intracranial with spinal vascular evaluation.

C. Lumbar puncture
• May delay definitive imaging; risks exacerbating cord edema or herniation if mass lesion is present.
• CSF in spinal infarction can be normal or show nonspecific mild protein elevation—does not confirm ischemia.
Common misconception: overreliance on CSF to distinguish causes of acute myelopathy.

D. CT scan
• CT myelography or non-contrast CT lacks sensitivity for early cord infarction and fails to detect intraparenchymal changes.
• CT angiography may visualize major vessels but misses small ASA branches and intramedullary pathology.
Common misconception: equating CT’s utility in stroke with spinal cord ischemia.

Comparison Table

ModalityPrimary TargetSensitivity for Acute Spinal InfarctionKey Notes
MRICord parenchyma (T2, DWI)High (>90% within 24 h)Detects edema, diffusion restriction
MRVVenous sinusesN/A for cord ischemiaUsed for cerebral CVT, not spinal
LPCSF analysisLowMay rule out infection/inflammation but not ischemia
CT scanBone, acute hemorrhagePoorMisses intramedullary changes; limited soft-tissue contrast

Clinical Pearls

- In acute myelopathy, always obtain MRI before invasive procedures (e.g., LP) to exclude compressive lesions.
• Diffusion-weighted imaging of the spinal cord can reveal ischemia within hours—look for focal restricted diffusion and “owl’s eyes” sign on axial.
• The artery of Adamkiewicz typically arises between T9–T12; infarcts at this level often present with lumbar motor deficits.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering LP first: delays diagnosis and risks herniation if a compressive lesion exists.
2. Relying on CT: misses early parenchymal changes; CT angiography visualizes large arteries but not intramedullary infarcts.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American College of Radiology Appropriateness Criteria, “Suspected Spinal Cord Ischemia” (2019): Recommends emergent MRI spine with DWI as “usually appropriate” (rating 8/9; Level C evidence).
• AHA/ASA Scientific Statement, Spinal Cord Ischemia (2018): Class I recommendation (Level B) for MRI with DWI to confirm diagnosis and exclude mimics.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The ASA arises from vertebral arteries and segmental radiculomedullary branches (notably the artery of Adamkiewicz). It supplies anterior two-thirds of the cord—motor tracts (corticospinal) and spinothalamic fibers. Posterior columns, supplied by paired posterior spinal arteries, are often spared.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Spinal cord infarction results from ASA occlusion or hypoperfusion. Mechanisms include aortic pathology (dissection, aneurysm repair), thromboembolism, and hypotension. Ischemia leads to cytotoxic edema, axonal injury, and neuronal death within hours.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: acute bilateral motor/pain‐temperature loss with preserved proprioception.
2. Emergent MRI spine (T2, DWI, contrast) to identify ischemia and rule out compressive lesions.
3. Vascular imaging (MR angiography) to assess aortic or radiculomedullary vessels if indicated.
4. Laboratory: exclude vasculitis/coagulopathy once compression is ruled out.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- T2-weighted MRI: hyperintense intramedullary signal within hours.
• DWI: true restricted diffusion in acute infarction (bright on DWI, low ADC).
• Axial “owl’s eyes” pattern: bilateral anterior horn involvement specific for ASA territory infarct.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Spinal cord infarction questions frequently test the urgency and specificity of MRI (vs CT or lumbar puncture) in acute myelopathy, often emphasizing vascular anatomy and imaging sequences.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) arises when thrombi obstruct one or more dural sinuses or cortical veins, raising venous pressure and causing both vasogenic and cytotoxic edema. Key principles:
• Venous drainage anatomy: superior sagittal and transverse sinuses receive cortical veins from frontal lobes; occlusion preferentially affects subcortical white matter.
• MRI signal characteristics: T2/FLAIR hyperintensity reflects vasogenic edema; DWI/ADC restriction indicates cytotoxic edema from venous infarction.
• MR venography (MRV) directly visualizes lack of flow (“filling defects”) in thrombosed sinuses.
Recognizing the combination of subcortical T2 hyperintensity, cortical restricted diffusion, and MRV defects is essential for diagnosing CVT.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The patient’s imaging—left frontal subcortical hyperintensity with cortical diffusion restriction—reflects mixed vasogenic/cytotoxic edema from venous outflow obstruction. MRV confirms the diagnosis by showing filling defects in the superior sagittal and transverse sinuses. According to the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2011 guidelines, anticoagulation with low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) or unfractionated heparin is recommended in acute CVT even in the presence of intracerebral hemorrhage (Class I, Level of Evidence B). Ferro et al. (NEJM 2004) demonstrated improved outcomes with LMWH compared to placebo. More recently, the RESPECT-CVT trial (N Engl J Med 2019; dabigatran vs warfarin) established noninferiority of direct oral anticoagulants for secondary prevention. Early anticoagulation reduces thrombus propagation, lowers intracranial pressure, and minimizes infarct expansion.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES)
• Why incorrect: PRES typically shows symmetric vasogenic edema in parieto-occipital regions without true diffusion restriction or venous sinus occlusion.
• Misconception: Confusing vasogenic hyperintensity with restricted diffusion.
• Differentiator: Absence of MRV filling defects; distribution posterior and bilateral rather than focal frontal.

C. Arterial ischemic stroke
• Why incorrect: Arterial infarcts follow a specific vascular territory (e.g., MCA) and cause abrupt focal deficits; MRV is normal.
• Misconception: Equating any diffusion restriction with arterial etiology.
• Differentiator: Lack of subcortical predominance and sinus filling defects; CT/MR angiography would show arterial occlusion, not sinus.

D. Multiple sclerosis
