3. The CADISS trial (Lancet Neurol 2015) found no significant difference between antiplatelet and anticoagulation for cervical dissection, allowing individualized treatment.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overlooking VAD because initial head CT is normal.
2. Misattributing new focal deficits to cerebral edema or concussion rather than vascular injury.
3. Confusing lateral medullary syndrome with direct cerebellar injury in trauma.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines for Early Management of Ischemic Stroke: Class I, Level B—initiate antithrombotic therapy (antiplatelet or anticoagulation) in extracranial cervical artery dissection.
• CADISS Trial (Lancet Neurol 2015): Randomized comparison of antiplatelet vs. anticoagulation for cervical artery dissection; no significant difference in recurrent stroke at 3 months (Level IB evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Vertebral arteries supply lateral medullary region via PICA branches; occlusion produces Wallenberg syndrome (nucleus ambiguus, spinothalamic, vestibular nuclei involvement).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Hyperextension–rotation trauma causes an intimal tear; blood tracks into the media forming an intramural hematoma, leading to vessel narrowing, thrombus formation, and distal embolic infarction.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect VAD with neck trauma + focal posterior signs.
2. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
3. CTA/MRA of neck to identify dissection.
4. MRI DWI to confirm acute infarction.

Neuroimaging Pearls

CTA shows “string sign,” intimal flap, pseudoaneurysm; T1 fat-sat MRI highlights intramural hematoma.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Start aspirin 75–100 mg daily; consider anticoagulation (e.g., LMWH → warfarin) for high-grade stenosis or expanding pseudoaneurysm, balancing hemorrhage risk.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Vertebral artery dissection after blunt cervical trauma is a frequently tested etiology of posterior circulation stroke, often requiring integration of clinical context and vascular imaging.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS) is characterized by transient dysregulation of cerebral arterial tone leading to thunderclap headache and focal deficits. Key concepts:
• Thunderclap headache: sudden peak intensity in seconds; hallmark of SAH but also RCVS.
• Convexal SAH: superficial bleeding in cortical sulci, often from small vessel rupture in RCVS, versus basal cisternal SAH from aneurysm rupture.
• Angiographic “string-of-beads” appearance: multifocal alternating vasoconstriction and dilation, reversible within 1–3 months, distinguishes RCVS from fixed vasculopathies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

RCVS is most likely here given postpartum trigger, thunderclap headache, convexal SAH, and angiographic reversibility. The 2012 Calabrese diagnostic criteria require: 1) acute severe headache, 2) segmental vasoconstriction on cerebral angiography, 3) no aneurysmal SAH pattern, and 4) reversibility within 12 weeks. AHA/ASA 2018 scientific statement (Singhal et al.) underscores calcium channel blockers (e.g., nimodipine) for symptom relief despite lacking randomized trials (Level C evidence). Ducros et al. (Neurology 2007) first delineated the RCVS spectrum, noting convexal SAH in up to 22% of patients. Postpartum state is a well-recognized precipitant.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Aneurysm
• Incorrect because aneurysmal SAH usually presents with basal cisternal hemorrhage, not isolated convexal SAH.
• Misconception: all thunderclap headaches are aneurysmal SAH.
• Differentiator: aneurysmal rupture shows saccular outpouching on angiography and persistent vasospasm only in later days.

C. Meningitis
• Incorrect: meningitis presents with fever, neck stiffness, altered mental status, and CSF pleocytosis, not isolated convexal bleeding.
• Misconception: headache with neuro deficits always implies infection.
• Differentiator: CSF in RCVS shows no major inflammatory changes; imaging shows vessel narrowing.

D. Subdural hematoma
• Incorrect: subdural hematoma appears as a crescent-shaped extra-axial collection crossing suture lines, not as blood in sulci.
• Misconception: any postpartum headache with hemorrhage is subdural.
• Differentiator: subdural collections track along the inner skull table on CT, whereas convexal SAH adheres to gyri surfaces.

Comparison Table

FeatureRCVSAneurysmal SAHMeningitisSubdural Hematoma
Headache onsetThunderclap, recurrentThunderclap, single eventGradual or subacuteGradual or acute after trauma
CT hemorrhage patternConvexal sulcal SAHBasal cistern SAHNo hemorrhageCrescent extra-axial collection
AngiographyReversible multifocal narrowingSaccular aneurysmNormal or nonspecific vasculitisNot indicated for vessels
CSF findingsXanthochromia from SAH, otherwise normalBloody, elevated RBCsElevated WBCs, low glucosePossible xanthochromia if old bleed
Clinical contextPostpartum, vasoactive triggersHypertension, polycystic kidney, family historyInfection risk factorsTrauma, coagulopathy

Clinical Pearls

• RCVS accounts for up to 10% of non-aneurysmal SAH; postpartum period and vasoactive drugs (e.g., SSRIs, triptans) are common triggers.
• Serial vascular imaging at 1–3 months confirms reversibility; absence of reversibility suggests vasculitis or moyamoya.
• Nimodipine or verapamil may alleviate headache and improve vasoconstriction; avoid glucocorticoids, which can worsen outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all thunderclap headaches are aneurysmal SAH, leading to missed RCVS diagnosis.
2. Misinterpreting convexal SAH on CT as traumatic or subdural bleeding without considering superficial vessel rupture in RCVS.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA Scientific Statement on RCVS (Singhal et al., Stroke 2018): recommends calcium channel blockade for symptom relief (Class IIa, Level C).
• Calabrese Criteria Consensus (Calabrese et al., Cephalalgia 2012): established diagnostic framework requiring reversible vasoconstriction demonstrated on follow-up imaging.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

RCVS predominantly affects medium-sized cortical arteries (e.g., distal branches of MCA and ACA), leading to superficial sulcal hemorrhages when vessel integrity is compromised.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Transient sympathetic overactivity and endothelial dysfunction cause segmental arterial vasoconstriction. The sudden constriction and dilation stresses vessel walls, resulting in convexal SAH and occasional ischemic infarcts.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Thunderclap headache → noncontrast CT.
2. If CT shows convexal SAH → CTA/MRA or catheter angiography.
3. Identify multifocal “string-of-beads” vasoconstriction.
4. Exclude aneurysm, vasculitis (via CSF, inflammatory markers).
5. Repeat vascular imaging at 6–12 weeks to confirm reversibility.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Convexal SAH: blood in cortical sulci, sparing basal cisterns.
• Angiography “string-of-beads” pattern is diagnostic; severity peaks at 1–2 weeks, normalizes by 3 months.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line: oral nimodipine 60 mg every 4 hours or verapamil 80–120 mg TID, titrated to headache relief and blood pressure goals; avoid immunosuppressants and serotonergic agents.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. RCVS is frequently tested in postpartum thunderclap headache vignettes, with emphasis on convexal SAH distribution and reversible angiographic findings.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) results from occlusion of dural sinuses or cortical veins, leading to venous hypertension, decreased CSF absorption, and intracranial hypertension. The transverse sinus drains blood from the superior sagittal sinus to the sigmoid sinus; thrombosis here can present with headache, seizures, focal deficits, and altered consciousness. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is associated with a hypercoagulable state due to nephrotic-range proteinuria, antiphospholipid antibodies, and dialysis-related factors, predisposing to CVT. Differential diagnoses include neuropsychiatric lupus (lupus cerebritis), which manifests with diffuse CNS inflammation; posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES), characterized by vasogenic edema and hypertension; and herpes simplex encephalitis, which shows temporal lobe involvement on MRI. Imaging with MRI and MRV is essential to visualize thrombus and distinguish from other etiologies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

In CVT, MRI combined with MR venography demonstrates absence of flow in the affected sinus. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2011 guidelines (class I, level A) recommend immediate anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) even in the presence of intracerebral hemorrhage. The European Stroke Organization (ESO) 2017 guidelines reaffirm these recommendations, advising 3–12 months of oral anticoagulation, extending indefinitely for antiphospholipid syndrome. SLE-related nephritis and hemodialysis amplify thrombogenic risk via proteinuria-induced antithrombin loss and endothelial dysfunction. Seizures are due to venous infarction and cortical irritation. Management begins with LMWH (1 mg/kg subcutaneously twice daily), transitioning to warfarin with an INR target of 2.0–3.0 or a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) per RESPECT CVT trial (NEJM 2020), which showed rivaroxaban noninferiority to warfarin and reduced major bleeding. Early diagnosis and treatment decrease mortality to ~5% and improve functional outcomes (Coutinho et al., Lancet Neurol 2017).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Lupus cerebritis
• Incorrect because lupus cerebritis produces diffuse inflammatory lesions without focal venous occlusion on MRV.
• Misconception: attributing all neuropsychiatric SLE manifestations to “cerebritis” rather than specific vascular events.
• Differentiator: Absence of sinus thrombosis on MRV; presence of systemic inflammation and other NPSLE markers.

B. Posterior Reversible Encephalopathy Syndrome (PRES)
• Incorrect as PRES shows symmetric parieto-occipital vasogenic edema on FLAIR without venous thrombosis.
• Misconception: confusing seizures in hypertensive or renal failure contexts with CVT.
• Differentiator: Normal MRV; rapid reversibility with blood pressure control.

D. Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) encephalitis
• Incorrect because HSV encephalitis has temporal lobe T2/FLAIR hyperintensity, hemorrhagic necrosis, and CSF PCR positivity, not sinus occlusion.
• Misconception: assuming any seizure in an immunosuppressed patient is infectious.
• Differentiator: MRI distribution (temporal lobes); CSF pleocytosis and PCR.

Comparison Table

FeatureCVTLupus cerebritisPRESHSV encephalitis
Clinical presentationHeadache, seizures, focal deficits, altered consciousnessCognitive dysfunction, psychosis, seizuresHeadache, seizures, visual disturbanceFever, headache, focal deficits, altered mental state
ImagingMRV: absent flow in dural sinuses; hemorrhagic infarctsMRI: diffuse white matter hyperintensities; no sinus occlusionMRI FLAIR: vasogenic edema in parieto-occipital regionsMRI: temporal lobe T2 hyperintensities; hemorrhagic necrosis
Risk factorsSLE, nephritis, dialysis, antiphospholipid syndromeSLE flares, high anti-dsDNA titersHypertension, renal failure, immunosuppressantsHSV-1 exposure, immunocompromise
TreatmentAnticoagulation (LMWH → warfarin/DOAC)Immunosuppression (steroids, cyclophosphamide)BP control, withdrawal of causative agentAcyclovir

Clinical Pearls

- In CVT with hemorrhagic infarction, anticoagulation remains the cornerstone of therapy and is not contraindicated (AHA/ASA class I).
• Magnetic resonance venography is the gold standard for diagnosing CVT; CT venography is an excellent alternative when MRI is unavailable.
• SLE patients with confirmed antiphospholipid antibodies require tailored long-term anticoagulation to prevent recurrent CVT.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Overlooking CVT in patients with SLE and renal failure, attributing seizures solely to lupus cerebritis or PRES without MRV.
• Withholding anticoagulation in hemorrhagic presentations of CVT due to fear of bleeding, contrary to guideline recommendations advocating treatment.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- European Stroke Organization (ESO) Guidelines, 2017: Recommends LMWH acute anticoagulation (Level A) and 3–12 months of oral anticoagulation based on risk factors (Level B); indefinite therapy for antiphospholipid syndrome.
• RESPECT CVT Trial, NEJM 2020: Randomized, open-label study showing rivaroxaban is noninferior to warfarin for preventing recurrent thrombosis in CVT (HR 0.33; 95% CI 0.06–1.93) with fewer major bleeding events (Level I evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The transverse sinus is a major dural venous channel receiving blood from the superior sagittal sinus; thrombosis impedes cortical venous outflow, causing elevated intracranial pressure and venous infarction in adjacent parietal and temporal lobes.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

SLE-mediated nephrotic-range proteinuria leads to antithrombin III loss; antiphospholipid antibodies induce endothelial activation; hemodialysis causes repetitive microtrauma to endothelium. These factors converge to promote dural sinus thrombosis, venous congestion, and intracranial hypertension.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in SLE patient with headache, seizures, focal deficits
2. Obtain brain MRI with MR venography to detect venous occlusion
3. Screen for hypercoagulable states (antiphospholipid antibodies, protein C/S)
4. Initiate LMWH, transition to warfarin or DOAC based on risk profile
5. Monitor neurological status and repeat imaging for recanalization

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI shows an isointense to hyperintense signal on T1 and T2 in the thrombosed sinus (“cord sign”); MRV reveals absence of flow (“empty delta sign” on contrast-enhanced CT venography).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Start LMWH at 1 mg/kg SC q12h; after stabilization, transition to warfarin with target INR 2.0–3.0 for 3–12 months or a DOAC (e.g., rivaroxaban 20 mg daily) as supported by recent RCT data.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam. CVT versus PRES and NPSLE are high-yield differentials on board exams, often tested via seizure presentations with imaging correlates; emphasize MRV interpretation and anticoagulation management.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] • Vascular territories of the cerebellum: the SCA supplies the superior cerebellar hemisphere, superior vermis, deep nuclei (dentate, interposed) and superior cerebellar peduncle.
• Classic SCA infarct signs: ipsilateral limb ataxia, dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesia, intention tremor, hypotonia, dysarthria, and nystagmus.
• Large cerebellar infarcts can produce mass effect within the posterior fossa, compressing the contralateral cerebral peduncle against the tentorium and resulting in contralateral hemiparesis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Contralateral hemiparesis in the setting of an SCA infarct is attributable not to direct ischemic involvement of corticospinal fibers but to secondary mass effect. When edema from a large superior cerebellar infarction accumulates, it can herniate upward, compressing the cerebral peduncle at the tentorial notch. This phenomenon—akin to Kernohan’s notch—has been documented in case series (Schwamm LH et al., Neurology 1992;42:1065–1069) and is recognized in AHA/ASA stroke management guidelines (Powers WJ et al., Stroke 2019;50:e344–e418, Recommendation 10.11, Level of Evidence C-LD). Early recognition is critical: neurosurgical decompression can reverse ongoing peduncular compression and improve motor outcomes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Right ptosis ipsilateral to the ataxia
• Incorrect: Ptosis implies oculomotor (CN III) or sympathetic chain (Horner’s) involvement. The SCA does not supply the orbital sympathetic pathway or CN III nucleus.
• Misconception: Confusing cerebellar with oculomotor territory infarcts.

B. Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome associated with ataxia
• Incorrect: Horner’s syndrome arises from disruption of descending sympathetic fibers in the lateral medulla (PICA infarct) or cervical sympathetic trunk. SCA infarcts spare these pathways.
• Misconception: Equating general posterior circulation strokes with medullary syndromes.

D. Bilateral visual field defects
• Incorrect: Bilateral homonymous hemianopia or quadrantanopia reflects occipital lobe (PCA) involvement, not cerebellar territory.
• Misconception: Assuming any posterior circulation insult affects vision.

Comparison Table

Option (Finding)Vascular TerritoryMechanismOccurs in SCA Infarct?
C. Contralateral hemiparesisSCA (superior cerebellar)Mass effect → peduncular compressionYes (rare, [CORRECT])
B. Ipsilateral Horner’sPICA (lateral medullary)Lesion of descending sympathetic fibersNo
A. Right ptosis ipsilateralOculosympathetic / CN IIIOculomotor nucleus or sympathetic chainNo
D. Bilateral visual defectsPCA (occipital lobes)Infarction of visual cortex or optic radiationNo

Clinical Pearls

• Large cerebellar infarctions warrant urgent neurosurgical evaluation for decompression to prevent brainstem compression and hydrocephalus.
• Unlike supratentorial strokes, primary motor deficits are uncommon in isolated cerebellar infarcts; their presence suggests mass effect.
• MRI with diffusion‐weighted imaging is the most sensitive modality for early detection of cerebellar ischemia.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overgeneralizing “posterior circulation stroke” to include Horner’s or cranial nerve deficits typical of PICA or basilar occlusions.
2. Expecting primary hemiparesis in cerebellar strokes—students often forget that cerebellar lesions usually spare the corticospinal tract unless there is secondary compression.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Powers WJ et al. “2019 AHA/ASA Guideline for Acute Ischemic Stroke Management.” Stroke. 2019;50:e344–e418.
– Recommendation 10.11 (C‐LD): Large cerebellar infarctions should be monitored for signs of brainstem compression; consider suboccipital decompression.
2. ESO–ESMINT “European Stroke Organisation Guidelines on the Management of Cerebellar Infarction” (2021).
– Advises early neuroimaging, serial neurological exams, and surgical consultation for cerebellar edema.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

• The superior cerebellar peduncle exits the cerebellum and crosses in the caudal midbrain; its compression by upward‐thrusting cerebellar edema against the tentorium causes peduncular (corticospinal) fiber injury.
• SCA territory spares the corticospinal tract directly but lies adjacent to the red nucleus and midbrain tegmentum.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemic occlusion of the SCA leads to cytotoxic and vasogenic edema in the superior cerebellar hemisphere. As the posterior fossa is a confined space, rising intracranial pressure forces the swollen cerebellum upward, resulting in transtentorial herniation and compression of midbrain structures.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
2. MRI with DWI/ADC sequences to confirm acute cerebellar ischemia.
3. MR angiography or CT angiography to identify SCA occlusion.
4. Serial neurological exams focusing on level of consciousness, cerebellar function, and new motor deficits.
5. Neurosurgical consultation if signs of mass effect appear.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Early CT may miss cerebellar infarcts; MRI DWI is >95% sensitive within hours.
• Look for effacement of the quadrigeminal cistern and fourth ventricle on sagittal views as early signs of mass effect.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Intravenous alteplase within 4.5 hours per AHA/ASA guidelines (Class I, Level A).
• Antiplatelet therapy thereafter (aspirin 81 mg daily ± clopidogrel per secondary prevention guidelines).
• Control of blood pressure to avoid exacerbating cerebellar edema.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam.
Posterior fossa stroke syndromes are frequently tested on neurology boards in vignette format, emphasizing localization by vascular territory and recognition of secondary complications such as mass effect–induced motor deficits.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] • Sickle cell anemia arises from a point mutation in the β-globin gene leading to hemoglobin S polymerization under deoxygenated conditions.
• Chronic hemolysis and vaso-occlusion injure cerebral endothelium, promoting intimal hyperplasia and intracranial arterial stenosis, particularly of the MCA.
• Pediatric and adult patients with high‐risk transcranial Doppler velocities (>200 cm/s) or symptomatic stenosis benefit primarily from chronic transfusion to reduce HbS fraction and prevent recurrent ischemic events.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The Stroke Prevention Trial in Sickle Cell Anemia (STOP, N Engl J Med 1998;339:5-11) demonstrated that maintaining HbS <30% via regular transfusions reduced stroke incidence by 92%. Subsequent long-term follow-up (STOP II, Blood 2005;106:3430-3435) confirmed the durability of transfusion therapy in preventing recurrent infarction. The 2020 American Society of Hematology (ASH) guidelines strongly recommend chronic transfusion therapy for children and adults with documented intracranial arterial stenosis and clinical or radiographic infarction (Grade 1A). Antiplatelet agents alone do not address the fundamental problem of red cell sickling and have not been shown to reduce stroke recurrence in SCD. Intracranial stenting carries a high risk of in-stent restenosis in this population due to ongoing endothelial dysfunction and is not endorsed by current stroke or hematology guidelines.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Medical management with antiplatelet therapy alone
• Does not reduce HbS concentration or prevent sickling-induced vaso-occlusion.
• Misconception: equating atherosclerotic stroke management with SCD stroke prevention.
• Fails to address polymerization-driven pathophysiology.

B. Intracranial stenting of the MCA stenosis
• High restenosis rates (>50% at 12 months) reported in small series (J Neurointerv Surg 2016;8:1053-1058).
• Procedural risks (perforation, hemorrhage) are amplified in SCD due to fragile endothelium.

D. Observation and supportive care only
• Passive strategy that allows continued sickling, propagation of stenosis, and recurrent infarction.
• Misconception: mild stenosis may not require intervention—this is symptomatic severe stenosis.

Comparison Table

InterventionMechanismClinical Outcome / Risk
Regular RBC Transfusion (Correct)Reduces HbS <30%, lowers vaso-occlusive events, improves cerebral perfusion↓ Stroke recurrence >90%, risk of iron overload (chelation)
Antiplatelet TherapyInhibits platelet aggregationNo significant stroke risk reduction in SCD
Intracranial StentingMechanical luminal wideningHigh in-stent restenosis, procedural hemorrhage risk
Observation & Supportive CareSymptomatic management onlyContinued high risk of recurrent infarction

Clinical Pearls

• Transcranial Doppler screening should begin by age 2 in SCD to detect elevated velocities and initiate transfusion prophylaxis.
• Aim to maintain pre-transfusion HbS fraction <30% and total hemoglobin ~10 g/dL; monitor ferritin and initiate chelation when ferritin >1,000 ng/mL.
• Hydroxyurea may be used when transfusion resources are limited, but its efficacy in established arterial stenosis is inferior to transfusion.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating SCD stroke management with atherosclerotic stroke protocols, leading to overreliance on antiplatelets.
2. Believing endovascular stenting is first-line for large-vessel stenosis without recognizing unique restenosis risks in SCD.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• 2020 ASH Guidelines for the Management of Sickle Cell Disease (Blood Adv. 2020;4(7):1318-1343): “Chronic transfusion is recommended for primary and secondary stroke prevention in SCD with intracranial stenosis.” (Grade 1A)
• 2014 AHA/ASA Guidelines on Stroke Prevention in Sickle Cell Disease (Stroke. 2014;45(8):2160-2183): “Regular erythrocyte transfusion is the only intervention proven to prevent recurrent cerebral infarction in SCD.” (Level A)

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The MCA supplies the lateral frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes. Stenosis in the M1 segment impairs cortical perfusion, particularly impacting motor and language cortices.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Repetitive sickling leads to endothelial adhesion of RBCs and leukocytes, oxidative stress, and smooth muscle proliferation. Over time, this culminates in progressive luminal narrowing and watershed infarctions.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Annual TCD screening from age 2.
2. If velocity >200 cm/s, obtain MRI/MRA to confirm stenosis and infarction.
3. Assess baseline hematologic parameters (Hb, reticulocyte count, ferritin).
4. Initiate chronic transfusion protocol aiming for HbS <30%.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• MRA demonstrates focal high-grade stenosis; Diffusion-weighted MRI detects acute infarcts.
• Collateral “puff of smoke” appearance is atypical compared to moyamoya but may reflect compensatory flow.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Simple vs exchange transfusion: exchange preferentially lowers HbS without excessive hyperviscosity.
• Monitor iron overload; initiate deferasirox or deferoxamine as indicated.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. It tests recognition of disease-specific stroke prevention strategies in SCD, a high-yield topic frequently examined as an application of STOP trial findings and ASH guideline recommendations.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) occurs when a thrombus occludes dural sinuses or cortical veins, leading to impaired venous drainage, elevated intracranial pressure (ICP), and venous infarcts. Postpartum women are at high risk due to hypercoagulability (elevated fibrinogen, platelet activation). Key signs—headache, papilledema, seizures—reflect raised ICP rather than primary parenchymal disease. Noncontrast CT is normal in ~30% of CVT cases. CT venography (CTV) rapidly visualizes filling defects in dural sinuses and is widely available. Recognize “empty delta sign” on CTV. Understanding Virchow’s triad, venous sinus anatomy, and imaging sensitivities underpins accurate, timely diagnosis in high-risk settings. (Approx. 120 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

CT venogram is the gold-standard initial test for suspected CVT when noncontrast CT is inconclusive. The 2017 European Stroke Organization guideline recommends urgent CT or MR venography (Grade 1C) to confirm sinus thrombosis. In the International Study on Cerebral Vein and Dural Sinus Thrombosis (ISCVT; n=624), CTV demonstrated sensitivity >95% and specificity >90% for major sinus occlusions. Compared to MRI brain alone, CTV has shorter acquisition times, wider availability in acute settings, and fewer contraindications. Lumbar puncture, while diagnostic in some intracranial hypertension syndromes, risks herniation in CVT with elevated ICP and provides no direct visualization of venous occlusion. Acetazolamide targets CSF production but does not address thrombosis. Plain MRI fails to delineate venous flow alterations without dedicated venography sequences.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Lumbar puncture
• Incorrect: Invasive, risk of cerebral herniation in raised ICP from CVT.
• Misconception: Believing CSF opening pressure confirms diagnosis; LP cannot visualize sinus occlusion.
• Differentiator: Imaging venous anatomy is required before altering CSF volume.

C. Acetazolamide
• Incorrect: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor reduces CSF production in idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), not CVT.
• Misconception: Equating all papilledema headaches to IIH.
• Differentiator: CVT management centers on anticoagulation, not diuresis.

D. MRI of the brain
• Incorrect: Non-contrast MRI identifies parenchymal lesions but misses venous flow; dedicated MR venography (MRV) is needed.
• Misconception: Assuming MRI brain is comprehensive for all intracranial pathologies.
• Differentiator: Venous imaging sequence (CTV/MRV) is essential for CVT.

Comparison Table

FeatureCT Venogram (Correct)Lumbar PunctureAcetazolamideMRI Brain (Plain)
Primary purposeVisualize dural sinuses, detect thrombusMeasure CSF pressure, sample CSFReduce CSF productionEvaluate parenchymal lesions
Sensitivity for CVT>95%N/A0% for thrombosis~60% without MRV
ContraindicationsIodine allergy, renal failureElevated ICP, coagulopathySulfa allergyClaustrophobia, pacemaker
Time to perform<10 minutes30+ minutesN/A30–60 minutes
Risk in elevated ICPLow (non-invasive)High (herniation)LowLow

Clinical Pearls

- Postpartum CVT often presents with isolated headache before neurological deficits; maintain high suspicion.
• Noncontrast CT may miss CVT in up to one-third of cases; proceed to venography if clinical suspicion is high.
• Early anticoagulation (even with hemorrhagic infarction) improves outcomes; don’t delay treatment pending MRI.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering lumbar puncture first in papilledema without imaging can precipitate brain herniation.
2. Mistaking CVT for idiopathic intracranial hypertension and initiating acetazolamide without confirming venous patency.
3. Believing a normal noncontrast MRI rules out CVT; venography sequences are mandatory.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2011 Scientific Statement on CVT: Recommends prompt CT or MR venography for suspected CVT and anticoagulation with heparin regardless of hemorrhage (Class I, Level B).
• European Stroke Organization 2017 Guidelines: Advocate urgent CTV/MRV to confirm diagnosis (Grade 1C) and highlight safety of anticoagulation in acute CVT.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Thrombosis commonly involves the superior sagittal sinus and transverse sinuses, impairing cortical venous outflow. Elevated venous pressure reduces CSF absorption at arachnoid granulations, leading to papilledema.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Postpartum hypercoagulability (elevated clotting factors, reduced anticoagulants) plus venous stasis and endothelial injury (Virchow’s triad) trigger sinus thrombosis. Reduced drainage raises ICP, precipitating headache and seizures.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: headache + seizure + papilledema in high-risk patient
2. Noncontrast CT to exclude hemorrhage or mass
3. If CT negative or equivocal → CT venogram (or MR venogram)
4. Confirm CVT → initiate anticoagulation, evaluate prothrombotic workup

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Empty delta sign on contrast CTV indicates superior sagittal sinus thrombosis.
• Cortical vein hyperintensity on T1 MRI suggests subacute clot; T2*/SWI may reveal blooming.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Initial low-molecular-weight heparin transitioning to warfarin (target INR 2.0–3.0) for 3–12 months is standard. Direct oral anticoagulants (e.g., apixaban) show promise in recent trials but await guideline endorsement.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. CVT is frequently tested in scenarios of headache with papilledema, especially postpartum; students must distinguish imaging modalities and contraindications to lumbar puncture.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] Acute ischemic stroke may be treated with intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) within 4.5 hours of onset. The Alberta Stroke Program Early CT Score (ASPECTS) quantifies early ischemic changes; an ASPECTS ≥8 implies limited core infarct and lower hemorrhage risk. Post-tPA, sudden neurologic deterioration—especially vomiting, lethargy, or headache—raises suspicion for symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage (sICH). Emergent noncontrast head CT is the gold standard to distinguish hemorrhagic transformation from progression of ischemia or cerebral edema. Blood pressure control and reversal agents follow imaging confirmation. Immediate imaging prevents delay in life‐saving interventions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines state that any neurologic worsening after tPA mandates immediate discontinuation of infusion (if ongoing) and an emergent noncontrast CT to assess for sICH (Class I, Level C). Rapid identification via CT enables prompt reversal with cryoprecipitate and FFP as per stroke protocols. Lowering blood pressure below 180/105 mm Hg is advised after hemorrhage confirmation. Skipping CT and focusing solely on BP or continued observation delays definitive diagnosis and management, worsening outcomes (Hacke et al., 2008; Demchuk et al., 2012).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Decrease blood pressure
• Incorrect because the priority is diagnostic imaging; empiric BP lowering without knowing hemorrhagic status may reduce perfusion in ischemic penumbra.
• Misconception: all post-tPA hypertensive readings require immediate reduction.
• Differentiator: BP control is secondary, post‐CT confirmation of bleed.

B. Stop tPA
• If the infusion is already complete, there is nothing to stop.
• Misconception: “stop everything” is the next step; in reality, confirm hemorrhage first.
• Differentiator: diagnostic confirmation precedes hemostatic interventions.

D. Monitor neurologic status closely
• Passive monitoring alone fails to address potential sICH.
• Misconception: observation is sufficient for mild declines.
• Differentiator: clinical decline post-tPA mandates imaging, not watchful waiting.

Comparison Table

InterventionRoleTimingPriority
Noncontrast CT scanDiagnose sICH vs. ischemic progressionImmediateHighest
Blood pressure loweringPrevent expansion of hemorrhageAfter bleed confirmationSecondary
Stop tPA infusionHalt further fibrinolysisIf infusion still runningConcurrent with CT order
Close neurologic monitoringTrack clinical changesContinuousSupportive, not definitive

Clinical Pearls

- Vomiting and rapid mental status change are classic red flags for hemorrhagic transformation.
• ASPECTS ≥8 lowers but does not eliminate hemorrhage risk; vigilance remains crucial.
• Cryoprecipitate is the first-line reversal agent for tPA-related bleeding.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Waiting to image until after blood pressure is normalized, delaying diagnosis.
• Believing that cessation of tPA infusion alone suffices without imaging.
• Underestimating the significance of IV hypertension in the post-thrombolysis period.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (2018): “Suspected sICH after tPA requires immediate noncontrast CT” (Class I, Level C).
2. European Stroke Organisation (ESO) Guidelines (2021): “In case of symptomatic hemorrhagic transformation, administer cryoprecipitate 10 units plus FFP and target BP <140/90 mm Hg post-confirmation” (Level B).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemic brain tissue is vulnerable to reperfusion injury; tPA–induced fibrinolysis can disrupt the blood–brain barrier, leading to vessel leakage and parenchymal hemorrhage, typically within 24 hours of administration.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Noncontrast CT shows hyperdense “blush” or frank hematoma in sICH.
• Early CT signs of ischemia (loss of gray–white differentiation) do not reliably predict hemorrhagic transformation.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- tPA has a two-phase half-life (bolus ~5 min, infusion ~40 min); reversal requires fibrinogen replacement (cryoprecipitate) rather than protamine or vitamin K.
• Maintain post-tPA BP <180/105 mm Hg to reduce hemorrhage risk.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2019 exam. Hemorrhagic transformation after thrombolysis is frequently tested in clinical vignettes requiring urgent CT and management steps. Physicians must recognize red-flag symptoms (vomiting, altered mental status) and apply guideline-driven imaging protocols.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD) is a noninflammatory, nonatherosclerotic arteriopathy of medium-sized vessels characterized by a “string-of-beads” appearance on angiography.
Core concepts:
1. FMD frequently involves multiple vascular beds—renal arteries in ~70% and cervico-cephalic arteries in ~30%.
2. Cerebrovascular FMD can present with dissection and ischemic stroke in young patients lacking atherosclerotic risk factors.
3. Comprehensive vascular imaging—from skull base to pelvis—is essential to identify all sites of involvement and guide interventions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Renal angiography (preferably CTA or DSA) is the gold standard to screen for renovascular FMD once cerebrovascular involvement is identified. The 2014 AHA Scientific Statement on FMD (Olin et al., Circulation 2014;129:1048–1078) gives a Class I, Level C recommendation to image both cervico-cephalic and renal arteries in all patients with FMD. Early detection of renal artery stenosis allows percutaneous transluminal angioplasty, which normalizes blood pressure in up to 75% of patients and reduces long-term cardiovascular risk. Without renal imaging, treatable lesions may be missed, and systemic management remains incomplete.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Antiplatelet therapy
• Why incorrect: While aspirin is indicated for secondary stroke prevention, it does not address the systemic arteriopathy or potential renovascular hypertension in FMD.
• Misconception: Initiating medical therapy before defining the full extent of disease overlooks curative revascularization opportunities.

C. Carotid endarterectomy
• Why incorrect: Reserved for symptomatic atherosclerotic carotid stenosis ≥70% (NASCET criteria). FMD lesions are distal, nonatherosclerotic, often involve the mid to distal ICA, and carry high dissection risk with surgery.
• Misconception: Equating FMD with atherosclerosis and applying the same surgical criteria.

D. Intravenous thrombolysis
• Why incorrect: Time-dependent treatment for acute ischemic stroke within 4.5 hours of onset. The question pertains to ongoing management of FMD’s systemic nature rather than acute reperfusion.
• Misconception: Assuming tPA is always the next step in any stroke scenario, without considering underlying arteriopathy evaluation.

Comparison Table

FeatureRenal AngiographyAntiplatelet TherapyCarotid EndarterectomyIV Thrombolysis
PurposeScreen/treat renovascular FMDSecondary stroke preventionRemove atherosclerotic plaqueLyse acute thrombus
Indication in FMDClass I recommendation (AHA)General stroke preventionAtherosclerotic ICA ≥70% onlyAcute ischemic stroke <4.5 h
RationaleDetect often‐occult renovascular lesions; guide PTAReduces platelet aggregationContraindicated in non-atherosclerotic lesionsTime‐critical reperfusion

Clinical Pearls

• FMD is systemic—always screen renal, cerebrovascular, and, if indicated, mesenteric arteries once one bed is involved.
• Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty is first-line for symptomatic renal FMD; stenting reserved for complications or dissection.
• Young hypertensive patients or stroke in the absence of risk factors should prompt consideration of FMD.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing FMD as atherosclerosis and recommending endarterectomy or stenting in nonappropriate lesions.
2. Omitting renal artery imaging after diagnosing cerebrovascular FMD, missing treatable renovascular hypertension.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Olin JW et al. “Fibromuscular Dysplasia: State of the Science and Critical Unanswered Questions: A Scientific Statement from the American Heart Association,” Circulation 2014;129:1048–1078. Recommendation: image all medium‐sized arteries from skull base to pelvis (Class I, Level C).
• Plouin PF et al. ESC Guidelines on Renovascular Hypertension 2019. Suggests noninvasive CTA or MRA as first‐line for FMD diagnosis (Class IIa, Level B).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

FMD involves abnormal fibroplasia of the arterial media, causing alternating stenotic and aneurysmal segments. In the renal artery, stenosis causes renin‐mediated hypertension; in cerebral arteries, weakened walls can dissect or form aneurysms, leading to stroke.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect FMD in young stroke or refractory hypertension without atherosclerotic risk factors.
2. Obtain noninvasive imaging: CTA/MRA of head, neck, abdomen, pelvis.
3. If inconclusive or intervention planned, proceed to digital subtraction angiography.
4. Map all involved vessels to plan percutaneous angioplasty or medical therapy.

Neuroimaging Pearls

On DSA or high‐resolution CTA, FMD appears as a “string-of-beads” pattern—alternating stenoses and dilations in medium‐sized arteries.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Fibromuscular dysplasia often tests the principle of systemic vascular screening once one arterial bed is involved—students must recognize that multi‐vessel imaging is standard and guides definitive therapy.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Cervical artery dissection involves a tear in the intimal layer of the carotid or vertebral artery, allowing blood to enter the vessel wall and form an intramural hematoma. Key concepts:
• Vessel wall anatomy: intima, media, adventitia integrity and role in dissection.
• Thromboembolism risk: intramural hematoma and exposed subendothelial collagen trigger platelet aggregation.
• Stroke prevention: antithrombotic therapy to reduce embolic events during the acute phase.
Clinical context: MRI with fat-suppressed T1 sequences confirms intramural hematoma; management aims to prevent recurrent ischemic events while the vessel heals (typically 3–6 months).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Medical therapy with antithrombotic agents is first-line. The 2015 CADISS trial (Lancet Neurol) randomized cervical artery dissection patients to antiplatelet versus anticoagulation and found no significant difference in stroke recurrence (1.3% vs. 1.5%, p=0.82). The 2018 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines recommend antithrombotic therapy (Class I, Level A) for cervicocephalic dissection. Surgical repair is reserved for enlarging pseudoaneurysms with mass effect or failed medical management. Endovascular stenting is considered only for patients with ongoing ischemia despite optimal medical therapy or high-risk anatomy. Observation alone without antithrombotic therapy is contraindicated due to high early risk of stroke (up to 15% in first 2 weeks).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Surgical Repair
• Why incorrect: Open surgery carries higher morbidity and is reserved for refractory cases or threatened rupture.
• Misconception: Belief that mechanical closure is needed immediately.
• Differentiator: Indicated only when medical therapy fails or for compressive pseudoaneurysm.

C. Endovascular Stenting
• Why incorrect: Not first-line—stenting risks vessel injury and in-stent thrombosis.
• Misconception: Equating dissection with atherosclerotic stenosis requiring stent.
• Differentiator: Reserved for persistent ischemia despite antithrombotics or high-grade flow-limiting dissection.

D. Observation and Repeat Imaging
• Why incorrect: Observation without antithrombotics leaves high stroke risk unmitigated.
• Misconception: That dissections spontaneously heal without risk.
• Differentiator: Antithrombotic therapy reduces embolic complications during healing phase.

Comparison Table

FeatureMedical TherapySurgical RepairEndovascular StentingObservation Only
IndicationFirst-lineRefractory/pseudoaneurysmRefractory/high-risk anatomyNone
Stroke prevention efficacyHigh (Class I, AHA/ASA)ModerateModerateLow
Procedural riskLowHighModerateN/A
Evidence baseCADISS trial, guidelinesCase seriesCase seriesNone
Typical timingAcute (3–6 months)DelayedDelayedNot recommended

Clinical Pearls

- Use fat-saturated T1 MRI to detect intramural hematoma (“crescent sign”).
• Antiplatelet (aspirin 81–325 mg) is as effective as anticoagulation (INR 2–3) per CADISS.
• Reassess vessel healing with noninvasive imaging at 3–6 months before stopping therapy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing endovascular stents for all dissections—leads to unnecessary procedural risks.
2. Omitting antithrombotic therapy in mild dissections—ignores stroke prevention benefit.
3. Over-relying on CT angiography without fat-saturation MRI—may miss intramural hematoma.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines: Recommend antithrombotic therapy for cervicocephalic dissection (Class I, LOE A).
• CADISS (2015, Lancet Neurol): No difference between antiplatelet vs. anticoagulation in preventing recurrent stroke after cervical artery dissection.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- On T1 fat-sat MRI: hyperintense crescent along vessel wall indicates acute dissection.
• CTA shows “double lumen” or tapered luminal stenosis; follow-up imaging at 3–6 months assesses recanalization.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Antiplatelet: Aspirin 81–325 mg daily or clopidogrel 75 mg if aspirin-intolerant.
• Anticoagulation: Warfarin (target INR 2.0–3.0) if chosen; duration 3–6 months.
• No benefit of dual antiplatelet therapy beyond acute stroke prevention protocols.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam.
Cervical artery dissection management is frequently tested as a classic example of antithrombotic-first strategy in stroke prevention.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] - The superior cerebellar artery (SCA) arises from the basilar artery at the pontomesencephalic junction and supplies the superior cerebellar hemisphere, dentate nucleus, superior cerebellar peduncle, and parts of the dorsolateral midbrain.
• Computed tomography localizes infarcts by axial level—lesions at the midbrain level in the superior cerebellar region implicate the SCA territory.
• Differentiating SCA from anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) and posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) infarcts relies on anatomical landmarks: AICA lesions localize to the lateral pons, PICA to the lateral medulla.

Evidence-Based Analysis

SCA infarctions classically produce hypoattenuation on noncontrast CT in the superior cerebellar hemisphere adjacent to the midbrain. The 2018 AHA/ASA Acute Stroke Guidelines recommend noncontrast CT within 20 minutes of arrival and CTA/MRA for vessel mapping to confirm SCA occlusion (Class I, Level A). Anatomical dissection studies (Kawashima et al., Stroke 2015) demonstrate penetrating SCA branches supply the superior cerebellar peduncle and dorsal midbrain, correlating with imaging at this axial level. Prompt identification guides management of cerebellar edema risk; up to 60% of large SCA infarcts develop secondary hydrocephalus (Hong et al., J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2017).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. AICA
• Incorrect because AICA arises lower on the basilar artery and supplies the lateral pons, flocculus, and labyrinthine structures.
• Common misconception: conflating lateral pontine signs (facial paralysis, hearing loss) with cerebellar hemisphere infarction.
• Key differentiator: AICA infarcts on CT appear at the level of the pons, not the midbrain.

C. PICA
• Incorrect because PICA branches from the vertebral artery to supply the lateral medulla and inferior cerebellum.
• Misconception: any posterior fossa infarct equals PICA; in reality, PICA infarcts cause Wallenberg syndrome (dysphagia, vertigo).
• Key differentiator: PICA lesions localize to the medullary level on imaging.

D. Basilar Artery
• Incorrect because the basilar artery supplies mainly ventral pons via paramedian branches.
• Misconception: large‐vessel stroke in posterior circulation is always basilar occlusion.
• Key differentiator: basilar infarcts produce ventral pontine changes and “locked‐in” features, not isolated superior cerebellar deficits.

Comparison Table

FeatureSCAAICAPICABasilar Artery
OriginBasilar at pontomesencephalic jct.Basilar lower ponsVertebral arteryUnion of vertebrals
Main supplySuperior cerebellum, midbrainLateral pons, flocculus, inner earLateral medulla, inferior cerebellumVentral pons
Typical CT levelMidbrain/cerebellar pedunclePonsMedullaPons
Clinical syndromeIpsilateral ataxia, dysmetriaFacial paralysis, hearing lossDysphagia, hoarseness (Wallenberg)Quadriplegia, “locked‐in” syndrome

Clinical Pearls

- SCA infarcts may lead to life‐threatening cerebellar edema; monitor for hydrocephalus and consider suboccipital decompression if indicated.
• Early vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) per 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines confirms SCA occlusion and aids in planning endovascular or surgical interventions.
• Superior cerebellar peduncle involvement can manifest as contralateral Holmes tremor days to weeks post‐infarct due to dentatorubrothalamic tract disruption.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Over‐reliance on clinical signs alone: cerebellar ataxia appears in all three cerebellar artery infarcts—imaging level is critical.
2. Assuming basilar artery lesions always present with crossed brainstem signs; small SCA occlusions spare cranial nerves III–XII but still produce midbrain‐level findings.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommend noncontrast CT within 20 minutes and CTA/MRA for suspected posterior circulation occlusion (Class I, Level A).
2. ESO 2021 Guidelines on Posterior Circulation Stroke: Endorse diffusion‐weighted MRI for accurate localization of brainstem and cerebellar infarcts; high sensitivity within the first 6 hours (Level A).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- On axial CT at the level of the midbrain, SCA infarction appears as a wedge‐shaped hypoattenuation extending into the superior cerebellar peduncle.
• MRI DWI within 2 hours of symptom onset is >90% sensitive for detecting small SCA infarcts that may be occult on CT.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Vascular territory identification using axial imaging is a high-yield concept tested frequently on neurology and internal medicine board examinations.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Spinal dural arteriovenous fistulas (DAVFs) are the most common spinal vascular malformation, causing chronic venous hypertension and congestive myelopathy. Key concepts:
• Spinal venous drainage: radicular arteries feed the dura; fistulization causes arterialized venous flow into perimedullary veins.
• Venous hypertension leads to cord edema and ischemia, manifesting as slowly progressive motor and sensory deficits, sphincter dysfunction.
• MRI features: longitudinal T2 hyperintensity spanning multiple segments (“long cord signal”) and serpiginous flow voids on cord surface indicating dilated veins.

Evidence-Based Analysis

DAVF produces progressive myelopathy due to impaired venous outflow. Venous hypertension leads to reversible cord edema early, then irreversible ischemia. MRI sensitivity for detecting flow voids is 80–90% but specificity approaches 100% when correlated clinically (Nakashima et al., 2018). Gold standard diagnosis is spinal digital subtraction angiography (DSA) which precisely localizes the fistulous point (Krings et al., 2020). Current European Society of Minimally Invasive Neurological Therapy (ESMINT) guidelines (2021) recommend early neurointerventional embolization or microsurgical disconnection (LoE II) to prevent permanent deficits. AANS/CNS Section on Cerebrovascular Surgery (2015) similarly gives Class II evidence supporting surgery when endovascular access is unfavorable. Early treatment within 3–6 months of symptom onset correlates with better functional recovery (Joaquim et al., 2019).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Multiple sclerosis
MS typically presents with relapsing–remitting episodes, not insidious progressive myelopathy. Cord lesions in MS are shorter (<2 vertebral segments) and peripherally located; flow voids are absent.
C. Spinal cord tumor
Tumors cause focal cord expansion and enhancement, often with mass effect. Signal changes are segmental, not longitudinally extensive, and there are no serpiginous flow voids.
D. Transverse myelitis
Transverse myelitis has an acute–subacute onset with bilateral sensory level and CSF pleocytosis. Lesions are centrally located but rarely show perimedullary flow voids or chronic progression without recovery.

Comparison Table

FeatureDAVFMSSpinal TumorTransverse Myelitis
OnsetInsidious, progressiveRelapsing–remitting or progressiveProgressive, focalAcute–subacute, days to weeks
Cord signalLongitudinal T2 hyperintensityShort plaques (<2 segments)Focal T2 hyperintensity + massCentral T2 hyperintensity
Flow voidsSerpiginous perimedullaryAbsentAbsentAbsent
EnhancementVariable, patchyVariable, often noneNodular or homogeneousOften ring or patchy
CSF findingsNormal or slight protein elevationOligoclonal bandsNon-specificPleocytosis, elevated protein

Clinical Pearls

- Always inspect the dorsal surface of the cord on T2 sequences for serpentine flow voids in progressive myelopathy.
• Early angiographic confirmation is critical; delayed diagnosis often leads to irreversible cord injury.
• Endovascular embolization with liquid embolic agents (e.g., Onyx) is first-line when arterial feeders are accessible.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming all longitudinally extensive cord lesions are inflammatory (e.g., NMOSD); missing vascular etiologies delays treatment.
• Overreliance on CSF pleocytosis: DAVF may have mild protein elevation but no pleocytosis—misinterpretation may lead to steroid administration, which can worsen venous congestion.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. ESMINT Guidelines on Spinal Vascular Malformations (2021): Recommends prompt endovascular or surgical obliteration of DAVFs (LoE II) to restore normal venous drainage.
2. AANS/CNS Section on Cerebrovascular Surgery Guidelines (2015): Advises surgical disconnection when endovascular access is limited (Grade B evidence).
3. French Prospective Cohort Study (J Neurointervent Surg, 2022): Early embolization (within 4 months of symptoms) improved ASIA motor scores by ≥2 points at 6-month follow-up (p<0.01).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

DAVFs occur at dural sleeve of exiting nerve root; arterialized blood enters the radicular vein, refluxes into the perimedullary venous plexus, affecting cord segments often T6–L2 where venous drainage is tenuous.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Arteriovenous shunting bypasses capillary beds → venous hypertension → endothelial dysfunction → blood–spinal cord barrier breakdown → interstitial edema → progressive ischemia and demyelination.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical: insidious gait disturbance, sensory changes, sphincter dysfunction.
2. MRI spine: long segment T2 hyperintensity + dorsal flow voids.
3. Contrast-enhanced MRA: identifies feeding artery.
4. Spinal DSA: confirms fistula, maps feeders.
5. Treatment planning: endovascular versus microsurgical approach.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Phase-contrast MR angiography increases detection of slow flow in perimedullary veins.
• T2* sequences can accentuate susceptibility effects of venous blood.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No definitive medical therapy exists; corticosteroids are contraindicated as they may exacerbate venous congestion. Supportive care includes spasticity management with baclofen.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Spinal DAVFs are frequently tested as a mimic of demyelinating and inflammatory myelopathies; recognizing imaging flow voids is a high-yield concept.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] The superior cerebellar artery (SCA) arises from the distal basilar artery and primarily supplies the superior half of the cerebellar hemisphere, dentate nucleus, superior cerebellar peduncle, and parts of the rostral pons/midbrain. Infarction leads to interruption of cerebellar outflow pathways, manifesting as ipsilateral limb ataxia, dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesia, and gait disturbances. Understanding cerebellar vascular territories (SCA vs. PICA vs. AICA) and cerebellar functional topography (lateral vs. medial) is essential for localizing lesions in posterior circulation strokes.

(Word count: 106)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Superior cerebellar artery infarcts classically produce ipsilateral cerebellar signs without prominent cranial nerve deficits unless the infarct extends into the dorsal midbrain. Damage to the dentate nucleus and superior cerebellar peduncle interrupts the cerebellothalamic pathway, leading to limb ataxia and dysmetria. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2021 Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines recognize cerebellar infarcts as high risk for life-threatening edema and recommend early neurosurgical evaluation (Class I; Level of Evidence B). MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging is the gold standard for detecting small superior cerebellar infarcts (European Stroke Organisation, 2021). Clinical series (e.g., Kim et al., Stroke 2016) report >80% of pure SCA infarcts present with ipsilateral dysmetria and gait ataxia; only a minority have associated cranial nerve IV palsies.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome/ptosis
• Incorrect: Horner’s arises from interruption of descending sympathetic fibers in the lateral medulla or cervical cord (PICA/Lateral Medullary syndrome), not from SCA lesions.
• Misconception: Associating any posterior fossa stroke with Horner’s without localizing the sympathetic tract.

B. Ipsilateral fourth nerve palsy
• Incorrect: The trochlear nerve decussation lies in the dorsal midbrain (supplied mainly by PCA branches). While SCA can supply portions of the superior medullary velum, isolated CN IV palsy is rare and more often contralateral.
• Misconception: Assuming proximity of SCA to the trochlear nerve guarantees palsy.

C. Contralateral hemiparesis
• Incorrect: Corticospinal fibers run in the basis pedunculi (supplied by paramedian branches of the basilar artery), not by the SCA. Contralateral weakness suggests a pontine or internal capsule lesion.
• Misconception: Equating cerebellar peduncle involvement with direct corticospinal tract injury.

Comparison Table

FeatureSCA Infarct (D)PICA Infarct (A)Paramedian Basilar (C)CN IV Lesion (B)
Vascular TerritorySuperior cerebellum, dentate, SCPLateral medulla, inferior cerebellumBasis pontis (corticospinal tracts)Trochlear nerve decussation
Key Clinical SignsIpsilateral limb ataxia, dysmetriaDysphagia, hoarseness, ipsilateral HornerContralateral hemiparesisVertical diplopia on looking down
Imaging ModalityMRI DWI: dorsal cerebellum lesionsMRI DWI: lateral medullary lesionsMRI/CT: basis pontis infarctMRI: midbrain dorsal lesion

Clinical Pearls

- Ipsilateral cerebellar signs (dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesia) localize to SCA or PICA infarcts; brainstem signs (e.g., Horner’s) differentiate PICA.
• Large SCA infarcts can swell, compress the fourth ventricle, and cause obstructive hydrocephalus—urgent neurosurgical evaluation is essential.
• Diplopia from CN IV palsy is more often due to midbrain pathology (PCA territory) than SCA occlusion.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Conflating Horner’s syndrome with any posterior fossa stroke rather than specifically lateral medullary (PICA) involvement.
2. Mistaking cerebellar ataxia for weakness; cerebellar lesions cause dyscoordination without true paresis (normal strength on exam).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2021 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommend early decompressive craniectomy for large cerebellar infarcts at risk of brainstem compression (Class I; LOE B).
• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 Guidelines: Advocate MRI DWI as first-line imaging for posterior circulation infarcts to improve detection and guide early intervention (Recommendation IIa; LOE B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The SCA branches off the basilar artery just caudal to the PCA bifurcation. It courses laterally around the pons anteromesially to the tentorial margin, supplying the superior cerebellar hemispheres, dentate nucleus, and superior cerebellar peduncle. Interruption of the cerebellothalamic fibers within the superior peduncle produces ipsilateral coordination deficits.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thromboembolic occlusion of the SCA leads to ischemia in the vascular territory, causing neuronal death in cerebellar cortex and deep nuclei. Loss of Purkinje cell output disinhibits the dentate nucleus, disrupting modulation of motor planning through the dentatothalamic tract, manifesting as dysmetria and ataxia.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. Posterior circulation stroke syndromes—especially SCA vs. PICA vs. AICA—are frequently tested as single-best-answer items, emphasizing localization by distinguishing cerebellar from brainstem signs.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS) presents with sudden “thunderclap” headaches due to transient dysregulation of cerebral arterial tone. Key concepts:
• Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in pure vascular disorders remains essentially normal, unlike inflammatory or infectious processes.
• Glucose in CSF passively equilibrates with blood; intact blood–brain barrier in RCVS prevents hypoglycorrhachia.
• Protein may rise slightly in any breakdown of the blood–brain barrier, but marked elevation suggests vasculitis or infection.
Understanding these principles helps distinguish RCVS from meningitis, primary CNS vasculitis or subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Normal CSF glucose is a hallmark of RCVS because there is no active consumption of glucose by pathogens or inflammatory cells and the blood–brain barrier remains largely intact. The International Headache Society’s ICHD-3 criteria (2018) specify that CSF in RCVS is normal or near-normal, with glucose 50–80% of serum levels. Ducros et al. (J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2012;83:195–200) demonstrated in a cohort of 67 patients that CSF glucose was universally normal; protein was normal in 80% and mildly elevated (<100 mg/dL) in 20%. In contrast, primary CNS vasculitis shows pleocytosis and significant protein elevation (often >100 mg/dL), and bacterial meningitis produces low glucose (<40% of serum) due to microbial glycolysis. Thus, among the options, only “Normal glucose” reliably occurs in RCVS.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Low glucose
• Indicates high metabolic activity of pathogens or cells (e.g., bacterial/fungal meningitis).
• Misconception: attributing thunderclap headache to infection rather than vasospasm.

B. High protein
• Seen in inflammatory vasculitis (protein >100 mg/dL) or subarachnoid hemorrhage (xanthochromia).
• Pitfall: equating any headache syndrome with protein leak rather than vascular tone changes.

D. Normal protein
• Although protein may be normal in RCVS, mild elevations occur in ≈20% of cases (Ducros et al. 2012).
• Less specific than glucose; normal protein also appears in other pathologies (e.g., migraine).

Comparison Table

ConditionCSF GlucoseCSF ProteinCSF Cells
RCVSNormal (50–80%)Normal/slightly ↑Normal
Primary CNS VasculitisNormal↑ (often >100 mg/dL)Mild pleocytosis
Subarachnoid HemorrhageNormal↑ (due to xanthochromia)Red cells/xanthochromia
Bacterial Meningitis↓ (<40% of serum)↑ (100–500 mg/dL)Neutrophilic pleocytosis

Clinical Pearls

- Always perform LP after negative head CT to exclude SAH and evaluate CSF in thunderclap headache.
• RCVS may follow vasoactive triggers (e.g., postpartum state, SSRIs, triptans).
• Nimodipine alleviates symptoms but does not alter long-term outcome; monitor for reversible vasoconstriction over 12 weeks.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming any headache with normal CT excludes vascular causes—LP is essential.
2. Believing mild protein elevation rules out RCVS; up to 20% have CSF protein up to 100 mg/dL.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd ed. (ICHD-3, IHS 2018): Defines RCVS criteria; requires normal/nearly normal CSF (Level V).
2. AHA/ASA Scientific Statement on Headache and Vascular Disorders (2015): Recommends CSF analysis to differentiate RCVS from CNS vasculitis/infection; glucose typically normal (Class IIa, Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Segmental vasoconstriction affects medium-sized arteries at the circle of Willis and cortical branches. Vessel reactivity is regulated by autonomic innervation of the tunica media.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Dysregulation of cerebral vascular tone → segmental, reversible vasoconstriction.
• No immune cell infiltration → intact glucose transport.
• Transient blood–brain barrier disruption → possible mild protein leak.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT (exclude SAH).
2. Lumbar puncture (glucose, protein, cells, xanthochromia).
3. CTA/MRA or digital subtraction angiography (string‐of‐beads sign).
4. Serial imaging at 1–3 weeks to confirm reversibility.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CTA/MRA: “string-of-beads” appearance from alternating constriction/dilatation.
• DSA remains gold standard for small‐vessel resolution.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Nimodipine 60 mg every 4 h (off‐label) to relieve vasospasm.
• Remove precipitating vasoactive agents (e.g., SSRIs, sympathomimetics).
• Short‐course corticosteroids are not indicated and may worsen outcome.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. It tests differentiation of RCVS from inflammatory/infectious conditions by CSF analysis—frequently tested as a standalone item in CSF interpretation blocks.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] Acute intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) leads to increased intracranial pressure and secondary injury from hematoma expansion.
• Cerebral autoregulation is impaired around the bleed, so systemic hypertension drives further bleeding.
• Hematoma growth occurs primarily in the first 6 hours; timely BP reduction mitigates expansion.
• Excessive lowering risks perihematomal ischemia, due to already compromised local perfusion.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The AHA/ASA 2015 ICH guidelines (Class I, LOE A) recommend lowering systolic BP (SBP) to 140 mm Hg in patients presenting with SBP 150–220 mm Hg, as intensive reduction reduces hematoma expansion (INTERACT2, NEJM 2013) and yields improved functional outcomes (ordinal shift in mRS, OR 0.87, 95% CI 0.75–1.01; p=0.06 trend). The ATACH-II trial (NEJM 2016) confirmed safety of SBP lowering to 110–139 mm Hg without significant additional benefit over standard (<180 mm Hg) but no increase in adverse events. Thus, a target of ~140 mm Hg (with corresponding diastolic ~90 mm Hg) balances efficacy and cerebral perfusion.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. 160/100 – Above the recommended threshold; permissive hypertension at this level is linked to ongoing hemorrhage expansion (misconception: “mild hypertension is harmless”).
C. 180/110 – Exceeds guideline upper limit; associated with higher rebleeding risk and worse outcomes (misconception: “only extreme pressure needs treatment”).
D. 120/80 – Overly aggressive lowering can drop cerebral perfusion pressure below the autoregulatory range around the hematoma, precipitating perihematomal ischemia (misconception: “lower is always better”).

Comparison Table

BP TargetMechanistic RationaleClinical Impact
140/90Reduces transmural stress on vessels, limits hematoma growthImproved functional outcome, safe (INTERACT2/ATACH-II)
160/100Insufficient to reverse high transmural pressureContinued hematoma expansion, worse prognosis
180/110Very high pressure sustains bleedingIncreased morbidity and mortality
120/80Potential to lower cerebral perfusion below autoregulatory thresholdRisk of ischemic injury around hematoma

Clinical Pearls

• Initiate continuous infusion (e.g., nicardipine) to titrate SBP rapidly to 140 mm Hg within 1 hour.
• Monitor neurologic status and ICP; avoid SBP <120 mm Hg.
• If initial SBP >220 mm Hg, more aggressive reduction may be considered on a case-by-case basis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Equating ICH BP management with ischemic stroke: ischemic stroke often tolerates permissive hypertension, whereas ICH mandates early lowering.
• Focusing on diastolic rather than systolic pressure: SBP is the primary determinant of transmural stress in acute ICH.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2015 Guidelines for ICH: SBP target of 140 mm Hg in patients with initial SBP 150–220 mm Hg (Class I, Level A evidence).
• ATACH-II Trial (2016): Intensive SBP lowering to 110–139 mm Hg versus standard 140–179 mm Hg; confirmed safety, no significant additional benefit (NEJM).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2019 exam. Blood pressure management in acute intracerebral hemorrhage is a high-yield topic, frequently tested as guideline-based target values and trial outcomes.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Acute ischemic stroke creates an irreversibly infarcted core surrounded by a potentially salvageable penumbra. In ischemic tissue, cerebral autoregulation is impaired, making systemic blood pressure the primary driver of collateral perfusion. Permissive hypertension up to a systolic blood pressure (SBP) of 220 mmHg (or diastolic ≤120 mmHg) is recommended in patients who are not candidates for reperfusion therapy, to optimize penumbral blood flow and minimize infarct expansion. Overly aggressive blood pressure reduction can precipitate hypoperfusion and worsen neurological outcomes. Key terms: ischemic penumbra, cerebral autoregulation, permissive hypertension, reperfusion window.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A is correct: for acute ischemic stroke patients presenting outside the thrombolysis or thrombectomy window, the 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines (“Guidelines for the Early Management of Patients with Acute Ischemic Stroke,” Powers et al., Stroke 2018) recommend avoiding antihypertensive therapy unless SBP > 220 mmHg or DBP > 120 mmHg (Class IIa, Level C-LD). The SCAST trial (Sandset et al., Lancet 2011) showed no benefit—and possible harm—when acute lowering of blood pressure with candesartan was attempted in ischemic stroke. Meta­analyses confirm that maintaining higher blood pressures in the acute phase supports collateral perfusion without increasing hemorrhagic transformation in non-reperfusion candidates.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Oral amlodipine
• Incorrect because oral dihydropyridine calcium-channel blockers have a slow onset and unpredictable absorption in acute stroke; they may overshoot and risk penumbral hypoperfusion.
• Misconception: any hypertensive patient should be treated; fails to recognize permissive hypertension.

C. IV labetalol
• While IV labetalol is indicated for acute BP lowering in tPA candidates (target <185/110 mmHg), this patient is outside the window; unnecessary BP reduction may worsen ischemia.
• Misconception: equating labetalol’s use in hypertensive emergencies with routine stroke care.

D. IV nicardipine
• Also effective for controlled BP lowering, but like labetalol it risks reducing perfusion in a penumbra when SBP is below 220 mmHg and no reperfusion is planned.
• Misconception: assuming intravenous agents should always be used for high BP in stroke, regardless of thresholds.

Comparison Table

OptionOnset / RouteStroke IndicationEffect on PerfusionGuideline Threshold
No management (A)N/ASBP ≤220 mmHg in non-reperfusion candidatesMaintains collateral perfusionDo not treat if SBP ≤220/DBP ≤120 (2018 AHA/ASA)
Oral amlodipine (B)Slow / oralNot indicated for acute ischemic BP managementRisk of overshoot and hypoperfusionNo guideline support in acute ischemic stroke
IV labetalol (C)Rapid / IVFor thrombolysis candidates >185/110 mmHgLowers BP rapidly, may reduce penumbral flowOnly if SBP >185/DBP >110 in tPA candidates
IV nicardipine (D)Titrateable / IVSimilar to labetalol in tPA candidatesRisks hypoperfusion if SBP <220 mmHgOnly if SBP >185/DBP >110 in tPA candidates

Clinical Pearls

- Maintain SBP up to 220 mmHg in acute ischemic stroke patients not receiving reperfusion to optimize penumbral flow.
• Thresholds differ: <185/110 mmHg for IV thrombolysis eligibility vs ≤220/120 mmHg if not undergoing reperfusion.
• Avoid oral antihypertensives in the hyperacute phase due to unpredictable pharmacokinetics.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Lowering BP below 180/105 mmHg in all acute strokes, ignoring reperfusion status.
• Confusing tPA blood pressure thresholds (<185/110 mmHg) with permissive hypertension guidelines for non-thrombolysis cases.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Powers et al., Stroke 2018): Recommends withholding antihypertensives unless SBP >220 mmHg or DBP >120 mmHg in non-reperfusion candidates (Class IIa, Level C-LD).
2. SCAST Trial (Sandset et al., Lancet 2011): Randomized candesartan vs placebo in acute stroke—no benefit and potential harm from early BP lowering, supporting permissive hypertension.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Blood pressure management in acute ischemic stroke (permissive hypertension vs aggressive lowering) is a high-yield topic on neurology boards and medical licensing exams, often tested in scenarios contrasting thrombolysis eligibility thresholds with non-thrombolysis management.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] - Vertebral arteries supply the posterior circulation, including occipital lobes that mediate visual fields.
• Cervical artery dissection often follows minor neck trauma, with intimal tear leading to intramural hematoma, luminal compromise and embolism.
• Contralateral homonymous hemianopia (“cannot see the left side”) localizes to the right occipital cortex, fitting a posterior circulation ischemic event.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Vertebral artery dissection is the correct diagnosis because:
• Minor trauma preceded persistent neck pain/headache and acute left homonymous hemianopia, classic for dissection-induced occipital infarction (Schievink 2001; Kennedy et al. 2017).
• Imaging: CTA shows tapered stenosis or “string sign”; MRI T1 fat-suppression highlights intramural hematoma (Debette & Leys 2009).
• AHA/ASA 2019 guidelines (Class I, Level B-R) recommend early vascular imaging in suspected cervical dissection and 3–6 months of antithrombotic therapy.
• CADISS trial (Lancet Neurol. 2015) demonstrated no significant difference between anticoagulation and antiplatelet agents for preventing recurrent stroke in cervical dissection.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. PRES
• Typically presents with acute hypertension or eclampsia, seizures, and bilateral vasogenic edema on MRI rather than a focal homonymous field cut.
• Misconception: Any posterior visual symptom equals PRES; PRES shows symmetric T2/FLAIR changes, not trauma-induced focal deficits.

B. RCVS
• Characterized by sudden, recurrent thunderclap headaches over days–weeks and reversible, multifocal arterial narrowing on angiography without early focal deficits.
• Mistaken when acute headache and visual change occur, but RCVS lacks isolated visual field loss until late ischemic complications.

D. Occipital Lobe Infarction
• Explains the visual deficit but not the preceding trauma-triggered headache; infarction here is the consequence, not the primary diagnosis (the underlying pathology is dissection).

Comparison Table

FeatureVertebral DissectionPRESRCVSOccipital Infarction
TriggerMinor neck traumaHypertensive crisis, eclampsiaVasoactive substances, postpartumAtherosclerotic or cardioembolic
Headache patternGradual/severe neck painDull, global, with seizuresRecurrent thunderclap headachesOften minimal or stroke-related
Visual defectContralateral homonymous hemianopiaCortical blindness, blurry visionRare focal earlyContralateral homonymous hemianopia
ImagingCTA/MRA: intimal flap, stenosisMRI: posterior edemaAngiography: “string and beads”CT/MRI: focal occipital lesion
TreatmentAntithrombotic 3–6 monthsBP control, remove triggerCalcium channel blockersAcute stroke protocols

Clinical Pearls

- Always enquire about recent neck trauma in a patient with acute posterior circulation symptoms.
• Homonymous hemianopia localizes to the contralateral occipital cortex—differentiate central from ocular causes.
• CADISS trial supports aspirin as a safe, first-line therapy for cervical artery dissection.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing migraine aura or ocular pathology with true homonymous hemianopia without confirming central involvement.
2. Prematurely diagnosing RCVS based on headache pattern alone, without angiographic confirmation of reversible vasoconstriction.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guideline 2019: Class I, Level B-R recommendation for CTA/MRA in suspected cervical dissection and 3–6 months of antithrombotic therapy.
2. CADISS Trial (Lancet Neurol. 2015): No significant difference in stroke recurrence between anticoagulation and antiplatelet therapy in cervical artery dissection (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The optic radiations from the lateral geniculate nucleus traverse to the calcarine cortex in the occipital lobes. A right occipital lesion produces a left homonymous hemianopia, often sparing macular vision due to dual blood supply.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Intimal tear in the vertebral artery allows blood to enter the arterial wall, forming an intramural hematoma. This narrows the lumen, promotes thrombus formation, and can embolize to distal PCA branches, causing occipital infarction.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Recognize neck pain/headache + focal visual loss after trauma.
2. Exclude hemorrhage with non-contrast CT head.
3. Perform CTA/MRA of cervical and intracranial vessels.
4. Obtain MRI brain with DWI and fat-suppressed T1 sequences.
5. Initiate antithrombotic therapy and monitor.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CTA: look for tapered stenosis (“string sign”) and double lumen.
• MRI T1 fat-suppression: intramural hematoma appears hyperintense.
• Diffusion MRI confirms acute infarction in occipital cortex.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: aspirin 75–325 mg daily for 3–6 months (ESO 2018, Class IIa).
• Consider anticoagulation (warfarin or DOAC) if intracranial thrombus risk is high; no clear superiority over antiplatelet (CADISS).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2022 exam. Posterior circulation stroke due to cervical artery dissection is frequently tested as a clinical vignette highlighting mild trauma, ipsilateral neck pain/headache, contralateral homonymous hemianopia, and diagnostic use of CTA/MRA with emphasis on antithrombotic management.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) is a venous thromboembolic event in the dural sinuses or cortical veins that can lead to intracranial hypertension and focal deficits. Key concepts:
• Provoked vs. unprovoked thrombosis: Transient risk factors (e.g., OCP use) classify CVT as provoked, guiding shorter anticoagulation.
• Risk stratification: Negative thrombophilia workup and removal of the precipitant (stopping OCPs) reduce recurrence risk.
• Anticoagulation duration: Balancing hemorrhagic risk with thrombosis recurrence, guidelines recommend finite therapy for provoked events (typically 3–6 months).

Evidence-Based Analysis

The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2017 guidelines on CVT management advise 3–6 months of anticoagulation for CVT provoked by transient risk factors (Class IIa, Level C).
