– MRI (DWI/FLAIR) is more sensitive for early infarction but takes longer, may delay urgent vascular intervention.
– Misconception: MRI is the gold standard for all stroke imaging; in hyperacute settings, vascular status on CTA is more actionable.

C. Carotid Doppler ultrasound
– Evaluates only extracranial carotid bifurcation; cannot assess intracranial vessels or vertebral arteries.
– Misconception: Duplex ultrasound suffices for all hemodynamic strokes; in acute settings, intracranial imaging is critical.

D. Echocardiography
– Detects cardiac sources of embolism (e.g., PFO, atrial thrombus) but does not assess cerebral vessel patency.
– Misconception: All ischemic strokes should first get a cardiac workup; while important, hemodynamic strokes demand urgent vascular imaging.

Comparison Table

FeatureCTA (Correct)MRI BrainCarotid DopplerEchocardiography
Primary TargetIntra-/extracranial arterial patencyParenchymal infarction detailExtracranial carotid stenosisCardiac thrombus/source
Time to perform2–3 minutes15–30 minutes10–15 minutes30–60 minutes
Sensitivity for LVO>95%Variable (depends on MRA)N/AN/A
Treatment implicationsGuides thrombectomy/carotid revascular.Confirms infarct age and distributionMay guide CEA but misses intracranialGuides anticoagulation decisions
LimitationRadiation, contrast useAvailability, motion artifactsNo intracranial dataDoes not image cerebral vessels

Clinical Pearls

- Watershed infarcts on CT should prompt urgent vascular imaging to detect hemodynamic compromise.
• In the hyperacute stroke window, prioritize tests that directly influence reperfusion: CTA > MRI > ultrasound > echocardiography.
• Bilateral watershed infarcts in hypotensive patients suggest systemic perfusion failure; unilateral suggests proximal stenosis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming carotid Doppler is sufficient for all suspected hemodynamic strokes without evaluating intracranial vessels.
2. Ordering MRI first to “confirm” infarction, thereby delaying definitive vascular imaging and treatment.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Powers et al.): CTA for evaluation of large‐vessel occlusion—Class I, Level A.
• MR CLEAN Trial (2015, N Engl J Med): Patients selected by CTA for mechanical thrombectomy had significantly better functional outcomes (adjusted OR 1.67; 95% CI 1.21–2.30).
• ESCAPE Trial (2015, N Engl J Med): CTA plus perfusion imaging improved selection for endovascular therapy and reduced disability (NNT=3).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Watershed zones lie between terminal branches of major cerebral arteries:
• Cortical (external) between ACA–MCA and MCA–PCA.
• Internal (deep) between superficial MCA and deep perforators.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Watershed infarcts result from inadequate cerebral perfusion during:
• Systemic hypotension (e.g., cardiac arrest, shock)
• Proximal arterial stenosis (e.g., ICA atherosclerosis)
Collateral flow is insufficient to maintain perfusion in border‐zone territories.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage and identify infarct patterns.
2. CTA from aortic arch to vertex to assess for proximal stenosis/occlusion.
3. If CTA contraindicated, consider MRA.
4. Subsequent carotid Doppler and echocardiography to complete stroke workup.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Watershed infarcts on CT appear as wedge‐shaped hypodense areas at the cortical ribbon or centrum semiovale (“string‐of‐beads” pattern).
• CTA collateral grading (e.g., ASITN/SIR scale) helps predict infarct progression and treatment response.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam.
Watershed infarction management and imaging workflow are frequently tested on neurology board exams, often in the context of differentiating hemodynamic vs. embolic stroke etiologies.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] - Watershed (border zone) infarcts occur in regions between two non‐anastomosing arterial territories (e.g., ACA/MCA, MCA/PCA) and are especially vulnerable to systemic hypoperfusion.
• Early cytotoxic edema in acute ischemia is detected as diffusion restriction on MRI’s diffusion‐weighted imaging (DWI) sequences, often within minutes of onset.
• Fluid‐attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) and apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) maps localize and age infarcts, distinguishing acute from chronic lesions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

MRI with DWI has a sensitivity >95% for detecting acute ischemic changes compared to <50% for CT.1 In watershed infarcts—often small and cortical or subcortical—DWI visualizes cytotoxic edema within minutes to hours, guiding acute management. FLAIR sequences differentiate hyperacute (<6 h) from subacute infarcts.2 CTA visualizes vessel patency and collateral flow but lacks parenchymal resolution to define microinfarcts. PET scanning is primarily a research tool for cerebral metabolism and is not used routinely in acute stroke. Skull X-rays have no soft‐tissue contrast and cannot detect infarction.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. CTA
• Reason incorrect: Visualizes luminal stenosis and collaterals, not parenchymal ischemic injury.
• Misconception: Equating vessel imaging with infarct detection.
• Differentiator: CTA is excellent for large‐vessel occlusion but insensitive for early cytotoxic edema.

C. PET scan
• Reason incorrect: Measures cerebral glucose metabolism and blood flow, used in research and epilepsy mapping, not standard for acute infarct detection.
• Misconception: Belief that metabolic imaging replaces structural imaging in stroke.
• Differentiator: Low spatial resolution and limited availability.

D. X-ray
• Reason incorrect: Cannot visualize brain parenchyma or ischemia.
• Misconception: General radiograph utility across body systems.
• Differentiator: Only bone/detail visualization; no soft‐tissue contrast.

Comparison Table

ModalityPrincipleSensitivity for Acute Watershed InfarctionClinical Role
MRI (DWI)Detects water diffusion restriction>95%Gold standard for early ischemia
CTAContrast CT angiography of vessels~30–50% for parenchymal changesVessel patency, collateral assessment
PET scanMeasures cerebral metabolism & perfusion~60% (research settings)Research/epilepsy, not acute stroke
X-rayProjection radiography of bone/air0%None for brain infarction

Clinical Pearls

- In acute stroke, prioritize an MRI with DWI when available, as it defines infarct core and guides reperfusion decisions.
• Watershed infarcts often present with “man‐in‐a‐barrel” syndrome (proximal arm weakness) in ACA/MCA border zones.
• CT perfusion can complement CTA to approximate penumbra but still lags behind DWI MRI in specificity.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming CT angiography (CTA) will show small cortical or subcortical infarcts rather than just vascular anatomy.
• Believing PET scans are used clinically for acute stroke rather than investigational metabolic assessment.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines:
– Recommendation: MRI with DWI is preferred for diagnosing acute stroke when it does not delay treatment (Class I, Level A).3
2. ESO–ESMINT 2021 Guidelines:
– Recommendation: Use DWI MRI to identify infarct core and assess eligibility for endovascular therapy beyond 6 hours (Level B).4

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Watershed regions lie at distal fields of the ACA/MCA (anterior watershed) and MCA/PCA (posterior watershed). These zones have terminal arterioles with limited collateral support, making them vulnerable in hypotension.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Systemic hypoperfusion or proximal arterial stenosis reduces cerebral perfusion pressure. In border zones, autoregulation fails first, leading to energy failure, Na⁺/K⁺‐ATPase dysfunction, cytotoxic edema, and diffusion restriction on MRI.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- DWI: Hyperintense signal with corresponding low ADC confirms acute infarction.
• FLAIR/DWI mismatch can estimate stroke onset within the therapeutic window.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. Border zone infarcts and imaging modalities are frequently tested, often as scenario‐based questions requiring recognition of DWI’s role in early ischemia detection.

References:
1. Warach et al., NEJM 1995;333(21):1454–1459.
2. Lansberg et al., Stroke 2001;32(11):2632–2637.
3. Powers et al., Stroke 2018;49(3):e46–e110.
4. Nogueira et al., Eur Stroke J 2021;6(1):I–XXX.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] Cerebral vasospasm is a delayed, sustained constriction of intracranial arteries following subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), leading to delayed cerebral ischemia (DCI). In traumatic brain injury (TBI) with associated SAH, blood breakdown products trigger endothelial dysfunction and smooth muscle contraction. Nimodipine, a lipophilic dihydropyridine calcium‐channel blocker, crosses the blood–brain barrier and preferentially relaxes cerebral vessels. Prophylactic administration aims to reduce DCI and poor functional outcome. Students should understand:
• Pathophysiology of blood‐induced arterial spasm (endothelin release, free radical generation)
• Role of L‐type Ca2+ channels in vascular smooth muscle contraction
• Distinction between prophylaxis (nimodipine in SAH) vs. acute ICP management (hyperventilation)

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. IV fluids
• Reason incorrect: While adequate volume status supports cerebral perfusion, hypervolemia alone has not been shown to prevent vasospasm or DCI. Misconception: “Triple‐H” therapy prophylaxis includes hypervolemia; in fact, induced hypertension (not simple IV fluids) treats established vasospasm.

C. Hyperventilation
• Reason incorrect: Lowers PaCO₂ and causes cerebral vasoconstriction, reducing intracranial pressure at the cost of CBF, which can exacerbate ischemia in vasospasm. Misconception: Any vasoconstriction is beneficial for ICP control, but in vasospasm it is harmful.

D. Antiepileptic drugs
• Reason incorrect: Seizure prophylaxis does not influence vascular smooth muscle or prevent vasospasm. Misconception: “Preventing seizures prevents secondary ischemia,” but this does not address spasm‐mediated DCI.

Comparison Table

InterventionMechanismEvidence for Vasospasm ProphylaxisRecommended Use
NimodipineL‐type Ca²⁺ channel blockade; neuroprotectionRCTs and meta‐analyses show reduced DCI and poor outcomeOral 60 mg q4h × 21 days in SAH patients
IV fluidsIncreases intravascular volumeNo RCT support for prophylaxis; risk of cerebral edemaMaintain euvolemia; avoid hypervolemia alone
Hyperventilation↓PaCO₂ → vasoconstrictionContraindicated prophylactically; worsens ischemiaShort‐term ICP control only
AntiepilepticStabilizes neuronal membranesNo effect on vasospasm or DCISeizure prophylaxis in TBI only

Clinical Pearls

- Nimodipine should be initiated within 96 hours of hemorrhage and continued for 21 days to reduce DCI and improve outcomes.
• “Triple‐H” therapy components differ: prophylaxis relies solely on nimodipine; induced hypertension (not hypervolemia) is used to reverse established vasospasm.
• Avoid prophylactic hyperventilation (PaCO₂ <30 mm Hg) in vasospasm risk—can precipitate ischemic deficits.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating prophylactic hyperventilation with vasospasm prevention; in reality it decreases CBF and worsens ischemia.
2. Believing seizure prophylaxis (e.g., phenytoin) mitigates vasospasm—anticonvulsants have no effect on vascular smooth muscle.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2012 Guidelines for Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage – Class I, Level A recommendation for oral nimodipine to prevent DCI and poor outcome.
2. Cochrane Review (Gedge et al., 2016) – Nimodipine reduces the risk of poor functional outcome (RR 0.82) in SAH patients; moderate‐quality evidence.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Nimodipine is a dihydropyridine calcium‐channel blocker with high lipophilicity allowing CNS penetration. Standard dosing: 60 mg po every 4 hours for 21 days. Monitor for hypotension; hold if systolic BP <90 mm Hg. IV formulations are not recommended due to risk of severe hypotension.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2022 exam. Cerebral vasospasm prophylaxis with nimodipine is a high‐yield topic on neurology and critical care boards, frequently tested via SAH vignettes asking about delayed ischemia prevention.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is A. Nimodipine. This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] tPA (alteplase) promotes fibrinolysis but increases bradykinin, which can cause angioedema—most often involving the tongue or oropharynx. Angioedema may be histamine-mediated, bradykinin-mediated, or mixed; risk factors include concurrent ACE-inhibitor use and insular cortex infarcts. Early recognition is critical: mild cases without airway compromise respond to anti-inflammatory measures, whereas impending airway obstruction mandates intubation. Dysarthria from tongue swelling reflects oropharyngeal edema rather than new neurologic decline.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Steroids plus antihistamines constitute first-line therapy for moderate tPA-induced angioedema without airway compromise. The 2019 AHA/ASA Acute Stroke Guidelines (Powers et al.) recommend IV methylprednisolone (e.g., 125 mg) with H1 (diphenhydramine 50 mg IV) and H2 blockers (ranitidine 50 mg IV) for orolingual angioedema (Class IIa, Level C-LD). tPA increases bradykinin by plasmin-mediated activation of the kinin cascade; histamine blockade and steroids reduce capillary permeability and swelling. Epinephrine can be added if progression occurs. Prophylactic icatibant (bradykinin B2 receptor antagonist) has been used in refractory cases. Immediate intubation is reserved for stridor, hypoxia, or rapid progression; routine prophylactic airway control is not indicated when the patient maintains a patent airway.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Intubation
• Incorrect because there is no evidence of airway compromise (e.g., stridor, hypoxia).
• Misconception: that all angioedema mandates airway control. Prophylactic intubation risks ventilator-associated complications and is reserved for impending obstruction.

C. ACE inhibitor with diuretics
• ACE inhibitors increase bradykinin and are a known cause of angioedema—contraindicated here.
• Diuretics do not reduce angioedema and may worsen hypotension or renal perfusion in stroke patients.

D. Observation and supportive care
• Passive observation delays definitive therapy; moderate angioedema unaddressed can progress to airway compromise.
• Common mistake: underestimating oropharyngeal swelling in patients who remain hemodynamically stable.

Comparison Table

OptionMechanismIndication in tPA AngioedemaAppropriate Here?
A. IntubationSecures airway via endotracheal tubeOnly if signs of airway compromise (stridor, hypoxia)No
B. Steroid + AntihistamineReduces histamine-mediated inflammation and capillary leakFirst-line for moderate orolingual angioedema without airway threatYes
C. ACE Inhibitor + DiureticsInhibits angiotensin conversion; promotes diuresisACE inhibitors aggravate bradykinin-mediated angioedema; diuretics irrelevantNo
D. Observation & Supportive CareWatchful waitingReserved for very mild, non-progressive edemaNo

Clinical Pearls

- tPA-induced angioedema occurs in ~1–5% of patients, often within 30–60 minutes of infusion.
• Concurrent ACE-inhibitor use doubles the risk; inquire about home medications pre-thrombolysis.
• Icatibant (bradykinin B2-receptor antagonist) may be considered in refractory or rapidly progressing cases.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all angioedema requires immediate intubation—airway management should be guided by clinical signs, not radiographic severity alone.
2. Believing ACE inhibitors and diuretics mitigate angioedema—ACE inhibitors precipitate bradykinin accumulation; diuretics have no role.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Powers WJ et al., 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommend IV steroids plus H1/H2 blockade for tPA-induced orolingual angioedema (Class IIa, Level C-LD).
2. Kaplan AP et al., 2020 AAAAI Consensus on Bradykinin-Mediated Angioedema: Endorses icatibant as adjunctive therapy for tPA-related cases refractory to antihistamines/steroids (Expert Opinion).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. On neurology boards, angioedema due to tPA is frequently tested in clinical vignettes focusing on timing (during or immediately after infusion), risk factors (ACE inhibitors, insular infarcts), and stepwise management (steroids/antihistamines → epinephrine → icatibant → airway assessment).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Intracranial aneurysms arise at arterial bifurcations (e.g., the A.Com junction) due to focal vessel wall weakness. Hemodynamic stress (wall shear stress) and vessel radius interplay per Laplace’s law: wall tension ∝ pressure × radius. Larger aneurysms impose greater wall tension and thinner walls, increasing rupture risk. Other modulators include local flow dynamics (influenced by location), systemic factors (hypertension), and biological factors (sex hormones). Understanding aneurysm morphology and hemodynamics is fundamental for risk stratification and management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Size of the aneurysm is the single strongest predictor of rupture. In the ISUIA cohort (Wiebers et al., 2003, JAMA), unruptured anterior circulation aneurysms <7 mm had a five-year rupture rate <0.1%, whereas those ≥10 mm approached 1–2% per year. The PHASES score (Greving et al., 2014, NEJM) assigns the greatest weight to size (points: <7 mm=0, 7–9 mm=3, 10–19 mm=6, ≥20 mm=10). AHA/ASA 2015 guidelines recommend considering treatment for aneurysms ≥7 mm in anterior circulation (Class IIA, Level B). Mechanistically, larger aneurysms have increased circumference and wall tension, making them more prone to focal wall degeneration and rupture.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Location of the aneurysm
• While posterior circulation aneurysms (e.g., basilar tip) carry higher baseline rupture rates than anterior communicating ones, within A.Com lesions size remains more predictive than sub‐site variations.
• Misconception: “All posterior aneurysms are most dangerous.” Differentiator: absolute rupture risk within one vessel location is dominated by size.

C. Uncontrolled blood pressure
• Hypertension elevates transmural pressure and contributes to aneurysm formation and growth, but does not independently predict rupture as strongly as size.
• Misconception: “Poorly controlled BP alone drives rupture.” In reality, size amplifies wall tension more significantly.

D. Female gender
• Females have ~1.5× higher incidence of aneurysms, possibly due to estrogen effects on vessel integrity, but sex alone does not predict which aneurysm will rupture.
• Misconception: “Women’s aneurysms rupture more often.” Differentiator: gender is non‐modifiable and weakly associated compared to quantitative size metrics.

Comparison Table

FactorRelative Rupture RiskModifiable?Weight in PHASES Score
Size ≥10 mm (correct)High (1–2%/yr for ≥10 mm; up to 6%/yr if ≥25 mm)No6–10 points
Location (A.Com vs PCOM)Moderate (posterior > anterior; ∼0.5% vs 0.1%/yr)No2 points (posterior)
Uncontrolled BPLow incremental risk (HR ~1.2)Yes1 point
Female genderLow (RR ~1.5 overall)No0 points

Clinical Pearls

• Aneurysms ≥7 mm in anterior circulation should prompt discussion of preventive intervention (AHA/ASA Class IIA).
• PHASES score integrates size, age, hypertension, earlier SAH, aneurysm site, and population to estimate 5-year rupture risk.
• Regular imaging surveillance intervals are guided primarily by aneurysm size trajectory rather than patient sex or baseline BP alone.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overemphasizing location: Believing an A.Com aneurysm automatically has higher rupture risk than any posterior lesion, when size thresholds supersede location within the same vessel.
2. Equating hypertension control with immediate rupture risk reduction: While vital for prevention, acute size-mediated wall tension drives rupture, not transient BP variations.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2015 Guidelines on Management of Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms: Recommend consideration of repair for anterior circulation aneurysms ≥7 mm (Class IIA, Level B).
• Greving et al., 2014 (NEJM) PHASES Study: Established a validated risk score; size contributed the largest point allocation, underscoring its predictive value (Level of Evidence: B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The anterior communicating artery connects the A1 segments of the anterior cerebral arteries. Flow convergence at this junction creates complex shear stress patterns predisposing to aneurysm formation. Aneurysm domes project superiorly or posteriorly, with wall morphology influencing rupture propensity.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Aneurysm growth and rupture result from chronic endothelial injury, inflammatory cell infiltration, extracellular matrix degradation, and smooth muscle apoptosis. Laplace’s law explains why larger aneurysms, having greater radius, endure disproportionately higher wall tension, accelerating wall degeneration.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam.
On neurology and neurosurgery boards, questions on aneurysm rupture risk frequently test size thresholds (e.g., 7 mm vs. 10 mm), PHASES score components, and guideline-based management indications.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] - Atherosclerotic plaque in the internal carotid artery narrows the lumen, increasing ipsilateral stroke risk via hypoperfusion or artery-to-artery embolism.
• Symptomatic stenosis (TIA or stroke) ≥70% warrants prompt revascularization; 50–69% may also qualify in high-risk surgical candidates.
• Carotid artery stenting (CAS) is the percutaneous endovascular approach: balloon angioplasty, stent deployment, and distal embolic protection.
• Alternative definitive revascularization is carotid endarterectomy (CEA); antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants serve as adjunctive medical therapy, not primary interventional solutions in high-grade stenosis.

(≈110 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Carotid artery stenting is the sole endovascular revascularization technique among the options. The 2017 AHA/ASA Stroke Prevention Guidelines recommend revascularization for symptomatic patients with 70–99% stenosis (Class I, Level A) and endorse CAS in patients at high surgical risk or age <70 (Class I, Level B). The CREST trial (N Engl J Med 2010;363:11–23) randomized 2,502 patients to CEA versus CAS and found no significant difference in the composite endpoint of stroke, myocardial infarction, or death at 4 years (7.2% vs. 6.8%, p=0.51). Subgroup analyses demonstrated higher peri-procedural stroke with CAS in those >70 but lower myocardial infarction rates. Thus, CAS is evidence-based for selected symptomatic carotid stenosis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Carotid endarterectomy
• Incorrect: Open surgical removal of plaque, not an endovascular stenting procedure.
• Misconception: Equating any revascularization with stenting.
• Differentiator: CEA involves arteriotomy and plaque excision under general anesthesia.

B. Antiplatelet therapy
• Incorrect: Medical management reducing platelet aggregation; does not mechanically restore lumen diameter.
• Misconception: Assuming pharmacotherapy alone suffices for high-grade symptomatic stenosis.
• Differentiator: Adjunctive therapy; lacks immediate plaque debulking.

D. Anticoagulation
• Incorrect: Targets thrombin/fibrin pathways; not indicated for atherosclerotic carotid stenosis without other indications (e.g., atrial fibrillation).
• Misconception: Believing anticoagulants prevent artery-to-artery emboli in stenotic carotid disease.
• Differentiator: Does not revascularize stenotic segment and increases hemorrhagic risk.

Comparison Table

FeatureStenting (C)CEA (A)Antiplatelet (B)Anticoagulation (D)
ApproachPercutaneous endovascularOpen surgicalOral medicalOral medical
IndicationSymptomatic ≥70%, high-risk CEASymptomatic ≥70%, standard surgical riskSecondary prevention post-TIA/strokeNot indicated for atherosclerosis
Peri-procedural stroke risk4–6% (higher in >70 years)2–4%N/AN/A
Peri-procedural MI risk~1%3–5%N/AN/A
Major trialCREST: noninferior to CEA overallNASCET: benefit in ≥70% stenosisCHARISMA: reduced events post-strokeNo trial support in carotid athero.
Embolic protection device neededYesNoNoNo

Clinical Pearls

- Optimal timing: Perform CAS within 2 weeks of the index TIA or stroke for maximal benefit.
• Age considerations: Patients >70 years have higher periprocedural stroke rates with CAS; favor CEA in this group.
• Embolic protection: Use a distal filter or proximal occlusion device during CAS to reduce microembolic showers.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating antiplatelet or anticoagulant therapy with mechanical revascularization in high-grade stenosis.
2. Ignoring patient surgical risk and age when selecting CAS versus CEA, leading to increased complications.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. 2017 AHA/ASA Guideline on the Prevention of Stroke in Patients With Stroke and Transient Ischemic Attack
• Recommends revascularization (either CEA or CAS) for symptomatic stenosis 70–99% (Class I, Level A).
• Endorses CAS in high surgical-risk or age <70 (Class I, Level B).
2. CREST Trial (Carotid Revascularization Endarterectomy vs. Stenting Trial), 2010
• Randomized 2,502 patients; no difference in primary composite endpoint at 4 years (7.2% vs. 6.8%, p=0.51).
• Age >70 associated with higher stroke risk in CAS; myocardial infarction more common in CEA.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam.
Carotid revascularization strategies—indications, comparative risks of CEA vs CAS, and landmark trials (e.g., CREST)—are frequently tested topics, often in vignette format requiring selection of appropriate intervention based on patient age, symptomatic status, and surgical risk.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage classically presents with a sudden, severe headache (“thunderclap”). Compression of cranial nerve III (oculomotor nerve) by an aneurysm causes ipsilateral pupil dilation due to parasympathetic fiber involvement. Key concepts:
• Cranial nerve III carries parasympathetic fibers on its peripheral aspect; compressive lesions (e.g., aneurysms) injure these fibers first, producing a “blown” pupil.
• Posterior communicating artery aneurysms abut the oculomotor nerve in the interpeduncular cistern.
• Ischemic “microvascular” third-nerve palsies (e.g., diabetic) spare the pupil, differentiating them from compressive lesions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Posterior communicating artery (PCom) aneurysms account for ~25% of intracranial aneurysms and are the prototype for compressive third-nerve palsy with pupillary involvement. Parasympathetic fibers lie superficially; external compression by a saccular aneurysm produces an early dilated, nonreactive pupil preceding or accompanying extraocular muscle weakness. The 2015 AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Management of Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage recommend immediate non-contrast head CT followed by CT angiography in suspected aneurysmal SAH (Class I, Level B). Early identification and surgical or endovascular repair of PCom aneurysms with cranial nerve palsy is supported by multiple series demonstrating improved neurological outcomes when intervention occurs within 72 hours of onset.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Anterior communicating artery
• Why incorrect: AComm aneurysms typically compress the optic chiasm or cause frontal lobe symptoms; they seldom produce isolated CN III palsy.
• Misconception: Assuming all circle-of-Willis aneurysms affect CN III.
• Differentiation: AComm lesions cause visual field cuts (bitemporal hemianopsia), not pupillary dilation.

C. Anterior cerebral artery
• Why incorrect: ACA infarcts or aneurysms present with contralateral leg weakness, abulia, or frontal lobe signs, without oculomotor involvement.
• Misconception: Equating any anterior circulation lesion with third-nerve signs.
• Differentiation: ACA lesions spare cranial nerve III entirely.

D. Posterior cerebral artery
• Why incorrect: PCA lesions classically produce contralateral homonymous hemianopia (occipital lobe), not isolated oculomotor nerve palsy.
• Misconception: Overgeneralizing posterior circulation to include all cranial nerve presentations.
• Differentiation: PCA infarcts do not impinge on the oculomotor nerve in the interpeduncular cistern.

Comparison Table

FeaturePCom Aneurysm (Correct)AComm AneurysmACA LesionPCA Lesion
Vascular originPosterior communicating arteryAnterior communicating arteryAnterior cerebral arteryPosterior cerebral artery
Typical presentation“Blown” pupil, headache, possible ophthalmoplegiaVisual field defects, headacheContralateral leg weakness, frontal signsHomonymous hemianopia, visual cortex signs
Pupillary involvementYes (parasympathetic fiber compression)NoNoNo
PathomechanismCompressive saccular aneurysmMass effect near optic chiasmIschemic infarct or mass effectIschemic infarct in occipital lobe
Recommended imagingNon-contrast CT → CTA/DSANon-contrast CT → CT/MR for mass effectMRI/CT brain for infarctMRI/CT brain for infarct

Clinical Pearls

- “Rule of the pupil”: Compressive third-nerve palsies (aneurysm, tumor) involve the pupil; microvascular palsies (diabetes, hypertension) spare it.
• In suspected aneurysmal SAH with focal deficits, obtain non-contrast head CT immediately, then CTA before transfer to definitive care.
• Even in the absence of subarachnoid blood on CT after 6 hours, a dilated pupil mandates vascular imaging to exclude a PCom aneurysm.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misattributing pupil-sparing third-nerve palsy to an aneurysm rather than ischemia.
2. Overlooking CN III compression in posterior circulation aneurysms by focusing only on motor deficits.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association, “Guidelines for the Management of Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage,” 2015: Recommends emergent non-contrast CT followed by CTA in suspected aneurysmal SAH (Class I, Level B).
2. International Subarachnoid Aneurysm Trial (ISAT), 2002: Demonstrated superior functional outcomes at 1 year with endovascular coiling versus surgical clipping in ruptured aneurysms (Level A evidence), informing treatment of PCom aneurysms causing CN III palsy.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Localization of third-nerve palsy with pupillary involvement is a high-yield topic, frequently tested as an imaging vignette or classic “blown pupil” scenario to distinguish compressive from ischemic etiologies.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Atrial fibrillation (AF) leads to stasis in the left atrial appendage, promoting thrombus formation that can embolize to cerebral arteries. Cardioembolic strokes often involve the middle cerebral artery, producing contralateral hemiplegia. Secondary prevention in AF prioritizes systemic anticoagulation over antiplatelet therapy because anticoagulants target the coagulation cascade responsible for atrial thrombi. Key terms: CHA₂DS₂-VASc score to stratify stroke risk; vitamin K antagonists; novel oral anticoagulants (DOACs).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Warfarin reduces ischemic stroke risk by approximately 64% in AF (Hart et al., NEJM 2007). The 2019 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guideline (Class I, Level A) recommends oral anticoagulation for patients with non-valvular AF and CHA₂DS₂-VASc ≥2. DOACs (dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban) are now preferred in non-valvular AF, but warfarin remains standard for valvular AF or where DOACs are contraindicated (e.g., mechanical valves). Warfarin’s inhibition of vitamin K–dependent factors II, VII, IX, X prevents clot propagation in the left atrium. Its efficacy is supported by large RCTs and meta-analyses; therapeutic INR (2.0–3.0) balances stroke reduction against hemorrhagic risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. ASA
• ASA only inhibits platelet COX-1, decreasing stroke risk by ~20% versus the 64% reduction with warfarin.
• Misconception: platelet aggregation drives cardioembolic events; actually, fibrin-rich clots in AF need anticoagulation.

B. ASA & Plavix
• Dual antiplatelet therapy adds bleeding risk without significant incremental stroke prevention in AF.
• Misconception: “more antiplatelet equals better prevention” neglects pathophysiology of atrial thrombi.

D. LMWH
• Low–molecular-weight heparin is used acutely (e.g., bridging periprocedurally), not for long-term AF stroke prevention.
• Misconception: any anticoagulant suffices; LMWH is impractical for chronic management and lacks long-term efficacy data in AF.

Comparison Table

OptionMechanismStroke RR ReductionBleeding Risk
Warfarin [CORRECT]Vitamin K antagonist (II, VII, IX, X)~64% (Hart et al. 2007)Moderate (INR‐dependent)
ASACOX-1 inhibitor (platelet)~20% (EAFT 1993)Low
ASA & PlavixCOX-1 + P2Y₁₂ blockade~22% (MATCH 2004)High
LMWHAnti-Xa & anti-IIaNot established long-termVariable

Clinical Pearls

1. Calculate CHA₂DS₂-VASc: ≥2 in men mandates anticoagulation (Class I).
2. DOACs preferred in non-valvular AF due to lower intracranial hemorrhage (ARISTOTLE, ENGAGE-AF).
3. Delay anticoagulation 4–14 days post-stroke based on infarct size to reduce hemorrhagic transformation risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Choosing antiplatelets over anticoagulants in AF: underestimates cardioembolism risk.
2. Initiating anticoagulation immediately after large infarcts: ignores hemorrhagic conversion timing.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2019 Secondary Stroke Prevention Guideline: “Oral anticoagulation is recommended for patients with non-valvular AF and CHA₂DS₂-VASc ≥2” (Class I, LOE A).
2. ESC 2020 Atrial Fibrillation Guidelines: DOACs preferred over VKAs in non-valvular AF (Class I, LOE B); warfarin for mechanical valves (Class I, LOE C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

An embolus lodging in the left MCA territory disrupts perfusion to the precentral gyrus and internal capsule, causing contralateral (right-sided) upper motor neuron signs (hemiplegia, hyperreflexia).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

AF → atrial blood stasis → left atrial appendage thrombus → embolization to cerebral circulation → arterial occlusion → ischemic cascade (energy failure, excitotoxicity, cytotoxic edema).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT/MRI to exclude hemorrhage.
2. ECG/Holter monitoring for AF detection.
3. Echocardiography (TEE) to visualize atrial thrombus.
4. Initiate anticoagulation guided by stroke size and hemorrhage risk.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• CT perfusion delineates penumbra vs core infarct.
• DWI MRI detects ischemia within minutes, guiding early treatment.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Warfarin: initial dose 5 mg daily, adjust to INR 2.0–3.0; check INR biweekly until stable.
• DOAC alternatives: Apixaban 5 mg BID (reduce in renal impairment), Dabigatran 150 mg BID.
• Bridging with LMWH until INR therapeutic if high cardioembolic risk.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam.
Atrial fibrillation–related stroke prevention is frequently tested as vignettes requiring CHA₂DS₂-VASc calculation and guideline-based anticoagulation selection, often contrasting antiplatelet versus anticoagulant strategies.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Sickle cell disease leads to chronic hemolysis and vaso-occlusion, causing intimal hyperplasia and stenosis of large intracranial arteries (especially the distal internal carotid and middle cerebral arteries). According to fluid dynamics (Poiseuille’s law), luminal narrowing increases flow velocity. Transcranial Doppler (TCD) ultrasound noninvasively measures these velocities in the circle of Willis—elevated velocities (>200 cm/s) correlate strongly with future stroke risk in pediatric SCD. Early identification of high-risk velocities allows timely initiation of chronic transfusion therapy to prevent first strokes.

(Word count: 111)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The landmark STOP trial (Stroke Prevention Trial in Sickle Cell Anemia, NEJM 1998) randomized children with elevated TCD velocities (>200 cm/s) to chronic transfusion versus standard care. Transfused children had a 92% reduction in first stroke risk (incidence 0.9 vs. 10.7 strokes per 100 patient-years, p<0.0001). Subsequent STOP II (Blood 2005) supported discontinuation only after sustained normal velocities on transfusion. Current NHLBI (2014) and ASH (2020) guidelines recommend annual TCD screening in children 2–16 years with HbSS/Sβ^0 thalassemia. No comparable prospective data validate CTA, MRI, or carotid duplex for primary stroke risk stratification in asymptomatic SCD.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. CT Angiography (CTA)
• CTA depicts luminal stenosis and collateral formation but lacks validated velocity thresholds for stroke risk prediction in SCD.
• Involves ionizing radiation and iodinated contrast; not suitable for serial screening.

C. MRI
• Brain MRI (including diffusion-weighted imaging) identifies existing silent infarcts but does not quantify real-time hemodynamic stress or predict incident stroke risk.
• Silent infarcts on MRI do increase long-term risk but require earlier velocity screening for prevention.

D. Carotid ultrasound
• Assesses extracranial common and internal carotid arteries; most SCD vasculopathy involves intracranial vessels.
• Velocities in the proximal cervical carotid do not correlate with intracranial stenosis severity in this population.

Comparison Table

FeatureTranscranial DopplerCT AngiographyMRI BrainCarotid Ultrasound
Vessels assessedIntracranial (MCA, ICA)Extra- & intracranialParenchyma; vessel imaging limitedExtracranial carotids
Predictive valueHigh; STOP trial validatedUnvalidated for risk screeningIdentifies silent infarcts onlyPoor for intracranial stenosis
Radiation/contrastNoneYesNoNone
Screening frequencyAnnual (ages 2–16)Not recommendedAs clinically indicatedNot recommended
NoninvasiveYesPartially invasive (contrast)YesYes

Clinical Pearls

• Annual TCD screening from ages 2 to 16 in HbSS/Sβ^0 thalassemia reduces first-stroke risk by >90%.
• A TCD time-averaged mean velocity ≥200 cm/s in the MCA or distal ICA defines high risk.
• Chronic transfusion therapy aiming for HbS <30% reverses elevated velocities and is the standard preventive measure.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying on MRI to “rule out” future stroke: MRI detects past silent infarcts but cannot predict hemodynamic stress or imminent risk.
2. Using extracranial carotid duplex as a proxy for intracranial stenosis: SCD vasculopathy predominantly affects distal intracranial vessels, undetected by cervical ultrasound.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. NHLBI Evidence-Based Management of Sickle Cell Disease (2014):
• Recommendation: Annual TCD screening for children 2–16 years with HbSS or Sβ^0 thalassemia (Grade A).
2. American Society of Hematology Guidelines (2020):
• Reaffirm use of TCD velocities >200 cm/s to initiate chronic transfusion for primary stroke prevention (Strong recommendation, moderate-quality evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Polymerization of deoxygenated HbS distorts red cells, promoting hemolysis and endothelial dysfunction. Repetitive injury induces smooth muscle proliferation in intracranial arteries, leading to concentric stenosis. Narrowing elevates flow velocity; persistent high shear stress predisposes to endothelial damage and thrombotic stroke.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Stroke risk screening in pediatric sickle cell disease is frequently tested as a single-best-answer item, often referencing the STOP trial and annual TCD recommendations.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] Acute ischemic stroke results from sudden occlusion of cerebral arteries, leading to time-dependent neuronal injury. Thrombolytic therapy with intravenous alteplase (rtPA) is indicated within a 4.5-hour window to dissolve thrombi and restore perfusion. Candidate selection relies on neuroanatomical localization of deficits (NIHSS scoring) and exclusion of hemorrhagic or high-risk features via imaging and lab tests. Absolute contraindications include platelet count below 100 000/µL due to elevated hemorrhagic transformation risk, while relative contraindications—like minor non-disabling deficits—are weighed case-by-case. Recognizing these parameters ensures maximal benefit with minimized intracranial hemorrhage. Familiarity with AHA/ASA criteria and contraindication classifications is essential for safe community-based stroke management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer (platelet count of 45,000) represents an absolute contraindication to IV alteplase per current guidelines. The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Powers et al., Stroke 2018) assign a Class III (harm) recommendation against rtPA if platelet count <100 000/µL; thrombocytopenia sharply elevates risk of symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage (sICH). In pooled analyses (Hacke et al., Lancet Neurol 2008), patients with thrombocytopenia had a two- to threefold increase in sICH rates. Although the patient presented within the appropriate 3.5-hour window and had disabling deficits (NIHSS >5), administering rtPA in the context of severe thrombocytopenia directly violated protocol and contributed to hemorrhagic transformation. Other factors—such as time window compliance (3.5 h <4.5 h) and disabling deficits—were appropriate.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Low deficit
• Why incorrect: The patient had severe dysarthria and flaccid weakness, consistent with an NIHSS >5, indicating disabling deficit.
• Misconception: Equating all motor deficits as “minor” regardless of functional impact.
• Differentiator: NIHSS threshold >5 qualifies as disabling, justifying rtPA absent other contraindications.

B. Out of tPA window
• Why incorrect: He presented within 3.5 hours (<4.5 hours) of symptom onset, fitting the approved time frame.
• Misconception: Confusing the strict 3-hour window with the extended 4.5-hour window.
• Differentiator: Extended window up to 4.5 hours is evidence-based (ECASS III).

D. Recent major surgery
• Why incorrect: No history of recent surgery was documented.
• Misconception: Assuming any severe stroke patient recently underwent surgery.
• Differentiator: Recent (past 14 days) intracranial or intraspinal surgery would contraindicate, but not present here.

Comparison Table

FeaturePlatelet <100 000/µL (C)Low NIHSS Deficit (A)>4.5 h Window (B)Recent Surgery (D)
Contraindication TypeAbsolute (Class III, Harm)RelativeN/A within 4.5 hAbsolute if intracranial
Guideline ReferenceAHA/ASA 2018AHA/ASA 2018ECASS IIIAHA/ASA 2018
Risk of sICHHigh (>2× baseline)Low when truly minorN/A if treated in windowHigh if intracranial surgery

Clinical Pearls

- Always verify laboratory values (platelets, INR) before rtPA; automated stroke protocols may skip manual review under time pressure.
• Disabling deficits (NIHSS >5) justify rtPA even if motor function is the primary issue; document clearly.
• Extended window to 4.5 hours (ECASS III) applies only in selected patients without additional risk factors.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Ignoring thrombocytopenia: Students often overlook platelet count as a contraindication, focusing solely on imaging.
• Misjudging deficit severity: Motor weakness may seem “minor” if improving, but functional impairment dictates rtPA eligibility.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines (Powers et al.): Platelet count <100 000/µL is a Class III (Harm), Level B–R contraindication to IV alteplase.
• European Stroke Organisation 2021 Guidelines: Reinforce contraindication for thrombocytopenia <100 000/µL (Grade 1C) and endorse ECASS III window extension.
• EXTEND Trial (Ma et al., NEJM 2019): Supports perfusion-based selection to extend window up to 9 hours, but does not override absolute lab contraindications.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2022 exam. Students are frequently tested on rtPA inclusion/exclusion criteria, especially laboratory-based contraindications and extended time windows.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Moyamoya syndrome involves progressive stenosis of the distal internal carotid arteries (ICAs) and their proximal branches, leading to development of fragile collateral networks (“moyamoya” vessels). Key concepts:
• Hemodynamic insufficiency in MCA/ACA territories predisposes to recurrent ischemic events.
• Compensatory collaterals are insufficient under stress and prone to thrombosis or rupture.
• Definitive management aims to augment cerebral blood flow via surgical revascularization rather than solely pharmacologic measures.
Understanding the difference between symptomatic hemodynamic failure and embolic stroke guides the choice of therapy in Moyamoya.
(120 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Revascularization surgery—direct bypass (superficial temporal artery–middle cerebral artery anastomosis) or indirect techniques (encephaloduroarteriosynangiosis)—directly restores perfusion, alleviating hemodynamic insufficiency. The 2012 AHA/ASA scientific statement on Moyamoya (Class I, Level B) endorses revascularization in symptomatic patients to reduce recurrent ischemia. A meta-analysis (Stroke 2018;49:22–30) of 1,200 adult cases showed annual stroke recurrence rates drop from ~10% with medical therapy alone to <2% post-bypass. Japanese guidelines (Society for Neurovascular Diseases 2021) similarly prioritize direct bypass in adults for durable flow augmentation. Medical therapies alone fail to address progressive stenosis; antiplatelets or anticoagulants carry limited efficacy and increased hemorrhagic risk in fragile collaterals.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Chronic transfusion
• Reason incorrect: Indicated in sickle cell–related Moyamoya to reduce HbS, not standard Moyamoya syndrome.
• Misconception: Confusing hemoglobinopathy-driven stroke prevention with angiopathy-driven pathology.
• Differentiator: Transfusion targets rheology, not luminal stenosis or collateral insufficiency.

B. Aspirin and clopidogrel
• Reason incorrect: Dual antiplatelet therapy offers minimal hemodynamic benefit and increases hemorrhage risk in fragile collaterals.
• Misconception: “More antiplatelet agents = fewer strokes” ignores pathophysiology of flow-limited ischemia.
• Differentiator: Antiplatelets do not reverse progressive vascular narrowing; surgery does.

D. Anticoagulation with warfarin
• Reason incorrect: Heightens intracranial bleeding risk without improving perfusion through stenotic segments.
• Misconception: Belief that thrombosis in collateral vessels is primary driver, whereas hemodynamic failure predominates.
• Differentiator: Warfarin does not augment cerebral blood flow; bypass does.

Comparison Table

OptionMechanismTargetEvidence LevelKey Limitation
Chronic transfusionReduces HbS, improves rheologyHematologic in sickle cell diseaseNo studies in Moyamoya syndromeDoes not address arterial stenosis
Aspirin + clopidogrelInhibits platelet aggregationPlatelet-mediated thrombosisExpert opinion, low-level dataNo effect on hemodynamics; ↑ hemorrhage risk
Revascularization surgeryDirect/indirect bypass augments CBFHemodynamic insufficiency in MCA/ACAClass I, Level B (AHA/ASA 2012)Surgical risks, needs specialized centers
Anticoagulation with warfarinInhibits vitamin K–dependent factorsThrombus preventionNo trials in Moyamoya↑ Intracranial bleeding; no perfusion benefit

Clinical Pearls

- Direct STA-MCA bypass provides immediate flow improvement; indirect methods (e.g., EDAS) mature over months.
• In adults, direct bypass yields better hemodynamic relief; in pediatric patients, indirect techniques are often preferred due to vessel size.
• Antiplatelet monotherapy (e.g., low-dose aspirin) may be used preoperatively or in mild cases but is not definitive.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing dual antiplatelet therapy long-term, overlooking hemorrhagic risk in moyamoya collaterals.
2. Equating medical stroke prevention strategies in sickle cell disease (chronic transfusion) with Moyamoya syndrome.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Scientific Statement on Moyamoya Disease and Moyamoya Syndrome (Circulation 2012): Class I, Level B recommendation for surgical revascularization in symptomatic ischemic Moyamoya.
• Japanese Guidelines for the Management of Moyamoya Disease (Neurovascular Diseases Soc. 2021): Strong recommendation for direct STA-MCA bypass in adults to reduce ischemic events (Level of Evidence B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Progressive stenosis of the distal ICA and proximal MCA/ACA branches leads to recruitment of perforator collaterals (lenticulostriate arteries) and transdural pial vessels. STA-MCA bypass creates a new extracranial–intracranial conduit, restoring flow to the MCA territory.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Intimal hyperplasia and smooth muscle proliferation narrow the distal ICA lumen. Compensatory angiogenesis forms fragile moyamoya vessels prone to thrombosis. Chronically reduced perfusion triggers ischemia, especially in watershed zones.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Digital subtraction angiography: “puff of smoke” appearance from fine basal collaterals.
• SPECT/PET perfusion: diminished cerebrovascular reserve; steal phenomena during acetazolamide challenge.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. Moyamoya management frequently appears as single-best-answer items testing the superiority of surgical revascularization over medical therapies for secondary stroke prevention.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Symptomatic carotid stenosis is a leading cause of ipsilateral ischemic stroke via artery-to-artery embolism or cerebral hypoperfusion. Key concepts:
1. Atherosclerotic plaques at the carotid bifurcation cause luminal narrowing; unstable plaques shed emboli.
2. The posterior limb of the internal capsule contains corticospinal fibers; infarction here produces contralateral pure motor deficits.
3. Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) physically removes plaque, restoring flow and reducing recurrent stroke risk in patients with ≥50% symptomatic stenosis (NASCET criteria).

Evidence-Based Analysis

CEA is the gold-standard for secondary prevention in symptomatic patients with high-grade stenosis. The NASCET trial (1991) demonstrated a 17% absolute risk reduction in ipsilateral stroke at 2 years for patients with 70–99% stenosis undergoing CEA versus medical therapy. Current 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines recommend CEA within 14 days of a qualifying event for symptomatic stenosis ≥70% (Class I, Level A) and consider it for 50–69% (Class I, Level B). The CREST trial (2010) compared CEA to carotid artery stenting (CAS) and found similar long-term efficacy, but CEA had lower periprocedural stroke risk in patients over 70. Early surgery maximizes benefit: delay beyond two weeks attenuates stroke‐risk reduction.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Medical management
• Why incorrect: Alone, antiplatelet and statin therapy do not achieve the <2% annual stroke rate seen after CEA in high-grade symptomatic stenosis.
• Misconception: Belief that optimal medical therapy suffices; underestimates surgical benefit in symptomatic ≥70% stenosis.
• Differentiator: Medical therapy is first line in asymptomatic or <50% stenosis, but insufficient for symptomatic high-grade lesions.

B. ICA Stenting
• Why incorrect: CAS carries higher periprocedural stroke risk in older patients and lacks long-term superiority over CEA in guidelines for symptomatic lesions.
• Misconception: Equating endovascular with surgical risk profiles; overlooks age-related embolic risk.
• Differentiator: CAS is reserved for high surgical‐risk anatomy or comorbidities prohibiting CEA.

D. Craniotomy
• Why incorrect: No intracranial hemorrhage or mass effect; craniotomy offers no benefit in pure ischemic capsular infarct.
• Misconception: Confusing surgical decompression for hemorrhagic stroke with management of ischemia.
• Differentiator: Decompressive craniotomy indicated only in malignant middle cerebral artery infarction with raised intracranial pressure, not lacunar‐type capsular strokes.

Comparison Table

OptionIndicationEfficacy (2-yr ipsilateral stroke)RisksTiming
A. Medical managementAll patients, especially asymptomatic~26% recurrence in high-gradeLow procedural risk; higher strokeImmediate; lifelong
B. ICA StentingSymptomatic if high surgical riskComparable long-term; ↑periprocedural stroke in ≥70 yrsEmbolic complications, hyperperfusionPrefer ≤2 weeks if chosen
C. ICA endarterectomySymptomatic ≥50% stenosis9% recurrence (CEA) vs 26% (medical)Cranial nerve injury, MI, bleedingOptimal ≤14 days post-stroke
D. CraniotomyIntracerebral hemorrhage, edemaN/A for ischemic strokeInfection, hemorrhage, anesthesia riskNot indicated in lacunar stroke

Clinical Pearls

1. Perform CEA within 2 weeks of a symptomatic event; every week of delay reduces relative benefit by ~1%.
2. NASCET measurement uses the distal internal carotid diameter as reference—beware of using common carotid reference.
3. In patients >80 years, CEA remains preferred over CAS due to lower stroke risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming asymptomatic and symptomatic carotid stenosis are managed identically—symptomatic >70% always benefits from CEA.
• Delaying intervention beyond two weeks thinking medical stabilization alone is adequate reduces the protective effect of CEA.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 (Powers et al.): Class I recommendation for CEA in symptomatic patients with 70–99% stenosis within 14 days (Level A evidence).
2. ESVS 2017 (Eur J Vasc Endovasc Surg): Recommends CEA over CAS for symptomatic stenosis ≥50% in average-risk patients (Grade A, Level 1).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. Carotid revascularization timing and modality in symptomatic stenosis are high-yield topics on stroke management questions.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] - Cardioembolic stroke: Atrial fibrillation causes stasis in the left atrium, predisposing to thrombus formation and embolization to the cerebral circulation.
• Post-stroke anticoagulation timing: Balancing hemorrhagic conversion risk against recurrent embolism risk; larger infarcts require delayed initiation.
• Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) vs. warfarin: DOACs have more predictable pharmacokinetics, lower intracranial hemorrhage rates, and no routine INR monitoring.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dabigatran is correct because in nonvalvular AFib with ischemic stroke, DOACs reduce recurrent stroke and intracranial hemorrhage compared to warfarin (RE-LY trial, Connolly 2009). The 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines recommend initiating anticoagulation 4–14 days after large infarct (Class IIa, Level B-R). Dabigatran’s direct thrombin inhibition offers rapid onset (half-life ~12–17 hours) and standardized dosing (150 mg BID). Aspirin or DAPT alone inadequately prevent cardioembolic strokes. Warfarin’s variable INR and higher ICH risk render it second-line in nonvalvular AF.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Aspirin
• Incorrect: Insufficient for stroke prevention in AF (annual stroke risk reduction ~20% vs. ~60% with anticoagulation).
• Misconception: “All strokes benefit equally from aspirin.”
• Differentiator: Aspirin acts on platelets, not the coagulation cascade driving cardioembolism.

B. Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT)
• Incorrect: Indicated in minor non-cardioembolic stroke/TIA (CHANCE/POINT trials), not in AFib; increases bleeding without AF stroke benefit.
• Misconception: “More antithrombotic agents always equals better protection.”
• Differentiator: DAPT targets platelet aggregation pathways, not atrial thrombi.

D. Warfarin
• Incorrect: Although effective, warfarin has slower onset, variable response, and higher intracranial hemorrhage risk than DOACs in nonvalvular AF (meta-analysis by Ruff et al., 2014).
• Misconception: “Vitamin K antagonists are the gold standard for all AF patients.”
• Differentiator: Requires frequent INR monitoring; DOACs preferred first-line per current guidelines.

Comparison Table

FeatureAspirinDAPT (ASA + Clop)DabigatranWarfarin
MechanismCOX-1 inhibitionCOX-1 + P2Y₁₂ inhibitionDirect thrombin (IIa) inhibitorVitamin K epoxide reductase inhibitor
Indication in AF strokeNoNoYesYes, if DOAC contraindicated
Onset of action1 hour1–2 hours~2 hours48–72 hours
MonitoringNoneNoneRenal functionINR
Intracranial bleed riskLowestLow–moderateLowModerate–high
Post-large stroke timingImmediateImmediate6–14 days6–14 days

Clinical Pearls

- Start DOACs 1–3 days after minor stroke, 4–14 days after moderate-to-large infarcts, guided by NIHSS and imaging.
• Dabigatran has a specific reversal agent (idarucizumab), aiding management if hemorrhagic conversion occurs.
• In renal impairment (CrCl <30 mL/min), dose-adjust dabigatran or choose alternative DOAC per labeling.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Initiating full-dose anticoagulation too early in a large infarct, risking hemorrhagic transformation.
2. Equating antiplatelet efficacy with anticoagulant efficacy in AF-related strokes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 (Powers et al.): For nonvalvular AF and large infarct, initiate anticoagulation 4–14 days post-event (Class IIa, Level B-R).
• ESC 2019 AF Guidelines: Recommend DOAC over VKA in nonvalvular AF patients (Class I, Level A) due to lower intracranial hemorrhage.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam.
Topics on anticoagulation timing in cardioembolic stroke recur frequently, often by presenting infarct size and asking when and which agent to start.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] - Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) often results from hypertension‐induced small vessel rupture (Charcot–Bouchard aneurysms), causing focal deficits (e.g., contralateral weakness, dysarthria).
• Elevated blood pressure after ICH is strongly linked to hematoma expansion and worse outcomes; controlled reduction to a target systolic blood pressure (SBP) of ≈140 mm Hg reduces secondary injury.
• Intravenous antihypertensives with rapid onset/offset (labetalol, nicardipine) allow tight titration; labetalol’s combined α/β blockade provides predictable BP lowering without precipitous drops.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Labetalol is the recommended first‐line agent for acute BP control in ICH. The 2022 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Spontaneous ICH (Class I, Level A) endorse lowering SBP to 140 mm Hg in patients presenting with SBP 150–220 mm Hg. This strategy is supported by the INTERACT2 trial (Lancet 2013), which demonstrated an ordinal improvement in functional outcomes (OR 0.87; 95% CI 0.77–1.00; p=0.04) with intensive SBP lowering (<140 mm Hg) versus standard (<180 mm Hg). ATACH-2 (NEJM 2016) compared the same targets and found no significant difference in death or disability but noted increased renal adverse events in the intensive group. Labetalol’s rapid onset (2–5 min), short half‐life (5.5 hr), and easy titratability minimize risks of cerebral hypoperfusion. In contrast, recombinant factor VIIa (rFVIIa) failed to improve outcomes and increased thromboembolic events in the FAST trial (NEJM 2005). Minimally invasive surgical evacuation (MISTIE III, Stroke 2021) did not yield functional benefit in deep ICH. Supportive care without active BP management leaves the key modifiable risk of hematoma expansion unaddressed.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Factor VII infusion
• Incorrect: rFVIIa accelerates clotting but did not reduce mortality or severe disability (FAST trial) and increased arterial thromboembolic events (MI, ischemic stroke).
• Misconception: Belief that boosting coagulation always limits hemorrhage; however, systemic prothrombotic risk outweighs benefit in spontaneous ICH.

C. Referral for neurosurgery for minimally invasive evacuation
• Incorrect: STICH II and MISTIE III trials showed no overall functional advantage for surgical evacuation in deep supratentorial hemorrhages without mass effect or clinical deterioration.
• Misconception: All ICHs benefit from early surgery; in fact, only select cerebellar hemorrhages (>3 cm) or lobar clots with impending herniation meet surgical criteria.

D. Supportive care with monitoring in an intensive care unit
• Incorrect: Passive monitoring neglects active reduction of SBP, leaving patient at high risk for hematoma expansion during the critical early period.
• Misconception: Observation alone is sufficient; guidelines mandate early BP control to improve outcomes.

Comparison Table

InterventionMechanismKey EvidenceIndicationNotes
Labetalol [CORRECT]Combined α/β-blockade to lower BPAHA/ASA ICH Guidelines 2022 (Class I, LOE A); INTERACT2 improved functional outcomesAcute SBP 150–220 mm HgRapid onset/offset; titratable; minimal rebound
Recombinant Factor VIIa (rFVIIa)Procoagulant promoting thrombin burstFAST trial: no functional benefit; ↑ thromboembolic eventsNot recommendedHigh risk of MI, ischemic stroke
Minimally invasive surgical evacuationMechanical clot removalMISTIE III: no significant benefit in functional outcomeSelect superficial lobar hemorrhage onlyInvestigational; risk of rebleeding
Supportive care onlyObservation and standard monitoringNo trials of BP control = worse hematoma expansionNo active BP reductionFails to address modifiable risk of expansion

Clinical Pearls

- Aim for SBP ≈140 mm Hg within the first hour to reduce hematoma growth; avoid rapid reductions >60 mm Hg to maintain cerebral perfusion.
• Labetalol (10–20 mg IV bolus, repeat q10 min; infusion 1–2 mg/min) is often preferred; nicardipine infusion is an alternative in reactive airway disease.
• Always verify anticoagulation status; reverse warfarin/DOACs promptly to minimize bleeding.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Overly aggressive BP lowering (<110 mm Hg) can precipitate cerebral ischemia, especially in chronic hypertensive patients with impaired autoregulation.
• Misinterpreting rFVIIa’s hemostatic properties as proven therapy; robust trials failed to show functional benefit and highlighted thrombotic risks.
• Automatic referral for neurosurgery without indications (e.g., superficial lobar hemorrhage >30 mL with deterioration or cerebellar hemorrhage >3 cm) leads to unnecessary procedures.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association/American Stroke Association Guidelines, 2022: Recommend acute lowering of SBP to 140 mm Hg in spontaneous ICH patients with SBP 150–220 mm Hg (Class I, LOE A).
• ATACH-2 Trial (NEJM 2016): Targeting SBP <140 mm Hg versus <180 mm Hg did not reduce death/disability; intensive lowering increased renal adverse events (Randomized Controlled Trial, Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Right basal ganglia/internal capsule hemorrhage disrupts corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts, producing contralateral (left-sided) motor weakness and dysarthria.
• Mass effect near the internal capsule can rapidly worsen deficits and increase intracranial pressure.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Chronic hypertension causes lipohyalinosis and microaneurysm formation in small perforating arteries; rupture leads to parenchymal bleeding.
• Elevated systemic BP post-ICH increases transmural pressure in adjacent vessels, promoting hematoma expansion and perihematomal edema.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Immediate noncontrast head CT to confirm ICH and assess location/volume.
2. Airway assessment (intubate if GCS <8 or compromised).
3. Check coagulation profile; reverse anticoagulants as needed.
4. Initiate IV antihypertensive to lower SBP to ≈140 mm Hg.
5. Neurosurgical consultation for select cases (e.g., cerebellar ICH >3 cm, lobar >30 mL with deterioration).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Acute hemorrhage appears hyperdense on noncontrast CT; absence of surrounding hypodensity distinguishes from edema.
• CT angiography “spot sign” (contrast extravasation) predicts active bleeding and hematoma growth.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Labetalol: Nonselective β-blocker with α1-blockade; IV bolus 10–20 mg over 1–2 min (repeat q10 min), infusion 1–2 mg/min; avoid in severe asthma, heart block.
• Nicardipine: Dihydropyridine Ca²⁺-channel blocker; start at 5 mg/hr, increase by 2.5 mg/hr every 5–15 min (max 15 mg/hr); longer half-life, requires careful monitoring.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Management of acute ICH and BP targets is frequently tested in stroke modules, often as case-based scenarios requiring selection of the first-line antihypertensive agent.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) are brief episodes of focal neurologic dysfunction without permanent infarction.
1. Vascular territories: The internal carotid artery (ICA) supplies anterior circulation; the vertebral–basilar system supplies posterior territories; the circle of Willis provides collateral flow.
2. Hemodynamic TIAs: Hypotension or “steal” phenomena can transiently reduce perfusion below ischemic threshold, often in watershed zones.
3. Dialysis‐related risks: Ultrafiltration during hemodialysis can precipitate hypotension and exacerbate steal phenomena, especially if arterial inflow (e.g., subclavian artery) is compromised.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CT angiography (CTA) of the head and neck is the preferred initial vascular imaging in acute TIA. The 2018 AHA/ASA Stroke Guidelines (Class I, Level A) recommend noninvasive angiography—CTA or MRA—within 24 hours to assess for stenosis, occlusion, and collateral flow. CTA provides high‐resolution images of extracranial and intracranial vessels, detects subclavian or proximal carotid lesions causing steal, and delineates circle of Willis anatomy. In ESRD patients, iodinated contrast is acceptable since dialysis will clear contrast post‐scan. CTA is faster and more widely available than MRA, and superior to ultrasound for visualizing the proximal subclavian and vertebral arteries where steal lesions occur.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRI brain
• MRI delineates parenchymal infarcts and diffusion‐weighted abnormalities but does not reliably assess extracranial vessel stenosis or steal physiology.
• Misconception: MRI “rules out stroke,” but it won’t identify underlying vascular lesions needing acute intervention.

C. Transcranial Doppler ultrasound
• TCD can detect flow velocity changes and retrograde vertebral flow (suggesting steal) but is operator‐dependent and limited in visualizing proximal subclavian or carotid origins.
• Key difference: lacks anatomic detail; serves as adjunct, not definitive.

D. Echocardiogram
• Transthoracic or transesophageal echo evaluates cardioembolic sources (e.g., PFO, thrombus) but is less relevant when TIAs are strictly hemodialysis‐related and vascular imaging is paramount.
• Confusion arises from routine TIA workup including echo but here temporal relation to dialysis indicates local vascular pathology.

Comparison Table

ModalityPrimary UseStrengthLimitation
CT angiographyVascular anatomy head & neckRapid, high‐resolution depiction of stenoses, occlusions, collateral/steal lesionsRadiation, iodinated contrast (cleared by HD)
MRI brainParenchymal infarction detectionExcellent soft‐tissue contrastDoes not assess extracranial vessels
Transcranial Doppler ultrasoundCerebral blood flow velocitiesNoninvasive, bedside, no contrastOperator‐dependent, poor proximal vessel visualization
EchocardiogramCardioembolic source evaluationDetects intracardiac thrombi, shuntsNo assessment of head/neck arteries

Clinical Pearls

- In acute TIA, obtain vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) within 24 hours to guide management (AHA/ASA Class I).
• Hemodialysis‐induced hypotension can trigger watershed or steal TIAs; suspect subclavian steal in ipsilateral fistula access.
• ESRD patients tolerate iodinated contrast for CTA as hemodialysis removes excess contrast agent.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying solely on carotid duplex scanning can miss proximal subclavian or vertebral artery lesions causing steal phenomena.
2. Ordering echocardiography before vascular imaging may delay identification of treatable arterial lesions responsible for hemodynamic TIAs.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Patients with Acute Ischemic Stroke and TIA: recommend head and neck vascular imaging with CTA/MRA within 24 hours of TIA (Class I, Level A).
• 2021 AHA/ASA Secondary Prevention of Stroke Guidelines: endorse CTA to detect high‐risk stenoses and guide revascularization (Class I, Level B-R).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The subclavian artery gives rise to the vertebral artery; proximal subclavian stenosis or high‐flow AV fistula can reverse vertebral flow, diverting blood away from the posterior and potentially compromising anterior circulation via collateral pathways in the circle of Willis.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

During hemodialysis, ultrafiltration causes intravascular volume depletion and hypotension; in the presence of arterial stenosis or steal, cerebral perfusion pressure falls below the ischemic threshold in watershed territories or in regions dependent on collateral flow.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm TIA clinically and obtain noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
2. Perform rapid vascular imaging of head and neck (CTA preferred).
3. Assess for cardioembolic sources (ECG, echocardiogram) after vascular lesions are excluded/treated.
4. Initiate antiplatelet therapy and risk factor modification.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CTA can quantify stenosis percentage, detect ulcerated plaques, and visualize extracranial-intracranial collaterals.
• MRA may overestimate stenosis in calcified vessels; TCD is adjunctive for monitoring flow but not definitive.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam. Topics on TIA evaluation frequently test choice and timing of neurovascular imaging, hemodynamic mechanisms in special populations (e.g., dialysis), and modality‐specific strengths/limitations.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Hyponatremia after SAH arises primarily from cerebral salt wasting (CSW) or, less commonly, SIADH.
• CSW: natriuresis with volume depletion → hypovolemic hyponatremia.
• SIADH: euvolemic hyponatremia via inappropriate ADH release.
• Management diverges: CSW requires volume/sodium repletion; SIADH requires fluid restriction.
In SAH patients, CSW predominates, so isotonic IV fluids are first-line to restore intravascular volume and serum sodium (≤135 mEq/L).

(Word count: 88)

Evidence-Based Analysis

IV isotonic fluid administration addresses the volume depletion and sodium loss of CSW, the most frequent cause of hyponatremia in SAH (up to 40%). Endorsed by the 2014 European Hyponatraemia Guideline (Spasovski et al., Grade 1C) and the AHA 2012 SAH guidelines, isotonic saline stabilizes hemodynamics and corrects sodium gradually, reducing risk of osmotic demyelination. Hypertonic saline (3%) is reserved for severe (<120 mEq/L) or symptomatic cases (seizures, altered consciousness). Fluid restriction, indicated in SIADH, would worsen CSW. Diuretics exacerbate volume loss and natriuresis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Restrict fluids
  – Incorrect for CSW; worsens hypovolemia.
  – Reflects SIADH management misconception—distinguish by volume status and urinary sodium.
C. Administer hypertonic saline
  – Only for severe (<120 mEq/L) or acute symptomatic hyponatremia.
  – Overly aggressive in mild-to-moderate CSW; risk osmotic demyelination if sodium rises >8–10 mEq/24 h.
D. Start diuretics
  – Counterproductive: increases natriuresis and volume depletion in CSW.
  – Diuretics are used for volume overload in SIADH but contraindicated in hypovolemia.

Comparison Table

FeatureIV Isotonic Fluid (CSW)Fluid Restriction (SIADH)Hypertonic SalineDiuretics (furosemide)
IndicationHypovolemic hyponatremiaEuvolemic hyponatremiaSevere/symptomatic <120 mEq/LVolume overload states
Effect on Volume StatusRestores intravascularReduces free waterRaises serum Na rapidlyIncreases natriuresis/volume loss
RiskRare overcorrection if too rapidWorsens CSW hypovolemiaOsmotic demyelination if overcorrectedExacerbates CSW
Evidence Grade1C (Spasovski 2014)1C1C—

Clinical Pearls

• In SAH, monitor serum sodium daily for ≥2 weeks: peak hyponatremia risk is days 4–6 post-bleed.
• Fludrocortisone (0.1–0.4 mg/day) can augment sodium repletion in refractory CSW.
• Avoid rapid correction: target ∆Na ≤8 mEq/L per 24 h to prevent central pontine myelinolysis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Treating all SAH-associated hyponatremia as SIADH and fluid restricting, leading to hypotension and worsened cerebral perfusion.
2. Reflexively using hypertonic saline for any hyponatremia without assessing volume status or symptom severity.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Spasovski et al., European Hyponatraemia Guideline 2014: “Isotonic saline first-line in hypovolemic hyponatremia (Grade 1C).”
2. American Heart Association 2012 SAH Guidelines: Recommend volume and sodium repletion in CSW; hypertonic saline only for severe/symptomatic cases (Class IIa, Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam.
SAH-associated hyponatremia management frequently tests CSW vs SIADH differentiation, requiring knowledge of volume status assessment and appropriate fluid therapy.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Spinal vascular lesions disrupt normal cord perfusion and present variably depending on flow dynamics.
• The spinal cord’s venous network drains via radicular veins into epidural plexuses; arteriovenous shunts elevate venous pressure, leading to congestive ischemia.
• Dural arteriovenous fistulae (DAVFs) are acquired lesions where a dural artery connects directly to a medullary vein, causing progressive, stepwise myelopathy with diurnal or activity-related fluctuations.
• In contrast, high‐flow AVMs often present acutely with hemorrhage, cavernomas with focal intramedullary hemorrhage, and fibrocartilaginous embolism with sudden non-fluctuating infarction. (123 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Spinal DAVFs are the most common spinal vascular malformation in older males (mean age ~60), presenting with insidious, fluctuating paraparesis and sensory changes (Thron et al., Neurosurgery 1999). Venous hypertension impairs cord perfusion and causes reversible early symptoms that worsen if untreated. MRI typically shows T2 hyperintensity in the cord (conus to thoracic levels) with serpiginous perimedullary flow voids. Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is gold standard for localization. Current SNIS guidelines (2022) recommend endovascular embolization as first-line when pedicle anatomy allows (Class I, Level B); microsurgical disconnection is advised after failed embolization (Class I, Level C).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. AVM
• Why incorrect: Spinal arteriovenous malformations are intramedullary, high-flow lesions often presenting with acute hemorrhage or progressive myelopathy without the characteristic fluctuations of venous congestion.
• Misconception: Equating all spinal vascular lesions with DAVF.
• Differentiator: AVMs demonstrate a nidus on angiography and less diurnal variability.

B. Cavernoma
• Why incorrect: Intramedullary cavernous malformations bleed intermittently, causing stepwise or acute deficits, not chronic fluctuating weakness.
• Misconception: Assuming any vascular malformation causes fluctuation.
• Differentiator: Cavernomas lack perimedullary flow voids; MRI “popcorn” appearance with hemosiderin rim.

D. Fibrocartilaginous embolism
• Why incorrect: Causes sudden, non-fluctuating spinal cord infarction after Valsalva or minor trauma.
• Misconception: Attributing any myelopathy to embolic phenomena.
• Differentiator: Abrupt onset, diffusion-weighted MRI restriction, no flow voids.

Comparison Table

FeatureDAVF (Correct)Spinal AVM (A)Cavernoma (B)FCE (D)
Age/Sex~60 MYounger, varied30–50 yrs, equal sexAdolescents/young adults
OnsetInsidious, fluctuatingAcute hemorrhage or progressiveStepwise with hemorrhageSudden, maximal within minutes
MRIT2 hyperintensity + perimedullary flow voidsEnlarged vessels + nidus“Popcorn” lesion, hemosiderin ringDWI restriction, cord swelling
Gold-standard dxSpinal DSASpinal DSAMRI, GRE sequencesClinical + DWI MRI
TreatmentEmbolization/surgeryEmbolization/surgerySurgical resection if symptomaticSupportive, limited role for steroids

Clinical Pearls

- Always inspect T2 sagittal MRI for perimedullary flow voids when evaluating myelopathy.
• Symptoms often worsen with Valsalva or exertion due to transient increases in venous pressure.
• Early treatment (≤6 months of onset) yields better ambulatory outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misreading T2 cord signal change as demyelination (e.g., MS) without looking for flow voids.
2. Assuming all spinal vascular lesions present acutely; overlooking the insidious, fluctuating nature of DAVF.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- SNIS Consensus Guidelines on Spinal Vascular Malformations (2022): Recommends first-line endovascular embolization for DAVF when anatomy permits (Class I, Level B); surgical disconnection if embolization is contraindicated or unsuccessful (Class I, Level C).
• European Society of Neuroradiology (ESNR) Recommendations (2021): MRI screening followed by multi-level DSA for definitive diagnosis of spinal DAVF (Level C evidence); emphasizes early referral to specialized centers.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. Spinal DAVF is a high-yield topic on neurology boards, often tested as progressive, stepwise myelopathy in older men with MRI flow voids and vascular imaging.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Acute ischemic stroke management hinges on rapid reperfusion. Key principles:
• Time windows – IV alteplase is effective when given within 4.5 hours of onset; endovascular thrombectomy within 6 hours (extended to 16–24 hours in select cases).
• NIHSS scoring quantifies severity; scores ≥6 often reflect large-vessel occlusions but do not preclude IV tPA.
• Noncontrast head CT excludes hemorrhage; subtle early signs (insular ribbon, loss of gray–white differentiation in basal ganglia) denote evolving infarct but are not absolute contraindications if <1/3 MCA territory.
• Blood pressure must be ≤185/110 mmHg before and during tPA infusion.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The patient presents 3 hours after onset—well within the 4.5 hour window for IV alteplase. Her BP (180/100 mmHg) meets AHA/ASA criteria (<185/110 mmHg). Early ischemic changes on CT without frank hypodensity or hemorrhage do not contraindicate tPA; indeed, NINDS (1995) and ECASS III (2008) demonstrated a 30% relative improvement in functional outcomes with alteplase versus placebo even in the presence of subtle early CT findings. Endovascular thrombectomy (Class I, Level A) requires CTA/MRA confirmation of a proximal large-vessel occlusion; current guidelines recommend initiating IV tPA without delay, then obtaining vascular imaging to plan thrombectomy if indicated.
