Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Labetalol
• Incorrect: While BP control is necessary to achieve <185/110 mmHg, immediate labetalol infusion alone delays definitive reperfusion.
• Misconception: Treating hypertension supersedes thrombolysis.
• Differentiator: BP control is an adjunct to, not a substitute for, tPA when within window and below thresholds.

C. Thrombectomy
• Incorrect: Endovascular therapy is indicated for confirmed LVO on CTA/MRA; one must administer tPA first and then obtain angiographic imaging.
• Misconception: High NIHSS automatically mandates thrombectomy without tPA.
• Differentiator: tPA can be given immediately; thrombectomy requires vascular localization.

D. Supportive care with monitoring
• Incorrect: Omitting reperfusion therapy forfeits proven benefit; without tPA or thrombectomy, infarct size and disability increase.
• Misconception: Elderly patients derive less benefit or have higher hemorrhage risk.
• Differentiator: Age alone is not a contraindication—benefit persists in >80 years.

Comparison Table

OptionPrimary ActionIndication CriteriaTime WindowNext Step
ThrombolysisPlasminogen→plasmin, clot lysisIschemic stroke, <4.5 h, BP ≤185/110, no bleed0–4.5 hAdminister alteplase immediately
ThrombectomyMechanical clot retrievalConfirmed proximal LVO on CTA/MRA, NIHSS ≥60–6 h (extended up to 24 h with mismatch)Obtain CTA then schedule procedure
Labetalolβ-blocker, BP reductionHypertension managementN/AAdjunct to prepare for tPA
Supportive careMonitoring, basic supportContraindications to reperfusionN/ANo reperfusion—nonstandard care

Clinical Pearls

1. Early CT signs (insular ribbon, loss of gray–white differentiation) portend larger infarct but do not exclude tPA if <1/3 MCA territory.
2. Maintain systolic BP between 140–180 mmHg post-tPA; abrupt drops may worsen penumbra perfusion.
3. “Door-to-needle” times <60 minutes improve outcomes—streamline BP control and imaging.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Excluding patients for subtle early ischemic CT changes; in fact, these are not contraindications unless extensive.
2. Waiting for vascular imaging before tPA; guidelines prioritize noncontrast CT and BP control to avoid delays.
3. Overaggressive BP lowering to <140 mmHg prior to tPA can reduce collateral flow.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guidelines (2019, updated 2021): IV alteplase recommended within 4.5 h (Class I, Level A); BP target ≤185/110 mmHg pre-tPA.
2. DEFUSE-3 Trial (N Engl J Med 2018): Extended thrombectomy window to 6–16 h for patients with salvageable penumbra (Class I, Level B-R evidence).
3. DAWN Trial (N Engl J Med 2018): Showed benefit of thrombectomy up to 24 h in mismatch profile (Class I, Level B-R).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Early ischemic changes in the basal ganglia and insular ribbon on CT correlate with MCA M1 occlusion; the insula is particularly vulnerable due to end-arterial perfusion.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Arterial occlusion triggers the ischemic cascade: energy failure, glutamate excitotoxicity, ionic pump failure, cytotoxic edema. Timely reperfusion salvages penumbral tissue.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Rapid NIHSS assessment and last known well time.
2. Noncontrast CT to exclude hemorrhage (goal <20 min).
3. BP control to ≤185/110 mmHg.
4. Administer IV alteplase if eligible.
5. Obtain CTA/MRA to evaluate for LVO and plan thrombectomy.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Noncontrast CT may show hyperdense MCA sign, sulcal effacement, loss of insular ribbon—early indicators of large infarct core but not exclusionary.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Alteplase dosing: 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg), 10% bolus over 1 min, 90% infusion over 60 min. Continuous BP monitoring; treat rises with labetalol or nicardipine.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Hyperacute stroke management is frequently tested as clinical vignettes requiring appropriate reperfusion decisions and understanding of time-sensitive neuroimaging and blood pressure thresholds.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] - The visual pathway travels from retina → optic nerve → chiasm → optic tract → lateral geniculate nucleus → optic radiations (Meyer’s loop through temporal lobe and dorsal fibers through parietal lobe) → primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe.
• The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) supplies the occipital cortex; infarction here classically causes a contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing due to collateral MCA flow.
• Understanding vascular territories (PCA vs. MCA vs. ACA) and their cortical distributions is key to localizing visual field defects.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Posterior cerebral artery occlusion results in ischemia of the calcarine cortex, producing a contralateral homonymous hemianopia in approximately 60–80% of PCA stroke patients (Battaglini et al., Neurology 2017). Macular sparing occurs in ~50% due to dual supply from the MCA (Petersen et al., Brain 2018). The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Class I, Level A) recommend urgent MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) to confirm cortical infarction and CT angiography to identify PCA occlusion. Although mechanical thrombectomy is established for anterior circulation large-vessel occlusions, distal PCA clots are less amenable; acute management focuses on IV alteplase within 4.5 hours, antiplatelet therapy, and secondary prevention per AHA/ASA 2021 updates.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke
• MCA infarcts involve lateral frontal/parietal lobes and optic radiations, causing quadrantanopia or incongruent field cuts plus face/arm weakness and aphasia. Pure homonymous hemianopia without motor or cortical signs is uncommon.

C. Anterior cerebral artery (ACA) stroke
• ACA supplies medial frontal and parietal lobes; deficits include contralateral leg weakness, abulia, grasp reflex—not visual field cuts, as visual cortex lies outside ACA territory.

D. Lacunar stroke
• Lacunar infarcts affect deep perforating arterioles in subcortical structures (internal capsule, thalamus). They produce pure motor, pure sensory, or ataxic syndromes, rarely cortical visual deficits.

Comparison Table

FeaturePCA Stroke (Correct)MCA StrokeACA StrokeLacunar Stroke
Vascular TerritoryOccipital lobe (calcarine cortex)Lateral frontal/parietal lobesMedial frontal/parietal lobesDeep subcortical (capsule, thalamus)
Visual Field DeficitContralateral homonymous hemianopia (± macular sparing)Contralateral quadrantanopia or incongruent hemianopiaRare visual deficitsAbsent
Other Key DeficitsAlexia without agraphia (dominant), visual agnosiaFace/arm weakness, aphasia, neglectLeg paresis, abulia, frontal release signsPure motor/sensory syndromes
Imaging FindingsOccipital DWI hyperintensityCortical DWI in MCA distributionMedial DWI changesSmall (<15 mm) deep infarcts

Clinical Pearls

- Macular sparing in PCA infarcts arises from collateral MCA supply to the occipital pole.
• Homonymous hemianopia respects the vertical meridian; quadrantanopia respects an oblique line (Meyer’s loop).
• Always perform bedside confrontation fields; confirm with formal perimetry and MRI in suspected PCA strokes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating any homonymous field cut with MCA stroke—MCA infarcts more often cause congruent quadrantanopias rather than full hemianopias.
2. Assuming lacunar strokes can produce cortical signs—small vessel strokes spare cortex, so visual field deficits are atypical.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Stroke; 2018): Class I recommendation for IV alteplase within 4.5 h for PCA strokes if no contraindications (Level A evidence).
• AHA/ASA 2021 Update (Stroke; 2021): Emphasizes MRI-based selection for thrombolysis in posterior circulation strokes and long-term secondary prevention with high-intensity statin and antiplatelet therapy (Level B-R).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The calcarine fissure in the occipital lobe houses the primary visual cortex (Brodmann area 17). Lesions here yield congruent field cuts; macular fibers project most posteriorly, explaining macular sparing when superficial PCA branches only partially infarct.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PCA occlusion triggers the ischemic cascade in cortical neurons: reduced perfusion → energy failure → excitotoxic glutamate release → oxidative stress → cell death predominantly in layers 4–6 of the visual cortex.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Bedside confrontation visual field testing
2. Urgent noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage
3. MRI brain with DWI to identify cortical infarct
4. CT angiography/MR angiography to localize PCA occlusion
5. Cardiac evaluation and vascular imaging for secondary prevention

Neuroimaging Pearls

- DWI: hyperintense signal in occipital cortex within minutes of PCA occlusion.
• FLAIR: may lag behind DWI; mismatch suggests hyperacute infarct amenable to reperfusion.
• Macular sparing appears as preserved signal in occipital pole.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Acute: IV alteplase (0.9 mg/kg up to 90 mg) within 4.5 h (10% bolus, remainder over 60 min).
• Secondary: aspirin 81–325 mg daily; high-intensity statin (atorvastatin 80 mg). Control hypertension, diabetes, and atrial fibrillation if present.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Visual field deficits and vascular anatomy are frequently tested; students should be prepared to correlate specific quadrantic or hemianopic patterns with arterial territories and associated cortical signs.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] Acute ischemic stroke results from arterial occlusion leading to an infarct core surrounded by a potentially salvageable penumbra. Reperfusion therapy aims to restore blood flow before irreversible neuronal injury. Intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is first-line within 4.5 hours but has contraindications (e.g., recent hemorrhage, surgery). Mechanical thrombectomy physically removes clot in large vessel occlusions (LVO) and is indicated when tPA is contraindicated or has failed. Key concepts:
• Ischemic penumbra and time‐dependent neuronal death
• Large vessel occlusion (e.g., proximal MCA/ICA) pathophysiology
• Reperfusion strategies: pharmacologic (tPA) vs endovascular

(Word count: 118)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Mechanical thrombectomy is a Class I, Level A recommendation in the 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for patients with anterior circulation LVO within 6 hours of onset and favorable imaging (ASPECTS ≥6). The MR CLEAN (2015) trial demonstrated a number needed to treat (NNT) of 7.4 for improved 90-day functional outcomes. Later DAWN (2018; NNT = 2.8) and DEFUSE-3 (2018; NNT = 3) extended the window to 6–24 hours for selected patients with perfusion–diffusion mismatch. In contraindicated tPA scenarios—recent surgery, hemorrhage risk, or beyond the window—thrombectomy remains the only proven reperfusion modality. Meta-analysis of HERMES collaborators confirms benefit across age and stroke severity subgroups.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. IV thrombolytic therapy
• Incorrect: Contraindicated by definition; risk of hemorrhagic conversion in high-risk patients.
• Misconception: Belief that every ischemic stroke patient qualifies for tPA.
• Differentiator: tPA has strict inclusion/exclusion criteria (e.g., no recent intracranial surgery).

C. Antiplatelet therapy
• Incorrect: Role is secondary prevention, not acute reperfusion.
• Misconception: Confusing chronic stroke prevention with emergent treatment.
• Differentiator: Onset of action too slow to abort evolving infarct.

D. Supportive care and rehabilitation
• Incorrect: Does not address acute vessel occlusion; only post-stroke management.
• Misconception: Underestimating the time‐sensitive nature of reperfusion.
• Differentiator: Lacks evidence for improving acute neurologic outcome.

Comparison Table

FeatureMechanical ThrombectomyIV tPAAntiplatelet TherapySupportive Care
IndicationLVO, tPA‐ineligible or failedAcute ≤4.5 h ischemic strokeSecondary preventionPost-acute management
Time windowUp to 6 h (extendable to 24 h)≤4.5 h from onsetChronicAnytime
MechanismEndovascular clot retrievalPlasminogen activationPlatelet inhibitionGeneral supportive measures
Key trials/guidelinesMR CLEAN, HERMES, DEFUSE-3NINDS, ECASS IIICAPRIE, CHARISMA—
Level of evidenceI, AI, AI, B—

Clinical Pearls

• Always obtain CT angiography after noncontrast CT to identify LVO.
• Aim for door-to-groin puncture ≤90 minutes to maximize penumbral salvage.
• General anesthesia may delay reperfusion; consider conscious sedation when feasible.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating antiplatelet loading with reperfusion—antiplatelets prevent recurrence, not acute infarct expansion.
2. Omitting vascular imaging post-CT scan—fails to identify thrombectomy candidates.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2019 Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommends thrombectomy for anterior LVO within 6 h (Class I, Level A).
• DAWN Trial (NEJM 2018): Extends thrombectomy eligibility to 6–24 h in patients with small core/large penumbra (Class I, Level B-R).
• DEFUSE-3 (NEJM 2018): Confirms benefit in 6–16 h window with perfusion mismatch (Class I, Level B-R).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Large vessel occlusions most commonly involve the proximal middle cerebral artery (M1 segment) or intracranial internal carotid artery, leading to contralateral hemiparesis, aphasia (dominant), and neglect (non-dominant).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thrombus in a major cerebral artery arrests antegrade perfusion, initiating the ischemic cascade: energy failure, glutamate excitotoxicity, and infarct core expansion. Mechanical thrombectomy rapidly restores flow to salvage penumbral tissue.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Rapid NIHSS assessment
2. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage
3. CT angiography/perfusion to confirm LVO and penumbra
4. Decision on thrombectomy eligibility (time, contraindications)

Neuroimaging Pearls

CT perfusion mismatch (Tmax >6 s volume versus infarct core) predicts penumbral tissue and thrombectomy benefit. Collateral scoring on CTA informs prognosis.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2022 exam.
Management of tPA-ineligible acute stroke with LVO is frequently tested as scenario-based questions focusing on time windows, imaging criteria, and guideline-based therapy.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] • Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) is defined as a transient neurological deficit without acute infarction.
• The ABCD² score (Age, Blood pressure, Clinical features, Duration, Diabetes) stratifies 2-, 7-, and 90-day stroke risk after TIA.
• Key variables: age ≥60 years (1 point), BP ≥140/90 mm Hg (1), unilateral weakness (2), symptom duration 10–59 min (1), diabetes (1).
• Total ABCD² ranges 0–7: low (0–3), moderate (4–5), high (6–7) risk categories.

Evidence-Based Analysis

An ABCD² score of 6 in this patient (age 1 + BP 1 + weakness 2 + duration 1 + diabetes 1) places him in the high-risk group. Johnston et al. (NEJM 2007) demonstrated that patients with scores 6–7 have a 90-day stroke risk of 17.8%. The 2018 AHA/ASA TIA guidelines (Class I, Level B-R) endorse using ABCD² for early risk stratification, noting that high-risk patients benefit from expedited imaging and dual antiplatelet therapy (POINT trial, NEJM 2018).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Low – Incorrect. Low-risk ABCD² (0–3) corresponds to <3 % 90-day stroke risk, but this patient scores 6. It reflects underestimation of his risk.
B. Moderate – Incorrect. Moderate (4–5) yields ~9.8 % 90-day risk; his 6-point score exceeds this threshold.
D. Very high – Incorrect. No “very high” category exists in standard ABCD² stratification; the uppermost defined tier is “high.”

Comparison Table

ABCD² ScoreCategory90-Day Stroke Risk (%)
0–3Low1–3
4–5Moderate~9.8
6–7High~17.8

Clinical Pearls

• TIA patients with high ABCD² scores (6–7) should receive brain MRI ± vascular imaging within 24 hours.
• Early dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) for 21 days reduces early recurrent stroke in high-risk TIAs (POINT, CHANCE trials).
• Carotid duplex and cardiac evaluation are urgent in high-risk patients to identify treatable sources.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Mistaking ABCD (4-factor) for ABCD²: omitting diabetes underestimates risk.
• Applying ABCD² to posterior circulation TIAs without symptom adjustment may misclassify risk.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2018 Secondary Stroke Prevention Guideline: endorses ABCD² for early risk stratification (Class I, LOE B-R).
• POINT Trial (NEJM 2018): early dual antiplatelet therapy in high-risk TIA (ABCD² ≥4) reduces 90-day stroke recurrence (HR 0.68; p=0.04).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. TIA risk stratification via ABCD² is frequently tested in both clinical vignettes and direct recall formats on neurology and internal medicine board exams.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] 1. The superior cerebellar artery (SCA) supplies the superior half of the cerebellar hemisphere, dentate nucleus, and superior cerebellar peduncle.
2. Cerebellar lesions produce ipsilateral limb ataxia, dysmetria, intention tremor, and dysdiadochokinesia due to interruption of cerebellar cortical and deep nucleus output.
3. Unlike brainstem or vertebrobasilar strokes, pure SCA infarcts do not typically cause cranial nerve nuclei signs (e.g., Horner’s syndrome, trochlear palsy) or long‐tract motor weakness.

Evidence-Based Analysis

SCA infarctions classically present with ipsilateral cerebellar signs—limb ataxia, dysmetria, and gait unsteadiness—because the artery perfuses the cerebellar cortex and deep nuclei (dentate). Powers et al. (2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines) recommend early MRI with diffusion‐weighted imaging to confirm posterior fossa strokes (Class I; Level B-R). In a series by Chung et al. (Stroke 2019), 87% of isolated SCA infarcts exhibited prominent ipsilateral limb ataxia and dysmetria, with minimal brainstem signs. The absence of pyramidal tract involvement (no contralateral weakness) and sparing of descending sympathetic fibers (no Horner’s) or trochlear nerve fascicles underscores the localizing value of cerebellar symptoms in SCA distribution.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome / ptosis
• Incorrect because Horner’s results from disruption of descending sympathetic fibers in the lateral medulla (PICA territory), not the SCA.
• Misconception: assuming all posterior circulation strokes yield Horner’s.
• Differentiation: PICA infarcts often cause Wallenberg syndrome with ipsilateral facial pain/temperature loss and Horner’s.

B. Ipsilateral fourth nerve palsy
• Incorrect as trochlear nucleus/fascicle lesions occur in dorsal midbrain/tectal regions, supplied by PCA or top of basilar, not SCA.
• Misconception: attributing isolated cranial nerve palsies to cerebellar artery strokes.
• Differentiation: Trochlear palsy presents with vertical diplopia worsened on downgaze and contralateral head tilt.

C. Contralateral hemiparesis
• Incorrect because corticospinal tracts are not in the SCA territory; they run ventrally in the pons and internal capsule.
• Misconception: believing cerebellar strokes produce pyramidal weakness.
• Differentiation: Hemiparesis signals involvement of internal capsule (MCA infarct) or ventral pontine branches.

Comparison Table

FeatureSCA Infarct (Correct)PICA Infarct (Wallenberg)PCA Infarct (Midbrain)Basilar (Paramedian)
Primary symptomsIpsilateral ataxia, dysmetriaContralateral pain/temp loss, ipsilateral Horner’sVertical gaze palsy, trochlear palsyContralateral hemiparesis
Cranial nerve involvementRareCN V, IX, XCN III, IVCN VI, VII
Brainstem signsMinimalProminent lateral medullaryDorsal midbrain signsVentral pontine signs
ImagingSuperior cerebellar lobe DWI lesionLateral medulla lesionTectal/midbrain lesionPontine infarct

Clinical Pearls

1. Isolated SCA strokes often present with acute limb ataxia, dysarthria, and truncal instability without sensory or long‐tract findings.
2. Early MRI DWI is more sensitive than CT for posterior fossa infarcts; do not delay imaging in suspected cerebellar stroke.
3. Cerebellar edema after infarction can cause mass effect—monitor for headache, vomiting, and decreased consciousness; consider neurosurgical decompression.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all posterior circulation strokes with Horner’s syndrome.
2. Assuming cerebellar infarcts produce contralateral weakness; remember cerebellar lesions impair coordination, not strength.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Powers WJ et al. 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke:
– Recommendation: MRI with DWI is preferred for posterior fossa strokes (Class I; Level B‐R).
2. Mattle HP et al. 2021 European Stroke Organisation Guidelines on Posterior Circulation Stroke:
– Recommendation: Obtain early neuroimaging (MRI over CT) and monitor for cerebellar swelling; consider ICU admission (Class IIa; Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. Cerebellar artery stroke syndromes (PICA, AICA, SCA) are tested frequently in NBME-style vignettes, often contrasting cranial nerve vs. cerebellar signs.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] • Malignant hypertension (>180/120 mmHg) can cause acute cerebrovascular complications: intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) vs. hypertensive encephalopathy.
• Chronic hypertension induces hyaline arteriolosclerosis; malignant spikes produce hyperplastic (“onion-skin”) arteriolosclerosis and Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysm rupture in deep penetrating arterioles (basal ganglia, thalamus, pons).
• Systemic sclerosis (esophageal dysmotility) predisposes to scleroderma renal crisis, triggering malignant hypertension and end-organ damage, including ICH.
• Presentation of sudden severe headache, rapid consciousness decline, and BP >200 mmHg strongly favors ICH over non-hemorrhagic processes.

(Word count: 113)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Intracerebral hemorrhage is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with malignant hypertension and acute neurologic deterioration. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2022 guidelines recommend noncontrast head CT as first-line imaging to confirm ICH (Class I, Level A). Hypertensive ICH most often involves deep structures due to rupture of Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysms. Acute BP spikes damage small arterioles via hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis, leading to focal hematoma formation. Landmark trials—INTERACT2 (Lancet 2013) and ATACH-2 (NEJM 2016)—support rapid BP reduction (target systolic 140 mmHg) to limit hematoma expansion and improve outcomes. In contrast, hypertensive encephalopathy (PRES) shows vasogenic edema on MRI without frank hemorrhage; Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) occurs subacutely in immunosuppressed hosts; subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) features thunderclap headache and blood in subarachnoid cisterns.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Hemolytic encephalopathy
 – Not a recognized entity; likely a misnomer for hypertensive encephalopathy (PRES).
 – PRES presents with headache, confusion, visual changes and MRI vasogenic edema, not focal parenchymal bleed on CT.

B. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
 – JC virus–mediated demyelination in immunocompromised; insidious onset over weeks, no malignant hypertension or acute loss of consciousness.
 – MRI: multiple non-enhancing white-matter lesions without hemorrhage.

D. Subarachnoid hemorrhage
 – Presents with sudden “worst headache of life,” nuchal rigidity, photophobia.
 – CT: hyperdensity in sulci and cisterns; often accompanied by normal or mildly elevated BP, not malignant hypertension–induced deep parenchymal bleed.

Comparison Table

FeatureIntracerebral Hemorrhage“Hemolytic” (Hypertensive) EncephalopathyPMLSubarachnoid Hemorrhage
OnsetHyperacute (minutes)Subacute (hours)Insidious (weeks–months)Thunderclap (seconds)
HeadacheSevere, focalDull, globalRare“Worst headache”
Blood PressureMalignant (>180/120 mmHg)Elevated but < malignant levelsNormotensiveVariable
NeuroimagingCT: hyperdense parenchymal bleedMRI: T2/FLAIR vasogenic edema (PRES)MRI: non-enhancing demyelinating lesionsCT: blood in sulci/cisterns
Focal Neurologic DeficitsCommon (hemiparesis, gaze deviation)Rare; mainly encephalopathyFocal demyelination (e.g., aphasia)May have cranial nerve signs, seizures
CSF AnalysisXanthochromia if extensionNormalJC virus PCR positiveXanthochromia, elevated opening pressure

Clinical Pearls

• Malignant hypertension in systemic sclerosis often heralds scleroderma renal crisis; always assess for end-organ damage including ICH.
• Noncontrast CT is the fastest way to distinguish hemorrhagic vs. non-hemorrhagic stroke in hypertensive emergencies.
• Tight BP control (target systolic ~140 mmHg) within 1 hour reduces hematoma expansion (INTERACT2, ATACH-2).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing hypertensive (PRES) encephalopathy with ICH—PRES has vasogenic edema on MRI, lacks parenchymal bleed on CT.
2. Overlooking systemic sclerosis as a risk factor for malignant hypertension and ICH; attributing headache solely to renal failure.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2022 Guideline on Spontaneous Intracerebral Hemorrhage: strong recommendation (Class I, Level A) for lowering systolic BP to 140 mmHg within 1 hour.
• INTERACT2 (Lancet 2013) & ATACH-2 (NEJM 2016): intensive BP reduction reduces hematoma growth and improves functional outcome; supports intravenous nicardipine/labetalol.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Deep cerebral structures (basal ganglia, thalamus, pons) supplied by small perforating arteries are most susceptible to hypertensive hemorrhage via Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysm rupture.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic hypertension → hyaline arteriolosclerosis; malignant spikes → hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis (“onion-skin”) → vessel fragility → parenchymal hemorrhage.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Stabilize ABCs; secure airway if low GCS.
2. Obtain noncontrast head CT immediately.
3. If ICH confirmed, reverse coagulopathy, consult neurosurgery.
4. Initiate IV antihypertensive therapy to target systolic 140 mmHg.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Noncontrast CT: hyperdense (50–80 HU) intraparenchymal lesion; use ABC/2 formula to estimate hematoma volume and guide prognosis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line agents: IV nicardipine infusion (5 mg/h, titrate by 2.5 mg/h q5–15 min) or IV labetalol bolus (10–20 mg) to safely lower systolic BP to ~140 mmHg; avoid precipitous drops to maintain cerebral perfusion.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. Hypertensive emergencies leading to intracerebral hemorrhage are commonly tested in vignette form, stressing differentiation from hypertensive encephalopathy and subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) on vitamin K antagonists presents a dual challenge: mass lesion and coagulopathy. Warfarin raises INR by depleting vitamin K–dependent clotting factors II, VII, IX and X. Rapid reversal minimizes hematoma expansion. Prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) provides concentrated clotting factors II, VII, IX and X, yielding fast INR normalization. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) and vitamin K act more slowly; platelets address antiplatelet, not anticoagulant, bleeding. Understanding pharmacokinetics of factor replacement and volume/status considerations guides urgent management. (120 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Four-factor PCC is first-line for urgent warfarin reversal in ICH. The 2015 and 2022 AHA/ASA ICH guidelines (Hemphill et al., 2015; Morotti et al., 2022) grade PCC as Class I, Level A evidence due to:
• Rapid INR correction to <1.4 within 30–60 minutes versus hours with FFP.
• Lower infusion volume (20–40 mL) reduces risk of volume overload and transfusion‐related lung injury.
• Observational studies (Pawluk et al., 2015) show reduced hematoma expansion and improved functional outcomes.
Intravenous vitamin K (5–10 mg) should accompany PCC but alone is insufficient acutely. Platelet transfusion is irrelevant without antiplatelet drug ingestion.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP)
• Incorrect because reversal is slower (3–6 hours), requires crossmatch and large volume (10–15 mL/kg).
• Misconception: “plasma always reverses coagulopathy quickly.”
• Fails to achieve rapid hemostasis needed to limit hematoma expansion.

C. Vitamin K administration
• Provides endogenous factor synthesis escalation over 6–24 hours.
• Misconception: “vitamin K alone normalizes INR quickly.”
• Does not address acute bleeding; must be adjunctive to PCC.

D. Platelet transfusion
• Targets platelet dysfunction (e.g., antiplatelet drugs), not factor deficiency.
• Misconception: “all hemorrhages benefit from platelets.”
• No role in warfarin-associated ICH unless platelet count <50,000/µL.

Comparison Table

FeaturePCC (Correct)FFPVitamin KPlatelets
Onset of action10–30 minutes3–6 hours6–24 hours1–2 hours
Volume per dose20–40 mL total10–15 mL/kgMinimal IV volume200–400 mL per unit
Components replacedII, VII, IX, XAll plasma proteinsCofactor for γ-carboxylationPlatelets
Risk of volume overloadLowHighMinimalModerate
Compatibility requirementsNo ABO match neededABO match requiredN/AABO match required

Clinical Pearls

- Administer four-factor PCC as soon as possible, ideally within 3 hours of symptom onset.
• Dose PCC by body weight and target INR (e.g., 25 IU/kg for INR 2–4).
• Always co-administer 5–10 mg IV vitamin K to sustain factor synthesis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Choosing FFP due to familiarity—leads to treatment delays and volume overload.
2. Omitting IV vitamin K when using PCC—risk of rebound coagulopathy as PCC factors clear.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA ICH Guideline Update 2022: Recommends four-factor PCC over FFP for warfarin-associated ICH (Class I, Level A).
• European Stroke Organisation 2021: Endorses rapid INR reversal with four-factor PCC and adjunctive IV vitamin K (Grade A recommendation).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam.
Warfarin reversal in ICH is frequently tested—expect questions on mechanism, dosing, timing, and comparative efficacy of PCC vs FFP.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Lateral pontine (facial) syndromes result from infarction of the anteroinferior cerebellar artery (AICA) territory. Key concepts:
• Vascular anatomy: AICA arises from the basilar artery and gives off the labyrinthine artery to the inner ear.
• Brainstem nuclei: In the lateral pons, AICA infarcts affect the facial nerve nucleus (facial paralysis) and vestibulocochlear nerve (hearing loss, vertigo).
• Clinical localization: Hearing impairment localizes pathology to the inner ear/cochlear nerve, distinguishing AICA from PICA (which spares CN VIII).

Evidence-Based Analysis

AICA infarcts classically produce an ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss due to occlusion of the labyrinthine branch. Norrving et al. (Lancet Neurol 2022) emphasize that cochlear infarction is pathognomonic for AICA strokes. MRI-DWI confirms lateral pontine lesions; CT angiography demonstrates AICA occlusion. The 2021 American Heart Association/American Stroke Association Guidelines for the Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke recommend prompt vessel imaging (CTA/MRA; Class I, Level B-NR) to identify posterior circulation occlusions and guide reperfusion strategies. In contrast, PICA infarcts present with Wallenberg’s syndrome without hearing loss, and MCA/ACA strokes involve cortical territories without isolated pontine signs.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. PICA
• Incorrect because PICA supplies the lateral medulla, sparing the internal auditory artery; hearing is preserved. Misconception: associating any posterior circulation stroke with auditory symptoms.
C. MCA
• MCA strokes affect the lateral cerebral cortex (face/arm areas) and subcortical white matter; they do not produce isolated pontine signs or cochlear infarction. Students may confuse contralateral cortical deafness (rare, requires bilateral lesions) with brainstem auditory loss.
D. ACA
• ACA supplies medial frontal lobes; infarction leads to contralateral leg weakness and abulia, not brainstem or auditory deficits. Confusing arterial territories in the circle of Willis is a common error.

Comparison Table

FeatureAICA InfarctPICA InfarctMCA InfarctACA Infarct
Arterial originBasilar → AICA + labyrinthine branchVertebral → PICAInternal carotid → MCAInternal carotid → ACA
Primary territoryLateral pons, inner earLateral medullaLateral cerebral hemisphereMedial frontal/parietal lobes
Key nuclei affectedFacial (VII), vestibulocochlear (VIII), spinal trigeminalNucleus ambiguus (IX/X), spinal trigeminalMotor/sensory cortexParacentral lobule
Clinical hallmarksIpsilateral facial paralysis, hearing loss, vertigo, ipsi facial pain/temp loss, contra body pain/temp lossDysphagia, hoarseness, vertigo, ipsi pain/temp loss of face & contra body, no hearing lossContralateral face/arm weakness & sensory loss, aphasia (dominant), visual field deficitsContralateral leg weakness, frontal lobe signs (gait apraxia, personality change)

Clinical Pearls

- The labyrinthine artery is an end‐artery branch of AICA; its occlusion causes irreversible cochlear ischemia and ipsilateral hearing loss.
• Facial paralysis (VII) in a lateral brainstem syndrome localizes to AICA, whereas dysphagia/hoarseness (IX/X) points to PICA.
• In suspected posterior circulation stroke, obtain MRI DWI and CTA/MRA urgently to distinguish between AICA, PICA, and basilar occlusions.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming any vertebrobasilar infarct yields hearing loss; only AICA (via labyrinthine artery) does so.
2. Confusing lateral medullary (Wallenberg) with lateral pontine syndromes; check for facial nerve involvement.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association 2021 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke
• Recommendation: Perform urgent vascular imaging (CTA or MRA) in suspected posterior circulation stroke (Class I, Level B-NR).
• Emphasis on rapid identification of AICA occlusion to guide thrombolysis or endovascular therapy.
2. European Stroke Organisation 2022 Clinical Practice Guidelines
• Recommendation: Offer intravenous thrombolysis to eligible posterior circulation stroke patients within 4.5 hours of onset (Grade A).
• Highlights MRI‐based decision‐making for brainstem strokes to reduce misclassification.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Brainstem stroke syndromes—particularly distinguishing AICA vs PICA—are tested regularly (approximately 2–3% of vascular neurology questions) in single-best-answer format. Posterior circulation anatomy and related clinical findings are high‐yield for neuroanatomy and stroke modules.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Acute stroke manifests with sudden focal deficits—in this case, right‐sided weakness and aphasia—indicating left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory involvement. Hyperacute management follows the “time is brain” principle: rapid differentiation between hemorrhagic and ischemic stroke via noncontrast CT. Elevated blood pressure is common in acute stroke and is often tolerated (permissive hypertension) until imaging clarifies the subtype. Concurrently, point‐of‐care glucose testing rules out hypoglycemia but does not replace urgent neuroimaging to guide reperfusion decisions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Noncontrast head CT within 20 minutes of arrival is a Class I, LOE C recommendation (AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines) to exclude intracranial hemorrhage before initiating reperfusion. The NINDS tPA trial established that CT confirmation of ischemia is mandatory for safe thrombolysis, reducing hemorrhagic risk. Meretoja et al. (2012) demonstrated that door‐to‐needle times ≤ 60 minutes correlate with better 90-day outcomes. While blood glucose must be checked immediately (Class I, LOE C), it is performed in parallel with imaging preparation and does not supplant CT as the next critical step.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Control blood pressure
• Incorrect: Acute ischemic stroke often benefits from permissive hypertension (up to 185/110 mm Hg) to maintain perfusion.
• Misconception: All elevated BP in stroke carries the same hemorrhage risk.
• Differentiator: Imaging must precede aggressive BP lowering to avoid delaying diagnosis.

C. IV thrombolysis
• Incorrect: Thrombolytic therapy requires exclusion of hemorrhage via CT. Administering alteplase without imaging can cause fatal intracranial bleeding.
• Misconception: Immediate tPA in any suspected stroke.
• Differentiator: CT proof of ischemia is mandatory before reperfusion.

D. Obtain blood glucose level
• Incorrect: Hypoglycemia mimics stroke but glucose testing is a rapid adjunct (fingerstick) performed alongside initial evaluation, not a standalone next step over CT.
• Misconception: Metabolic screen overrides imaging.
• Differentiator: CT remains the priority to define stroke subtype.

Comparison Table

OptionPurposeTimingKey Consideration
CT brain [CORRECT]Differentiate hemorrhage vs ischemiaImmediate (≤ 20 min)Guides reperfusion eligibility
Control blood pressureManage hypertensive responseAfter imagingAvoid SBP < 185 mm Hg until subtype known
IV thrombolysisReperfusion therapyPost‐CT confirmationContraindicated if hemorrhage present
Obtain blood glucoseExclude metabolic stroke mimicsConcurrent with triageDoes not replace need for CT imaging

Clinical Pearls

- Aim for noncontrast CT within 20 minutes of ED arrival to expedite decision-making.
• Maintain permissive hypertension (SBP ≤ 185/110 mm Hg) before imaging; aggressive lowering can reduce penumbral perfusion.
• Implement parallel workflows: start blood glucose check and CT preparation simultaneously.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Lowering BP precipitously in acute stroke patients, risking worsened cerebral ischemia.
2. Administering tPA prior to neuroimaging, overlooking the requirement to exclude hemorrhage.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Class I recommendation for noncontrast CT head within 20 minutes of arrival (LOE C).
2. Meretoja E et al., Stroke 2012: Reduced door-to-needle times (< 60 min) significantly improve 90-day functional outcomes.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam. On board exams, acute stroke management questions frequently test rapid imaging protocols and time-sensitive reperfusion strategies.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Carotid artery dissection occurs when an intimal tear allows blood to enter the vessel wall, forming an intramural hematoma. This can compress adjacent cranial nerves within the carotid sheath. The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) courses medial to the internal carotid artery in the neck; injury produces an ipsilateral lower motor neuron palsy. Key concepts:
• Anatomy of the carotid sheath: contains ICA, internal jugular vein, vagus nerve, and nearby cranial nerves (IX–XII).
• Hypoglossal nerve function: motor innervation to ipsilateral tongue musculature; lesion causes deviation toward the side of injury.
• Distinction from sympathetic chain lesions: affect pupil (Horner’s syndrome), not tongue movement.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option D is correct: carotid dissection can extend into the carotid sheath and directly injure the hypoglossal nerve, producing an ipsilateral tongue deviation toward the lesion side. Neuroimaging (CTA/MRA) often reveals a mural hematoma adjacent to the nerve’s course. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2011 guidelines (Class I, Level B) recommend imaging to assess both arterial injury and associated cranial nerve involvement. In a cohort study by Arnold et al. (Neurology 2010), approximately 4–8% of cervical dissections presented with cranial nerve palsies—hypoglossal involvement being the most common. No evidence supports involvement of pre- or post-ganglionic sympathetic fibers in tongue movement, as those fibers mediate ocular and facial sweating functions.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Pre-ganglionic nerve damage
– Incorrect: Pre-ganglionic fibers refer to sympathetic neurons emerging from the spinal cord (T1–T2) en route to the superior cervical ganglion. Lesion here causes Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis) but does not affect tongue motor function.
– Misconception: Confusing sympathetic chain anatomy with cranial motor nerves.
– Differentiator: Hypoglossal nerve is purely somatic motor, not sympathetic.

B. Post-ganglionic nerve damage
– Incorrect: Post-ganglionic sympathetic fibers travel from the superior cervical ganglion along the carotid to the eye and face; damage leads to anhidrosis and ptosis, but tongue deviation is unaffected.
– Misconception: Equating all fibers in the carotid sheath as motor to tongue.
– Differentiator: Post-ganglionic lesions spare XII function.

C. It does not affect tongue movement
– Incorrect: Multiple case series document hypoglossal palsy with tongue deviation in carotid dissection.
– Misconception: Underestimating the space-occupying effect of the intramural hematoma.
– Differentiator: Direct compression of CN XII causes clear motor deficits.

Comparison Table

FeatureHypoglossal Nerve Palsy (CN XII)Pre-ganglionic Sympathetic LesionPost-ganglionic Sympathetic LesionNo Tongue Involvement
Nerve fibers affectedLower motor (somatic)Sympathetic pre-ganglionicSympathetic post-ganglionicNone
Clinical signsIpsilateral tongue deviationMiosis, ptosis, anhidrosisMiosis, ptosis, facial anhidrosisNone
Tongue weaknessPresentAbsentAbsentAbsent
Association with carotid dissectionYesYes (Horner’s syndrome)Yes (Horner’s syndrome)No

Clinical Pearls

- Hypoglossal palsy in carotid dissection typically presents with dysarthria and tongue fasciculations pointing toward the side of injury.
• In any patient with neck pain and acute tongue deviation, obtain urgent CTA/MRA of cervical vessels to exclude dissection.
• Coexistence of Horner’s syndrome and XII palsy (“crescent sign”) strongly localizes the lesion to the carotid artery sheath.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misattributing tongue deviation to sympathetic chain lesions; students must distinguish motor from autonomic fibers.
2. Assuming carotid dissections only cause stroke; in ~20% of cases, cranial nerve palsies are the presenting feature without ischemic symptoms.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Prevention of Stroke in Patients With Stroke and Transient Ischemic Attack (2011): Class I, Level B recommendation for vascular imaging in suspected cervical artery dissection to detect arterial and nerve involvement.
2. CADISS Trial (Lancet Neurol 2015): randomized trial showing no difference in recurrent stroke rates between antiplatelet and anticoagulation therapy in cervical artery dissection patients; informs pharmacotherapy decisions (Level A evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The hypoglossal nerve exits the skull via the hypoglossal canal, descends medial to the internal carotid artery, then loops around the occipital artery to innervate intrinsic and extrinsic tongue muscles. A dissecting hematoma within the carotid sheath exerts mass effect on CN XII.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Dissection begins with an intimal tear, blood enters the media forming a hematoma. Expansion compresses adjacent structures—cranial nerves IX–XII run in the carotid space. Hypoglossal fibers, being most medial, are particularly vulnerable to compression, leading to axonal ischemia and neuropraxia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: neck pain + tongue deviation/dysarthria
2. Neurological exam: isolate CN deficits (XII on tongue, sympathetic signs for Horner’s)
3. Vascular imaging: CTA or MRA of neck vessels
4. Confirm dissection: look for “double lumen” or “flame-shaped” occlusion
5. Initiate antithrombotic therapy based on imaging and bleeding risk

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CTA: high-resolution imaging shows intramural hematoma as crescentic hyperdensity.
• MRA: fat-suppressed T1 imaging highlights the hematoma rim.
• DSA: “string sign” or “flame-shaped” narrowing of the ICA.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Initiate antithrombotic therapy within 24–48 hours unless contraindicated.
• Antiplatelet (aspirin 75–100 mg daily) vs. anticoagulation (heparin to warfarin INR 2–3) are equivalent per CADISS trial.
• Duration: 3–6 months, then re-evaluate vessel healing.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. Carotid dissection with cranial nerve palsies is a high-yield topic on stroke and neurovascular exams; expect questions on imaging hallmarks, management guidelines, and distinguishing motor vs autonomic nerve deficits.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Medial medullary (Dejerine) syndrome arises from infarction of the medial medulla, typically due to occlusion of branches of the vertebral artery or anterior spinal artery. Key structures in this territory include:
• Corticospinal tract: lesion causes contralateral hemiparesis.
• Medial lemniscus: lesion causes contralateral loss of proprioception and vibration.
• Hypoglossal nerve fibers/nucleus: lesion causes ipsilateral tongue weakness and deviation.
Recognizing that ipsilateral cranial nerve signs plus contralateral body deficits localize to the brainstem is critical for acute stroke management and vessel-based localization.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Right vertebral artery occlusion best explains the triad of left-sided weakness (corticospinal tract in right pyramid), left proprioceptive loss (right medial lemniscus), and right tongue weakness (right hypoglossal nucleus/fibers). The vertebral artery gives off the anterior spinal artery that supplies the medial medulla; occlusion at its origin or the vertebral artery itself leads to medial medullary infarction. A 2019 AHA/ASA guideline on posterior circulation stroke emphasizes early vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) to identify vertebral artery occlusion (Class I, LOE B-R). Kim et al. (Stroke, 2018) detailed that vertebral artery territory infarcts frequently present with combined motor and cranial nerve deficits, distinct from PICA or basilar strokes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Left vertebral artery
• Incorrect laterality: left-sided occlusion would produce right hemiparesis and right proprioceptive loss.
• Misconception: assuming “vertebral artery” without considering side reverses clinical signs.
• Differentiator: tongue deviation would be to the left with left hypoglossal involvement.

C. Basilar artery
• Basilar occlusion affects pons: would cause bilateral ‘locked-in’ features or ipsilateral facial sensory/motor deficits, conjugate gaze palsy, not isolated hypoglossal and contralateral body signs.
• Misconception: all brainstem strokes present similarly.
• Differentiator: basilar infarcts seldom spare face and produce cranial nerve VI or VII signs rather than XII.

D. Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
• PICA infarcts (Wallenberg) spare corticospinal tracts and hypoglossal nucleus; manifest with ipsilateral facial pain/temp loss, dysphagia, hoarseness, contralateral pain/temp loss, but normal strength and proprioception.
• Misconception: lateral medullary and medial medullary syndromes are interchangeable.
• Differentiator: absence of motor weakness and presence of nucleus ambiguus signs in PICA.

Comparison Table

FeatureRight Vertebral Artery (Medial Medullary)Basilar Artery (Pontine)PICA (Lateral Medullary)
Motor weaknessContralateral hemiparesisOften bilateral or paramedianAbsent
ProprioceptionContralateral loss (medial lemniscus)Variable; may affect medial lemniscus if paramedianPreserved (spinothalamic affected)
Cranial nerve involvementIpsilateral XII (tongue deviation toward lesion)VI/VII, gaze palsies, facial paralysisIX/X (dysphagia, hoarseness), nucleus ambiguus
Vascular territoryMedial medullaPons (ventral)Lateral medulla
Typical arteryVertebral or ASA branchBasilarPICA

Clinical Pearls

- Tongue deviation toward the lesion side is pathognomonic for hypoglossal nucleus involvement in medial medullary infarct.
• Always assess strength, proprioception, and multiple cranial nerves in suspected brainstem strokes to localize the vascular territory.
• Vertebral artery origin stenosis can present subtly with transient brainstem symptoms; consider CTA/MRA even with mild deficits.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing medial and lateral medullary syndromes: medial involves hypoglossal nerve and contralateral motor loss; lateral spares motor tracts and involves nucleus ambiguus.
2. Over-attributing any brainstem weakness to basilar artery occlusion; precise cranial nerve involvement distinguishes pontine from medullary lesions.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA (2019) “Guidelines for the Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke”
• Recommendation: Perform emergent vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) in suspected posterior circulation strokes to identify vertebral artery occlusion (Class I, Level B-R).
2. European Stroke Organisation (ESO) (2021) “Guidelines on Management of Posterior Circulation Stroke”
• Recommendation: Use high-resolution MRI for precise localization in brainstem infarcts; consider vessel wall imaging to differentiate etiologies (Class IIa, Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Brainstem stroke syndromes (medial vs lateral) are high-yield topics tested as single best‐answer questions, often requiring recognition of crossed signs and specific cranial nerve involvement.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] - The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the lateral cerebral cortex; large‐vessel occlusions produce severe deficits and large penumbras.
• Intravenous alteplase (IV tPA) within 4.5 h and mechanical thrombectomy (MT) within 6 h are class I interventions to salvage penumbral tissue.
• A history of ischemic stroke within 3 months is a relative, not absolute, contraindication to tPA; benefit often outweighs hemorrhage risk in large‐vessel occlusion (LVO).
• Bridging therapy (tPA + MT) maximizes early reperfusion and improves functional outcomes in anterior LVO.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option B is correct because:
• AHA/ASA guidelines (Powers et al. 2021 update) give Class I, Level A recommendation for IV alteplase in eligible patients within 4.5 h, even with a stroke 2 months ago (relative exclusion).
• Mechanical thrombectomy for anterior circulation LVO within 6 h (Class I, Level A) greatly increases recanalization rates (~70–80%) versus IV tPA alone (~30% for LVO).
• Trials such as MR CLEAN and ESCAPE showed that bridging therapy reduces disability at 90 days (OR ~1.7, p<0.01).
• Combined therapy addresses both microvascular and macrovascular occlusion, optimizing penumbral salvage.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. IV tPA alone
• Incorrect: Recanalization rates for LVO are low (~30%). Relies solely on fibrinolysis; MT needed for large clots.
• Misconception: tPA suffices for all ischemic strokes.

C. DAPT
• Incorrect: Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) is indicated for minor stroke/TIA prevention over 21 days, not acute LVO management.
• Misconception: All ischemic strokes benefit from DAPT acutely.

D. IV heparin
• Incorrect: No evidence supports unfractionated heparin in acute LVO; increases hemorrhagic transformation risk.
• Misconception: Systemic anticoagulation prevents clot propagation in hyperacute stroke.

Comparison Table

InterventionTime WindowRecanalization Rate in LVOKey ContraindicationsGuideline Strength
IV tPA + MT0–4.5 h / 0–6 h~75–80%Relative: stroke <3 monthsI, A
IV tPA alone0–4.5 h~30%Relative: stroke <3 monthsI, A
DAPTPost-TIA/minorn/aNot for acute LVOI, B (for minor stroke)
IV heparinNot recommendedn/aHigh hemorrhage riskIII, C

Clinical Pearls

- Prior stroke <3 months is relative, not absolute, contraindication to IV tPA; weigh risk/benefit in severe LVO.
• Always assess large‐vessel occlusion with CTA/MRA to plan for MT.
• “Door-to-needle” time <60 min and “door-to-groin” puncture <90 min are critical metrics.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Treating LVO with tPA alone due to underestimating clot burden.
2. Overgeneralizing DAPT indications from minor stroke/TIA to all ischemic strokes.
3. Misinterpreting relative vs absolute tPA exclusions, leading to underuse in high-benefit scenarios.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines 2021 (Powers et al.): Class I, LOE A for IV alteplase ≤4.5 h even with stroke 3 months prior; Class I, LOE A for MT ≤6 h in anterior LVO.
• CHOICE Trial (Stroke, 2023): Bridging therapy (IV tPA + MT) yielded higher 90-day functional independence (mRS 0–2) compared to direct MT alone (OR 1.5, p=0.02).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam.
High-yield for stroke management questions: they often test time windows, contraindications to tPA, and indications for mechanical thrombectomy.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] - Acute ischemic stroke evaluation prioritizes exclusion of hemorrhage (via non-contrast CT) and identification of occlusive large-vessel disease.
• CT Angiography (CTA) rapidly delineates arterial anatomy to detect large vessel occlusions amenable to mechanical thrombectomy.
• Time-sensitive decision-making: while thrombolysis is limited by strict windows/contraindications, endovascular therapy extends to 24 hours in selected patients based on vessel imaging and perfusion criteria.

(Word count: 84)

Evidence-Based Analysis

CTA is the correct next step when tPA is not given because current guidelines (AHA/ASA 2018; ESO 2021) recommend vessel imaging in all suspected acute ischemic strokes to identify large-vessel occlusions for endovascular therapy. The 2018 AHA/ASA guideline (Class I, Level A) states: “Perform CTA immediately after non-contrast CT to assess intracranial and extracranial vessels in patients with suspected large-vessel occlusion.” The DAWN (2018) and DEFUSE-3 (2018) trials extended the thrombectomy window to 6–24 hours in patients selected by advanced imaging. Without CTA, you cannot triage to mechanical thrombectomy, potentially missing a treatable large-vessel occlusion.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Check for contraindications to thrombolysis
• This step is done prior to administering tPA, not after deciding tPA is not indicated.
• Misconception: believing contraindication review substitutes vessel imaging.
• CTA instead directly evaluates salvageable brain tissue and occlusion.

C. Admit for observation
• Passive observation delays identification of large-vessel occlusion and endovascular therapy.
• Misconception: assuming normal CT obviates need for further imaging.
• CTA is time-critical to preserve penumbra.

D. Start anticoagulation
• Full anticoagulation is not indicated in acute ischemic stroke unless specific cardioembolic source proven and hemorrhage excluded by advanced imaging.
• Misconception: equating acute management of atrial fibrillation–related stroke with immediate anticoagulation.
• CTA guides mechanical thrombectomy, not anticoagulation decisions.

Comparison Table

OptionKey FeatureBenefitDrawback
AContraindication review for tPAEnsures safety for thrombolysisIrrelevant once tPA is ruled out
B (Correct)CT AngiographyIdentifies large‐vessel occlusion, triages to thrombectomyRequires contrast, minimal delay
CObservationAvoids immediate interventionsMisses therapeutic window
DAnticoagulationTargets cardioembolic strokesRisk of hemorrhage, not first step

Clinical Pearls

- Always obtain CTA promptly when non-contrast CT is negative but suspicion for acute stroke remains, even outside thrombolysis window.
• Mechanical thrombectomy yields benefit up to 24 hours in selected patients; vessel imaging is mandatory for eligibility.
• Normal non-contrast CT does not exclude large vessel occlusion or evolving infarct.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating a “normal” CT with no need for further imaging—this overlooks penumbral tissue at risk.
2. Starting anticoagulation reflexively in acute stroke without confirming hemorrhage absence and cardioembolic source.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines: Class I, Level A recommendation for CTA immediately after non-contrast CT in suspected large-vessel occlusion.
• DAWN Trial (NEJM 2018): Demonstrated thrombectomy benefit 6–24 hours post-onset when selected by vessel and perfusion imaging (NIHSS ≥10, mismatch criteria).
• DEFUSE-3 (NEJM 2018): Extended window to 16 hours with favorable penumbral imaging (Class IIA, Level B).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Immediate non-contrast CT to exclude hemorrhage.
2. If no contraindication and within 4.5 h, assess for tPA—if not indicated, proceed.
3. Perform CTA head/neck to detect large-vessel occlusion.
4. If LVO present and within thrombectomy window, activate neurointerventional team.
5. Consider CT perfusion or MR perfusion for extended-window candidates (6–24 h).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Non-contrast CT rules out hemorrhage; CTA visualizes arterial occlusion, contrast filling defects, tandem lesions.
• CT perfusion can quantify core vs penumbra but CTA alone suffices for initial occlusion detection.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Vessel imaging in acute stroke is frequently tested on neurology boards, often in the context of choosing between tPA, mechanical thrombectomy, or supportive care timing.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Superior cerebellar artery (SCA) strokes injure the superior cerebellum, including the cerebellar hemispheres, vermis, and deep nuclei.
• The cerebellar vermis and hemispheres coordinate axial and appendicular motor control—lesions produce truncal and limb ataxia.
• The SCA spares vestibular nuclei (posterior fossa), so vestibular‐mediated vertigo is less prominent than cerebellar signs.
• Dysarthria and nystagmus may occur with any cerebellar lesion but are secondary to vermian versus hemispheric involvement.

(Word count: ~82)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Ataxia is the hallmark of SCA infarction because the artery supplies the superior cerebellar hemisphere and vermis, regions responsible for gait and truncal stability. A prospective series by Kim and Caplan (Neurology 2006;67:1285–1293) found gait/truncal ataxia in 90% of isolated SCA infarcts versus vertigo in 35%. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association 2018 guidelines on posterior circulation stroke emphasize that cerebellar signs—particularly ataxia—are the most sensitive indicators of cerebellar artery involvement (Class I, Level A). In contrast, vertigo predominates in PICA or AICA infarcts due to closer proximity to vestibular nuclei.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Vertigo
– Although vestibular symptoms occur in ~30–40% of SCA strokes, they are more characteristic of PICA/AICA lesions.
– Misconception: Any cerebellar infarct causes vertigo; in reality, SCA infarcts spare vestibular nuclei.

C. Nystagmus
– Seen in ~50% of cerebellar infarcts but nonspecific and less prominent than ataxia.
– Differs from ataxia in that it reflects oculomotor pathway involvement rather than limb/truncal coordination.

D. Dysarthria
– Occurs in ~40–60% of SCA strokes but never as isolated a finding and less frequent/severe than gait instability.
– Often coexists with ataxia rather than standing alone as the primary deficit.

Comparison Table

DeficitFrequency in SCA InfarctLocalizationKey Distinction
Ataxia (gait/truncal)~85–95%Cerebellar vermis & hemispheresPrimary manifestation of SCA involvement
Vertigo~30–40%Vestibular nuclei (spared)More common in PICA/AICA lesions
Nystagmus~45–55%Flocculonodular lobeOculomotor sign, less specific
Dysarthria~40–60%Cerebellar hemisphere/vermisSecondary sign, often co‐occurs

Clinical Pearls

• In cerebellar stroke syndromes, always perform heel–knee–shin and finger–nose–finger tests to quantify ataxia.
• SCA infarctions can cause mass effect and hydrocephalus; early MRI prevents misdiagnosis as peripheral vertigo.
• Distinguish cerebellar from vestibular vertigo: cerebellar deletion has dysmetria, preserved head‐impulse test.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating any posterior fossa stroke with vertigo—students often over-call vestibular signs in SCA infarcts.
2. Focusing on dysarthria as the key cerebellar sign; ignoring that truncal/gait ataxia is more sensitive.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2018 Stroke Guidelines: “Cerebellar signs, particularly ataxia, are the most sensitive markers of cerebellar infarction” (Class I, Level A).
• ESO 2022 Posterior Circulation Stroke Guidelines: Recommend early MRI DWI for suspected cerebellar strokes to detect small SCA infarcts (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The SCA arises just distal to the basilar apex, supplying the superior cerebellum (dentate nucleus, superior vermis, superior peduncle). Lesions disrupt Purkinje cell outputs to deep nuclei, producing marked gait and truncal instability.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thromboembolic occlusion of the SCA leads to ischemia in cerebellar cortex and deep nuclei. Neuronal energy failure in Purkinje cells impairs inhibitory cerebellar output, resulting in incoordination.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: acute gait/truncal ataxia without cranial nerve deficits.
2. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage (often normal in early posterior fossa strokes).
3. Emergent MRI with DWI to confirm SCA infarct.
4. Vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) to identify vessel occlusion.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• CT may miss early SCA infarcts—MRI DWI is >90% sensitive within hours.
• Infarct appears as restricted diffusion in superior cerebellar hemisphere/vermis on MRI.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• IV alteplase within 4.5 h of symptom onset (per AHA/ASA 2018).
• Antiplatelet therapy (aspirin) started 24 h post‐thrombolysis or immediately if no tPA.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam.
Superior cerebellar artery infarctions are frequently tested in both multiple‐choice and clinical vignettes, often contrasting ataxia‐predominant SCA strokes with vertigo‐predominant PICA/AICA lesions.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] 1. Vascular territories: The anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) supplies the lateral pons, facial nerve nucleus, vestibulocochlear nerve, and gives off the labyrinthine artery to the inner ear.
2. Lateral pontine syndrome: Characterized by ipsilateral facial paralysis, loss of ipsilateral corneal reflex, ipsilateral hearing loss (cochlear nucleus), and contralateral pain/temperature loss from the body.
3. Differential from lateral medullary (PICA) syndrome: PICA infarcts spare cochlear structures and do not cause ipsilateral hearing loss.

(Word count: 94)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The hallmark of an AICA infarct is ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss, due to occlusion of the labyrinthine branch that arises from AICA in ~85% of individuals (Kim JS et al., Neurology 2019). Diffusion-weighted MRI in acute brainstem strokes consistently shows that lesions in the ventrolateral pons affecting the cochlear nucleus correlate with audiometric deficits (Chen L et al., Stroke 2020). The 2019 AHA/ASA Stroke Guidelines recommend that posterior circulation infarcts, including lateral pontine (AICA) strokes, undergo the same emergent vascular imaging and reperfusion considerations as anterior circulation strokes (Class I; Level A evidence). Early recognition of hearing loss in brainstem syndromes is crucial: urgent MRI can identify small pontine infarcts not seen on CT and guide thrombolysis or thrombectomy (Markus HS et al., Lancet Neurol 2021).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA)
• Why incorrect: PICA supplies the lateral medulla and inferior cerebellum; infarction causes Wallenberg’s syndrome without cochlear involvement.
• Misconception: Assuming all posterior fossa strokes present with facial and auditory symptoms.
• Differentiator: PICA infarcts produce dysphagia, hoarseness, ipsilateral Horner’s, but spare hearing.

C. Superior Cerebellar Artery (SCA)
• Why incorrect: SCA supplies the superior cerebellar cortex and some midbrain; infarcts cause ataxia, dysmetria, and oculomotor deficits, not isolated hearing loss.
• Misconception: Equating cerebellar artery distribution with brainstem nerve nuclei involvement.
• Differentiator: SCA strokes lack facial paralysis and auditory pathway involvement.

D. Basilar Artery
• Why incorrect: Basilar artery occlusion causes bilateral pontine signs (e.g., locked-in syndrome) or ‘crossed’ sensory/motor deficits; isolated hearing loss is not a feature.
• Misconception: Attributing any pontine syndrome to basilar lesions.
• Differentiator: Basilar infarcts produce coma or bilateral motor paralysis, not unilateral hearing loss.

Comparison Table

FeatureAICA (Correct)PICASCABasilar Artery
Vascular territoryLateral pons + labyrinthine arteryLateral medulla + inferior cerebellumSuperior cerebellum + midbrainVentral pons + paramedian branches
Key nuclei involvedFacial nucleus, cochlear nucleusNucleus ambiguus, vestibular nucleiSuperior cerebellar peduncleCorticospinal tracts, pontine nuclei
Hearing lossIpsilateral sensorineural [Yes]NoNoRare
Facial paralysisIpsilateral [Yes]NoNoPossible bilateral
Sensory loss (body)Contralateral pain/tempContralateral pain/tempVariableVariable

Clinical Pearls

- Ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss in a lateral brainstem syndrome almost pathognomonic for AICA infarction.
• AICA gives rise to the labyrinthine artery in most individuals—occlusion causes acute cochlear ischemia.
• Always obtain diffusion-weighted MRI for posterior fossa stroke suspected when CT is normal.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing facial motor versus sensory deficits in AICA versus PICA strokes—only AICA causes facial paralysis.
2. Assuming all cerebellar artery strokes (SCA, PICA, AICA) can present with hearing loss; only AICA involves the cochlear apparatus.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke
• Recommendation: Posterior circulation strokes, including AICA infarcts, warrant emergent vascular imaging and consideration for reperfusion therapies identical to anterior circulation strokes (Class I; Level A).
2. European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 Guidelines on Posterior Circulation Stroke
• Recommendation: In acute brainstem syndromes with auditory involvement, prioritize MRI with DWI and MRA to localize AICA territory infarcts (Class IIa; Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam.
Lateral pontine (AICA) versus lateral medullary (PICA) syndromes are frequently tested on neurology and neuroanatomy sections of board exams, often presented as clinical vignettes emphasizing hearing loss or facial paralysis to distinguish vascular distributions.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] - The medulla oblongata’s medial two-thirds are supplied by the anterior spinal artery (ASA), a paired branch of the vertebral arteries.
• Occlusion of the ASA produces medial medullary (Dejerine) syndrome: interruption of the pyramid causes contralateral hemiparesis; medial lemniscus lesions produce contralateral loss of vibration and proprioception; hypoglossal nucleus/fibers involvement leads to ipsilateral tongue weakness and deviation toward the side of the lesion.
• By contrast, posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) infarction yields lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome with nucleus ambiguus signs (dysphagia, hoarseness) and contralateral pain/temperature loss, sparing corticospinal tracts and hypoglossal function.

(Word count: 117)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Medial medullary syndrome is classically due to ASA occlusion. The ASA arises just distal to the vertebral arteries and runs caudally along the ventral surface of the medulla. Infarction produces a wedge-shaped lesion visible on diffusion-weighted MRI. According to the 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Patients with Acute Ischemic Stroke (Class I, Level B-R), high-resolution MRI with DWI is recommended to detect brainstem infarcts. Hypoglossal nucleus lies in the floor of the fourth ventricle; its involvement explains tongue deviation toward the lesion side (lower motor neuron pattern). Atherosclerosis and arterial dissection of vertebral arteries are common etiologies. Literature reviews (e.g., Saver et al., Stroke 2016) emphasize precise clinical localization to guide rapid imaging and reperfusion decisions.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Vertebral artery
• Why incorrect: Main vertebral trunk occlusion often produces PICA or extensive cerebellar infarcts rather than isolated medial medullary signs.
• Misconception: Equating vertebral occlusion directly with ASA territory infarction.
• Differentiator: Vertebral occlusion yields nucleus ambiguus signs (dysphagia), cerebellar ataxia, or PICA pattern rather than pure ASA triad.

C. Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
• Why incorrect: PICA infarcts cause lateral medullary syndrome—ipsilateral facial pain/temperature loss, dysphagia, hoarseness—without contralateral hemiparesis or tongue deviation.
• Misconception: Confusing “medullary” distribution with medial involvement.
• Differentiator: PICA spares corticospinal tracts and hypoglossal nucleus.

D. Basilar artery
• Why incorrect: Basilar artery occlusion produces pontine syndromes (e.g., locked-in syndrome) with bilateral motor and cranial nerve deficits not isolated to medulla.
• Misconception: Assuming any brainstem infarct arises from basilar involvement.
• Differentiator: Basilar stroke presents with quadriplegia, horizontal gaze palsy, or ‘crossed’ ptosis, not solitary tongue deviation and hemiparesis.

Comparison Table

FeatureAnterior Spinal Artery (Medial Medullary)Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (Lateral Medullary)
Motor DeficitContralateral hemiparesisNone
Sensory Deficit (Body)Contralateral vibration/proprioceptionContralateral pain/temperature
Cranial Nerve InvolvementHypoglossal (XII): ipsilateral tongue weakness/deviationNucleus ambiguus (IX, X): dysphagia, hoarseness
Additional SignsAbsent facial nucleus signsIpsilateral facial pain/temperature loss, ataxia, vertigo

Clinical Pearls

- The triad of contralateral hemiparesis, contralateral proprioceptive loss, and ipsilateral tongue deviation localizes strongly to medial medullary syndrome.
• Tongue deviation in a brainstem stroke indicates hypoglossal nucleus/fiber involvement; deviation is toward the lesion side.
• On MRI DWI, medial medullary infarcts appear as narrow, heart-shaped diffusion restrictions ventromedially.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mislocalizing tongue deviation to nucleus ambiguus involvement and prescribing swallowing studies unnecessarily.
• Confusing PICA (lateral medullary) syndrome with medial medullary infarction—failing to note absence of hemiparesis in PICA strokes.
• Overattributing any medullary stroke to vertebral artery occlusion without considering branch-specific syndromes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Stroke 2018): Recommends urgent MRI DWI for posterior circulation syndromes to guide reperfusion (Class I, Level B-R).
• ESO–ESMINT 2021 Guidelines on Acute Stroke Intervention: Emphasize endovascular treatment for basilar/vertebral trunk occlusions (Class I, Level A) but note that small-vessel ASA occlusions are managed medically.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The ASA supplies ventral medulla structures: corticospinal tracts (pyramids), medial lemniscus, hypoglossal nucleus and exiting fibers. Hypoglossal fibers emerge between the pyramid and olive, making them vulnerable in medial lesions.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Occlusion of the ASA—often by atherosclerotic plaque at its vertebral origin or dissection—produces end-artery infarction. There is minimal collateral flow in the medial medullary territory, leading to sharply demarcated wedge-shaped infarction.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Recognize the clinical triad (hemiparesis, proprioceptive loss, tongue deviation).
2. Exclude hemorrhage with non-contrast CT.
3. Confirm infarct with MRI DWI.
4. Perform CT/MR angiography to evaluate vertebral, basilar, and ASA patency.
5. Initiate reperfusion therapy if within window; begin antiplatelet and risk-factor management.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- DWI sequences best detect early brainstem infarcts.
• CT angiography can sometimes visualize ASA occlusion but is limited by vessel size—focus on vertebral artery origins and basilar patency.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Intravenous alteplase 0.9 mg/kg within 4.5 hours of symptom onset.
• Post-acute management with aspirin (81–325 mg daily) and statin therapy aiming for LDL <70 mg/dL.
• Consider dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin plus clopidogrel) for 21 days in high-risk small-vessel stroke per CHANCE trial.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Medullary infarction syndromes (medial vs lateral) are frequently tested as clinical vignettes, emphasizing triad localization, artery‐structure relationships, and differentiation from cerebellar or pontine strokes.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Malignant MCA infarction involves cytotoxic and vasogenic edema in ≥50% of the MCA territory, leading to raised intracranial pressure (ICP) and risk of herniation. Early recognition (within 48 hours) is critical, as maximal swelling peaks at 3–5 days. Neuroanatomically, the MCA supplies lateral frontal, parietal lobes, and basal ganglia; massive infarction disrupts autoregulation and triggers edema. Decompressive hemicraniectomy creates space for swelling, lowers ICP, and prevents secondary brainstem compression.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Decompressive hemicraniectomy within 48 hours in patients ≤60 years reduces mortality (from ~80% to ~30%) and increases favorable outcomes (modified Rankin Scale ≤3 at 6 months). The DECIMAL (2007), DESTINY (2007) and HAMLET (2009) randomized trials showed absolute mortality reduction of ~50% (NNT≈2). The 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines endorse early hemicraniectomy as a Class I, Level A recommendation for malignant MCA infarction in patients 18–60 years. Waiting for midline shift or trialing only medical therapies delays definitive treatment and worsens outcome.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Osmotic therapy
• Osmotic agents (mannitol, hypertonic saline) provide transient ICP reduction but do not address mass effect from large infarct.
• Misconception: medical therapy alone suffices; in malignant edema, surgical decompression is required.

C. Aspirin
• Antiplatelet therapy is indicated for secondary prevention but has no role in managing life-threatening cerebral edema.
• Differentiator: aspirin cannot reduce established cytotoxic swelling.

D. Supportive care and monitoring
• Monitoring without intervention allows progressive herniation.
• Key error: malignant MCA infarction demands proactive intervention; supportive care alone is insufficient.

Comparison Table

FeatureHemicraniectomyOsmotic TherapyAspirinSupportive Care
MechanismSurgical skull-fenestration to lower ICPOsmotic shift of water from brain parenchymaInhibits platelet aggregationGeneral ICU support
TimingWithin 48 hours of stroke onsetAt any sign of elevated ICP (adjunctive)At 24 hours post-thrombolysisContinuous
Mortality Reduction~50% absoluteTransient, minimal impactNone in edemaNone
Functional OutcomeImproved mRS ≤3 at 6 monthsNo proven long-term benefitNo impact on herniationNo impact
IndicationMalignant MCA infarct ≥50% territoryRaised ICP without surgical optionSecondary preventionBaseline care only

Clinical Pearls

- Hemicraniectomy is most effective if performed within 48 hours, ideally before clinical herniation signs.
• Age <60 years: strongest evidence; DESTINY II (2014) extends benefit to older patients for survival but with higher disability.
• Infarct extent >50% MCA territory on CT is threshold for “malignant” classification.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Waiting for midline shift on imaging before consulting neurosurgery—delay increases irreversible injury.
2. Relying solely on osmotic diuretics—fails to address fixed mass; only temporizes ICP.
3. Assuming antiplatelet agents modify edema—misunderstands pathophysiology of cytotoxic swelling.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of AIS: Class I, LOE A recommendation for decompressive hemicraniectomy within 48 hours in patients 18–60 years with malignant MCA infarction.
• DESTINY II Trial (Juttler et al., Lancet Neurol 2014): randomized older patients (>60 years) and demonstrated decreased mortality (45% vs 75%, p<0.001) though with greater residual disability; supports expanded surgical criteria (Level of Evidence B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam.
Malignant MCA infarction and indications for decompressive hemicraniectomy are high-yield topics, frequently tested as scenario-based questions focusing on timing, imaging criteria, and age limits.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] CADASIL (Cerebral Autosomal Dominant Arteriopathy with Subcortical Infarcts and Leukoencephalopathy) is a hereditary small-vessel disease caused by NOTCH3 mutations leading to vascular smooth muscle cell degeneration and arteriolar fibrosis. Key principles:
• Small vessel occlusion in deep white matter and basal ganglia produces lacunar infarcts, migraines, cognitive decline, and strokes.
• Vascular risk factors (especially smoking, hypertension) exacerbate endothelial dysfunction and accelerate ischemic injury in CADASIL.
• No disease-modifying therapy exists; management focuses on reducing modifiable stroke risks.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Smoking increases oxidative stress and endothelial damage, amplifying the small-vessel pathology in CADASIL. Observational cohorts demonstrate smokers with CADASIL suffer strokes ~5 years earlier than non-smokers. The 2018 AHA/ASA Primary Prevention of Stroke Guideline (Class I, Level A) and USPSTF 2020 Tobacco Cessation Recommendation (Grade A) both emphasize clinician-led smoking cessation as a cornerstone of stroke prevention.
Warfarin carries heightened intracerebral hemorrhage risk in leukoencephalopathy and microbleeds; no data support anticoagulation.
Aspirin’s benefit in CADASIL is unproven and may increase microbleed burden without reducing lacunar infarcts.
Abstaining from any intervention forfeits the only evidence-backed strategy to delay stroke onset in this population.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Anticoagulant (warfarin)
• Why incorrect: Elevated hemorrhage risk in leukoaraiosis; no RCT data supporting anticoagulation for CADASIL.
• Misconception: Confusing cardioembolic prophylaxis with small-vessel stroke prevention.
• Differentiator: Anticoagulation indicated for atrial fibrillation, not for genetic arteriopathy.

C. Aspirin
• Why incorrect: Limited observational data fail to show stroke risk reduction; may worsen microbleeds.
