• Misconception: Assuming antiplatelet therapy universally benefits all ischemic stroke subtypes.
• Differentiator: Unlike smoking cessation (an upstream risk factor), aspirin acts downstream on platelets with unclear net benefit.

D. No treatment
• Why incorrect: Ignores established benefit of risk factor modification; misses an opportunity to delay first stroke.
• Misconception: Belief that genetic conditions are untreatable so management is futile.
• Differentiator: Even in monogenic disease, secondary prevention via lifestyle is impactful.

Comparison Table

FeatureSmoking Cessation (A)Warfarin (B)Aspirin (C)No Treatment (D)
MechanismReduces endothelial oxidative damageInhibits vitamin K-dependent clotting factorsInhibits platelet cyclo-oxygenaseNone
Evidence in CADASILObservational benefit; delays stroke onsetNo data; risk of hemorrhageNo proven benefit; risk of microbleedsN/A
Key BenefitLowers stroke risk; slows SVD progressionPrevents cardioembolic strokes (not relevant here)Secondary prevention in atherothrombotic diseaseNone
Main RiskNicotine withdrawal (manageable)Intracerebral hemorrhageIncreased microbleed burdenContinued risk factor exposure

Clinical Pearls

- CADASIL patients who quit smoking may delay their first stroke by 4–6 years compared to continuing smokers.
• Routine anticoagulation is contraindicated unless there is a separate cardioembolic indication.
• Discuss nicotine replacement therapy and behavioral counseling early in CADASIL clinics.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating small-vessel stroke prevention with anticoagulation—CADASIL pathology is non-embolic.
2. Overgeneralizing aspirin’s benefit from large-artery ischemic stroke to genetic small-vessel disease.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association/American Stroke Association, 2018 Primary Prevention of Stroke Guideline: Class I, Level A recommendation for lifestyle modification, including smoking cessation, in all high-risk populations.
• U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, 2020 Tobacco Use in Adults: Clinical Interventions Recommendation: Grade A—clinician-delivered interventions and pharmacotherapy for smoking cessation to prevent cardiovascular and cerebrovascular disease.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

NOTCH3 gene mutations lead to accumulation of granular osmiophilic material and loss of smooth muscle cells in small arterioles. This progressive arteriopathy causes chronic hypoperfusion, lacunar infarction, and leukoencephalopathy. Vascular risk factors potentiate this microvascular injury.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Smoking cessation: First-line involves nicotine replacement, varenicline, bupropion; referral to counseling improves quit rates by 50–70%.
• Warfarin: contraindicated absent cardioembolism; associated with symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage in SVD.
• Aspirin: reserved for conventional atherothrombotic risk; no CADASIL-specific indication.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam.
CADASIL stroke prevention questions often test recognition of modifiable risk factors versus inappropriate use of anticoagulation or antiplatelets in hereditary small-vessel disease.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) are brief episodes of focal neurological dysfunction without infarction. Key principles:
• TIA pathophysiology often involves either cardioembolism or large-artery atherosclerosis (e.g., carotid stenosis).
• After excluding a cardiac source (echocardiogram, Holter), evaluation for extracranial/intracranial stenosis is critical.
• Rapid vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) identifies high-grade carotid lesions that may benefit from urgent endarterectomy or stenting, reducing early stroke risk.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Neck CTA is the optimal next step because it:
1. Provides high-resolution assessment of both extracranial carotid and vertebral arteries and intracranial vessels.
2. Rapidly detects ≥50% stenosis where intervention reduces stroke risk (NASCET criteria).
3. Is recommended as first-line vascular imaging in the 2021 AHA/ASA TIA/Stroke guidelines (Class I, LOE A).
Brain MRI, while sensitive for silent infarcts, does not evaluate vessel lumen. Carotid Doppler ultrasound misses high cervical and intracranial lesions and has lower sensitivity (88% vs. 98% for CTA). EEG is irrelevant in suspected ischemia.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Brain MRI
• Incorrect: Does not assess carotid/vertebral artery stenosis.
• Misconception: MRI is diagnostic for stroke but not a substitute for vascular imaging in TIA.
• Differentiator: MRI shows tissue changes; CTA shows vessel patency.

C. Carotid Doppler ultrasound
• Incorrect: Limited to extracranial carotids, operator-dependent, can miss high lesions.
• Misconception: “Ultrasound is always first” – but CTA offers comprehensive head/neck coverage.
• Differentiator: Doppler sensitivity ~88% vs. CTA >95% for ≥70% stenosis.

D. Electroencephalogram (EEG)
• Incorrect: Evaluates cortical electrical activity in seizures, not vascular stenosis.
• Misconception: TIA might be seizure – but the clinical history here is classic ischemic TIA.
• Differentiator: EEG adds no value in TIA workup.

Comparison Table

FeatureNeck CTABrain MRICarotid Doppler USEEG
Primary PurposeVascular lumen imaging head/neckParenchymal imagingExtracranial carotid flowElectrical brain activity
Sensitivity for ≥70% stenosis>95%N/A~88%N/A
Intracranial vessel assessmentYesLimited (with MRA only)NoNo
Time to performMinutes (CT suite)30–60 min (MRI suite)15–30 min20–40 min
Impact on managementDirect (CEA/stenting decision)Diagnostic (stroke vs. TIA)ScreeningNone for TIA

Clinical Pearls

- Perform vascular imaging within 24 hours of TIA; identify high-grade stenosis to guide carotid endarterectomy.
• NASCET criteria (≥70% symptomatic stenosis) confer greatest surgical benefit.
• CTA also detects vessel dissection, a critical TIA mimic requiring different management.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying solely on carotid Doppler and missing high cervical/intracranial stenoses.
2. Ordering EEG to “rule out seizure” in a classic vascular TIA scenario, delaying critical vascular assessment.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2021 Guideline for the Prevention of Stroke in Patients With Stroke and TIA: Class I recommendation for CTA/MRA of head and neck in TIA (Level A evidence).
• European Stroke Organisation (2022): Strong recommendation for comprehensive vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) within 24 hours of TIA (Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam.
Vascular imaging in TIA is a high-yield topic; examinees should distinguish between parenchymal (MRI) and vascular (CTA/MRA) studies and know the urgency of identifying symptomatic carotid stenosis.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Lacunar infarcts are small (<15 mm) subcortical strokes, often involving the internal capsule, caused by lipohyalinosis of penetrating arterioles from chronic hypertension. Secondary prevention focuses on aggressive blood pressure control and antithrombotic therapy tailored to stroke subtype. While a PFO can be a source of paradoxical embolism, it is often incidental in the presence of a clear small‐vessel etiology. Aspirin monotherapy remains first‐line for lacunar stroke, whereas anticoagulation and PFO closure are reserved for confirmed cardioembolic or cryptogenic strokes in selected patients.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Aspirin 75–325 mg daily reduces recurrent non‐cardioembolic stroke by ≈22% (AHA/ASA 2019 Sec Prev Guideline, Class I, LOE A). The SPS3 trial (2013) randomized 3,020 lacunar stroke patients to aspirin vs. aspirin + clopidogrel; dual therapy showed no ischemic benefit and a 50% increase in major hemorrhage. Anticoagulation with warfarin is indicated for atrial fibrillation or venous thromboembolism, not for small‐vessel disease. PFO closure trials (RESPECT 2017, CLOSE 2017) demonstrated benefit only in cryptogenic stroke patients <60 years without alternative risk factors. Here, the lacunar pattern and poorly controlled hypertension point to small‐vessel pathology—aspirin plus tight blood pressure management is optimal.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Warfarin
• Reason incorrect: Targets cardioembolic sources; lacunar strokes are non‐cardioembolic.
• Misconception: Equating PFO presence with embolic stroke requiring anticoagulation.
• Differentiator: No evidence of atrial fibrillation or venous source.

C. PFO closure
• Reason incorrect: Benefit shown only in select cryptogenic strokes without other causes.
• Misconception: Any detected PFO mandates closure.
• Differentiator: Imaging shows lacunar infarct consistent with hypertension‐related small‐vessel disease.

D. Aspirin and Plavix
• Reason incorrect: Long‐term dual antiplatelet therapy increases bleeding without added efficacy in lacunar stroke (SPS3).
• Misconception: More intensive antithrombotic therapy always yields better outcomes.
• Differentiator: DAPT is limited to ≤21 days post-minor non‐cardioembolic stroke (CHANCE/POINT).

Comparison Table

FeatureAspirin MonotherapyWarfarinPFO ClosureAspirin + Clopidogrel
IndicationLacunar small‐vessel strokeCardioembolic strokeCryptogenic stroke with high‐risk PFOMinor non‐cardioembolic stroke
Key guideline/trialAHA/ASA 2019; SPS3AF GuidelinesRESPECT, CLOSECHANCE, POINT
Recurrent stroke reduction22%N/A for lacunesYes, in selected cryptogenic ptsShort‐term benefit only
Major bleeding riskLowModerate–highProcedural/device riskHigh if >21 days

Clinical Pearls

- Lacunar infarcts: hallmark is pure motor/sensory deficits; aggressive BP control (<130/80 mmHg) is as crucial as antiplatelet therapy.
• Short‐term DAPT (≤21 days) reduces early recurrence in minor non‐cardioembolic stroke, but long‐term use raises hemorrhage risk without extra ischemic protection.
• PFO closure should be considered only after ruling out conventional etiologies and in patients <60 years with high‐risk PFO features (e.g., large shunt, septal aneurysm).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Attributing lacunar strokes to embolism solely because of a PFO, leading to unnecessary anticoagulation or closure.
• Overprescribing long‐term dual antiplatelet therapy for lacunar stroke despite SPS3 evidence against it.
• Underemphasizing hypertension control, the most potent modifiable risk factor for small‐vessel strokes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2019 Secondary Stroke Prevention (Stroke 2019;50:e344–e418): Aspirin monotherapy recommended for lacunar stroke (Class I, LOE A); BP target <130/80 mmHg (Class I).
2. SPS3 Trial (Lancet 2013;382:507–516): No benefit of long‐term aspirin + clopidogrel over aspirin alone; increased major bleeding (HR 1.5).
3. RESPECT Trial (NEJM 2017;377:1022–1032): PFO closure vs. medical therapy in cryptogenic stroke; absolute risk reduction ~1%/year in selected <60 years.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Board exams frequently test stroke subtype recognition (lacunar vs. cardioembolic), appropriate secondary prevention (antiplatelet vs. anticoagulant), and criteria for PFO closure. Recognizing imaging patterns and risk profiles is high‐yield.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Angioedema is an acute, potentially life-threatening swelling of the deep dermis and submucosa, often affecting the orolingual area. Intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) used in acute ischemic stroke can provoke orolingual angioedema through plasmin-mediated bradykinin generation, leading to increased vascular permeability. Risk factors include concurrent ACE-inhibitor therapy and insular cortex infarction. Prompt pharmacologic intervention targets histamine-mediated components of the edema, while vigilant airway monitoring prevents asphyxiation. First-line management consists of H1/H2 antihistamines and corticosteroids, with epinephrine reserved for severe or refractory cases; supportive measures include stopping the tPA infusion and ensuring airway protection.

(Word count: 120)

Evidence-Based Analysis

tPA-induced angioedema occurs in approximately 1–5% of thrombolysed stroke patients (Waqar et al., 2013). The underlying mechanism involves plasmin-mediated cleavage of high-molecular-weight kininogen to bradykinin, which binds endothelial B2 receptors, increasing nitric oxide and prostaglandin release and causing vascular leak (Binsfeld et al., 2017). Case series (Hill et al., 2003; Kamath et al., 2015) demonstrate rapid symptom resolution with prompt administration of H1-antagonists (diphenhydramine 25–50 mg IV) plus corticosteroids (methylprednisolone 125 mg IV). The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke recommend this regimen (Class IIa, Level B-NR), noting that epinephrine (0.3–0.5 mg IM) should be used only if airway compromise worsens. These interventions directly counteract histamine release and stabilize endothelial barriers, making “Anti-histamine & steroids” the cornerstone of therapy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Reassurance
• Incorrect: Orolingual angioedema can rapidly progress to airway obstruction.
• Misconception: Assuming mild swelling requires no active treatment.
• Differentiator: Unlike reassurance, antihistamine/steroid therapy halts progression.

B. Intubate
• Incorrect: Prophylactic intubation without attempting medical therapy exposes patients to unnecessary risks.
• Misconception: Belief that airway compromise is inevitable.
• Differentiator: Intubation is reserved for failed medical management or imminent airway collapse.

D. Discontinue tPA
• Incorrect: While stopping infusion removes further bradykinin stimulus, it does not reverse established edema.
• Misconception: Thinking removal of tPA alone treats angioedema.
• Differentiator: Pharmacotherapy is required to actively reduce vascular permeability.

Comparison Table

FeatureAnti-histamine & SteroidsIntubateReassuranceDiscontinue tPA
Primary ActionStabilize endothelium, block histamine receptorsMechanical airway protectionNo active interventionStop further plasmin generation
Onset of Effect15–30 minutesImmediateN/AImmediate
IndicationMild-to-moderate orolingual angioedemaSevere airway compromise or respiratory distressNone—underestimates riskAdjunctive only
Guideline RecommendationAHA/ASA 2018: IIa/B-NRAHA/ASA 2018: IIb/C-LD (if needed)Not recommendedSupportive, not definitive

Clinical Pearls

- ACE-inhibitor use increases tPA-related angioedema risk by up to sixfold; consider heightened monitoring.
• Orolingual swelling often appears contralateral to the infarcted hemisphere due to autonomic dysfunction.
• Early administration of H2-blockers (e.g., ranitidine 50 mg IV) alongside H1-antagonists can enhance edema resolution.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating tPA-induced angioedema with classic IgE-mediated allergy and over-relying on epinephrine alone.
2. Delaying pharmacologic therapy while awaiting airway compromise, falsely believing angioedema is self-limiting.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommend IV diphenhydramine 25–50 mg and methylprednisolone 125 mg for tPA-induced angioedema (Class IIa, Level B-NR).
• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 Guidelines on Acute Ischemic Stroke: Advise prompt H1/H2 blockade plus corticosteroids as first-line therapy for orolingual angioedema post-thrombolysis (Grade C).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

tPA converts plasminogen to plasmin, which not only degrades fibrin but also generates bradykinin via cleavage of high-molecular-weight kininogen. Bradykinin binds endothelial B2 receptors, triggering NO and prostaglandin release, increasing vascular permeability in submucosal tissues. Concomitant ACE inhibitor use impairs bradykinin degradation, exacerbating edema formation.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. Acute stroke management frequently tests tPA complications—recognition of orolingual angioedema and its pharmacologic management is a high-yield topic on neurology boards.
